quote: In view of the course of decisions which have been made since that time, it is very certain that such an ordinance would now be regarded as repugnant to the power conferred upon Congress to regulate commerce among the several States.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the Osborne v. Mobile decision would now be considered unconstitutional given subsequent legal developments, effectively overruling its precedential value.

cited_decision: Pensacola Telegraph Co. v. Western Union Telegraph Co.
quote: In the case of The Pensacola Telegraph Company v. The Western Union Telegraph Company, 96 U. S. 1, we held that it was not only the right, but the duty of Congress to take care that intercourse among the States and the transmission of intelligence between them be not obstructed or unnecessarily incumbered by state legislation
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case favorably to support its reasoning about Congress's power over interstate telegraph communications, without any negative treatment.

quote: In Western Union Telegraph Company v. Texas, 105 U. S. 460, we decided that a State cannot lay a tax on the interstate business of a telegraph company, as it is interstate commerce
rationale: The Acting Decision references this case positively to support its holding that states cannot tax interstate telegraph business, using it as precedential authority.

cited_decision: Robbins v. Shelby County Taxing District
quote: It comes plainly within the principle of the decisions lately made by this court in Robbins v. The Taxing District of Shelby County, 120 U. S. 489
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case as supporting precedent for the principle that occupation taxes on interstate commerce are unconstitutional, applying its reasoning favorably.

cited_decision: Philadelphia & Southern Steamship Co. v. Pennsylvania
quote: It comes plainly within the principle of the decisions lately made by this court in Robbins v. The Taxing District of Shelby County, 120 U. S. 489, and Philadelphia and Southern Steamship Co. v. Pennsylvania, 122 U. S. 326
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case alongside Robbins as supporting precedent for the principle that states cannot impose taxes that burden interstate commerce.

quote: This certificate distinctly presents for decision the question (argued, but not decided, when this case was before this court at a former term, reported in 144 U. S. 653 ) of the construction of the will of Jacob Dawson
rationale: The court merely references the prior proceeding of the same case to provide context for the current decision, without any substantive treatment of the earlier ruling.

quote: The opinion of the Supreme Court of the State appears to have been formed upon full consideration of the difficulties of. the case; and is entitled to great weight, especially upon the construction of the statute of the State. Suydam v. Williamson, 24 How. 427
rationale: The court cites Suydam v. Williamson as support for the general principle that state court opinions on state statute construction are entitled to great weight, without any critical analysis.

quote: He begins by giving her " all my estate, real and personal," which of itself would carry a fee, unless restricted by other words. Lambert v. Paine, 3 Cranch, 97
rationale: The court cites Lambert v. Paine as authority for the established principle that a gift of 'all my estate' carries a fee simple unless restricted, without any substantive discussion or criticism.

cited_decision: Brant v. Virginia Coal & Iron Co.
quote: In Brant v. Virginia Coal Co., the bequest which was held to give a life estate, and no power to convey a fee, was only of the testator's estate, real and personal, to his wife, "to have and to hold during her life, and to do with as she sees proper, before her death." 93 U. S. 327
rationale: The court distinguishes Brant by explaining that the language in that case was different from the current will, specifically noting the limiting phrase 'during her life' which is absent in the present case.

quote: If the clause containing them is repugnant and void, the view of the Supreme Court of Nebraska that the widow took an estate in fee isfortified. See Howard v. Carusi, 109 U. S. 725 ; Potter v. Couch, 141 U. S. 296, 315, 316
rationale: The court cites Howard v. Carusi along with Potter v. Couch as supporting authority for the principle regarding repugnant clauses in wills, without detailed analysis.

quote: If the clause containing them is repugnant and void, the view of the Supreme Court of Nebraska that the widow took an estate in fee isfortified. See Howard v. Carusi, 109 U. S. 725 ; Potter v. Couch, 141 U. S. 296, 315, 316
rationale: The court cites Potter v. Couch along with Howard v. Carusi as supporting authority for the principle regarding repugnant clauses in wills, without detailed analysis.

quote: And this court, on reconsideration of the whole matter, with the aid of the various judicial opinions upon the subject, and of the learned briefs of counsel, is of opinion that the sound construction of this will, as to the extent of the power conferred on the widow, is in accordance with the conclusion of the state court, and not with the former decision of this court, which must, therefore, be considered as overruled.
rationale: The court explicitly states that its former decision in Giles v. Little 'must, therefore, be considered as overruled' after reconsidering the construction of the will and finding the state court's interpretation to be correct.

quote: In Merrill v. Monticello, 138 U. S. 673, 687, 691, it was held that the implied power of a municipal corporation to borrow money to enable it to execute the powers expressly conferred upon it by law, if existing at all, did not authorize it to create and issue negotiable securities to be sold in the market and to be taken by the purchaser freed from the equities that might be set up by the maker
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Merrill v. Monticello approvingly as part of a line of cases establishing the principle that municipal corporations cannot issue negotiable bonds without express authority, providing additional analysis without questioning its precedential value.

quote: We, therefore, must regard the cases of Rogers v. Burlington and Mitchell v. Burlington, as overruled in the particular referred to, by later cases in this court.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Rogers v. Burlington has been overruled by later cases, thus nullifying its precedential value on the question of municipal authority to issue negotiable bonds under a general borrowing power.

quote: In Claiborne County v. Brooks, 111 U. S. 400, it was held that the power to issue commercial paper was foreign to the objects of the creation of the political divisions of counties and townships, and was not to be conceded to such organizations unless by virtue of express legislation or by very strong implication from such legislation
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Claiborne County v. Brooks approvingly as part of the established line of precedent supporting the principle that municipal corporations lack implied authority to issue negotiable securities, without questioning its validity.

quote: We, therefore, must regard the cases of Rogers v. Burlington and Mitchell v. Burlington, as overruled in the particular referred to, by later cases in this court.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Mitchell v. Burlington has been overruled by later cases, thus nullifying its precedential value on the question of municipal authority to issue negotiable bonds under a general borrowing power.

quote: But in Police Jury v. Britton, 15 Wall. 566, it was held that the trustees or representative officers of a parish, county or other local jurisdiction, invested with the usual powers of administration in specific matters, and the power of levying taxes to defray the necessary expenditures of the jurisdiction, have no implied authority to issue negotiable securities
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Police Jury v. Britton approvingly as establishing the principle that municipal bodies lack implied authority to issue negotiable securities, treating it as good law without any criticism or doubt about its precedential value.

quote: Due process of law, this court has held, does not require the State to adopt any particular form of procedure, so long as it appears that the accused has had sufficient notice of the accusation and an adequate opportunity to defend himself in the prosecution. Rogers v. Peck, 199 U. S. 425, 435 , and previous cases in this court there cited.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Rogers v. Peck as supportive authority for the principle that due process does not require specific procedural forms, using it to establish the legal standard without any criticism or limitation.

quote: Holding this view> notwithstanding our reluctance to overrule former decisions of this court, we now are constrained to hold that the technical enforcement of formal rights in criminal procedure sustained in the Crain Case is no longer required in the prosecution of offenses under present systems of law, and so far as that case is not in accord with the views herein expressed it is necessarily overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it is overruling the Crain case, finding that its technical enforcement of formal rights in criminal procedure is no longer required under present systems of law.

quote: The position there taken that the legislature of Texas, while the State was owner of the bonds, could limit their negotiability by an act of legislation, of which all subsequent purchasers were charged with notice, although the bonds on their face were payable to bearer, must be regarded as overruled. And the further position that negotiable government securities, redeemable at the pleasure of the government after a specified day, but in which no date is fixed for final payment, cease to be negotiable as overdue after the day named when they first become redeemable, must be regarded as limited to cases where the title of the purchaser is acquired with notice of the defect of title, or under circumstances which discredit the instrument
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that certain positions from Texas v. White must be regarded as overruled and limited, thereby narrowing the scope and applicability of that decision.

cited_decision: Vermilye & Co. v. Adams Express Co.
quote: But the notes in the case before us have no such feature. They are absolutely payable at a certain time, and we think the case is authority for holding that such an obligation, overdue, ceases to be negotiable in the sense which frees the transaction from all inquiry into the rights of antecedent holders. This ground is sufficient of itself to justify the decree in favor of the Express Company.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Vermilye by noting that the treasury notes in that case were 'absolutely payable at a certain time' unlike the bonds in the present case, showing different factual circumstances requiring different legal treatment.

quote: The rules established in Murray v. Lardner, 2 Wall. 110, 118 — 'that the purchaser of coupon bonds, before due, without notice and in good faith, is unaffected by want of title in the seller, and that the burden of proof in respect-to notice and want of good faith is on,the claimant of the bonds as against the purchaser' — were repeated and reaifirmed
rationale: The Acting Decision simply references the established rules from Murray v. Lardner without any criticism or limitation, merely noting that these rules were reaffirmed in Texas v. White.

quote: The case came before the court again in another aspect, and is reported as Texas v. Hardenberg, 10 Wall. 68, in which the grounds of the former decision were reconsidered and declared to be satisfactory.
rationale: The Acting Decision merely references Texas v. Hardenberg as a case that reconsidered and affirmed the grounds of Texas v. White, without any independent analysis or treatment of Hardenberg itself.

quote: The same questions, as to part of the same issue of bonds, came again before the court in Huntington v. Texas, 16 Wall. 402, in which the two prior decisions were relied on, on behalf of the State of Texas, as conclusive.
rationale: The Acting Decision simply references Huntington v. Texas as another case involving the same bonds where prior decisions were relied upon, without providing any independent treatment or analysis of the Huntington decision.

cited_decision: National Bank of Washington v. Texas
quote: Some of the same issue of bonds were in litigation before this court in National Bank of Washington v. Texas, 20 Wall. 72. In that case the title of the appellant was acquired after the 31st day of December, 1864, when they became redeemable, and they were not indorsed by the governor.
rationale: The Acting Decision references National Bank of Washington v. Texas as part of the series of cases involving the same bonds, providing factual background without any critical analysis or treatment of the decision's precedential value.

quote: 'To hold otherwise,' said this court in Cromwell v. County of Sac, 96 U. S. 51, 58, 'would throw discredit upon a large class of securities issued by municipal and private corporations, having years to run, with interest payable annually or semi-annually.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Cromwell v. County of Sac supportively to reinforce a principle about securities and interest payments, without any criticism or limitation of the cited decision.

quote: And the doctrine was reaffirmed in Railway Co. v. Sprague, 103 U. S. 756.
rationale: The Acting Decision simply notes that Railway Co. v. Sprague reaffirmed the doctrine from Cromwell v. County of Sac, without providing any independent analysis or treatment of the Sprague decision.

quote: It must be regarded as a settled doctrine of this court, established by its recent decisions, that the question whether a suit is within the prohibition of the 11th Amendment is not always determined by reference to the nominal parties on the record. Poindexter v. Greenhow, 114 U.S. 270, 287.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Poindexter v. Greenhow as establishing settled doctrine regarding the 11th Amendment analysis, referencing it as authority without criticism or negative treatment.

quote: The grounds of this jurisdiction were stated in Allen v. Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Co., 114 U.S. 311. The vital principle in all such cases is that the defendants, though professing to act as officers of the State, are threatening a violation of the personal or property rights of the complainant, for which they are personally and individually liable.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Allen v. Baltimore & Ohio Railroad as establishing the grounds for jurisdiction in cases involving state officers, citing it as supportive authority without negative treatment.

quote: And the point as involved in that case was stated by Mr. Justice Swayne, delivering the opinion of the court in Davis v. Gray, 16 Wall. 203, 220, as follows: In deciding who are parties to the suit the court will not look beyond the record.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Davis v. Gray to explain the principle about determining parties to a suit, referencing it as authority for a legal principle without criticism.

cited_decision: Commonwealth of Ky. v. DENNISON, GOVERNOR, &C.
quote: This view was reiterated by this court in Kentucky v. Dennison, 24 How. 66, 98, where it was said to be settled, that where the State is a party, plaintiff or defendant, the Governor represents the State, and the suit may be, in form, a suit by him as Governor in behalf of the State, where the State is plaintiff, and he must be summoned or notified as the officer representing the State, where the State is defendant.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Kentucky v. Dennison as reiterating established principles about state representation in suits, using it as supportive authority without negative treatment.

quote: The converse of that case is to be found in Hagood v. Southern, 117 U.S. 52. There, the State of South Carolina, which was the party in interest, was not nominally a defendant... The decrees of the Circuit Court granting the relief were reversed, and the cause remanded, with instructions to dismiss the bills, on the ground that the suits, though nominally against the officers of the State, were really against the State itself.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Hagood v. Southern as a precedent that supports its analysis of when suits against state officers are actually suits against the state, using it as supportive authority.

quote: This principle is illustrated and enforced by the case of United States v. Lee, 106 U.S. 196. In that case the plaintiffs had been wrongfully dispossessed of their real estate by defendants, claiming to act under the authority of the United States.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites United States v. Lee as illustrating and enforcing the principle that defendants claiming governmental authority must show lawful authority, using it as supportive precedent.

cited_decision: Osborn v. Bank of United States
quote: But what was said by Chief Justice Marshall in Osborn v. Bank of the United States, supra, must be taken in connection with its immediate context... There is nothing, therefore, in the judgment in that cause, as finally defined, which extends its authority beyond the prevention and restraint of the specific act done in pursuance of the unconstitutional statute of Ohio, and in violation of the act of Congress chartering the bank, which consisted of the unlawful seizure and detention of its property.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Osborn v. Bank of United States by limiting its scope and explaining how the present case differs factually, noting that Osborn involved specific property seizure while the current case involves different circumstances.

quote: It follows that the cases of Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co., 94 U. S. 535 , and Security Mutual Life Insurance Co. v. Prewitt, 202 U. S. 246 , must be considered as overruled and that the views of the minority judges in those cases have become the law of this court.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co. must be considered as overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value.

cited_decision: Security Mutual Life Insurance Co. v. Prewitt
quote: It follows that the cases of Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co., 94 U. S. 535 , and Security Mutual Life Insurance Co. v. Prewitt, 202 U. S. 246 , must be considered as overruled and that the views of the minority judges in those cases have become the law of this court.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Security Mutual Life Insurance Co. v. Prewitt must be considered as overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value.

quote: The case was heard on bill and answer, and is to be considered on the averments of the bill which are not denied by the answer. Iowa v. Illinois, 147 U. S. 1, 7 .
rationale: The case is cited merely as procedural authority for how to consider averments in a bill that are not denied by the answer, without any substantive discussion or treatment.

quote: The cases in. this court in which the conflict between the power of a State to exclude a foreign corporation from doing business within its borders, and the federal constitutional right of such foreign corporation to resort to the federal courts has been considered, can not be reconciled. They began with Insurance Co. v. Morse, 20 Wall. 445
rationale: The case is mentioned as the beginning of a line of cases addressing the conflict between state power and federal constitutional rights, but without specific analysis or treatment of its holding.

quote: They began with Insurance Co. v. Morse, 20 Wall. 445 , which was followed by Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co., 94 U. S. 535 ; Barron v. Burnside, 121 U. S. 186
rationale: The case is listed as part of a series of cases in the line of precedent addressing the conflict between state power and federal rights, but without specific discussion of its holding or reasoning.

quote: They began with Insurance Co. v. Morse, 20 Wall. 445 , which was followed by Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co., 94 U. S. 535 ; Barron v. Burnside, 121 U. S. 186 ; Southern Pacific Co. v. Denton, 146 U. S. 202
rationale: The case is listed as part of a series of cases in the line of precedent addressing the conflict between state power and federal rights, but without specific discussion of its holding or reasoning.

cited_decision: Martin v. Baltimore & Ohio R. R. Co.
quote: Martin v. Baltimore & Ohio R. R. Co., 151 U. S. 673, 684
rationale: The case is listed as part of a series of cases in the line of precedent addressing the conflict between state power and federal rights, but without specific discussion of its holding or reasoning.

cited_decision: Barrow S. S. Co. v. Kane
quote: Barrow S. S. Co. v. Kane, 170 U. S. 100, 111
rationale: The case is listed as part of a series of cases in the line of precedent addressing the conflict between state power and federal rights, but without specific discussion of its holding or reasoning.

cited_decision: Herndon v. Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Ry. Co.
quote: Herndon v. Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Ry. Co., 218 U. S. 135
rationale: The case is listed as part of a series of cases in the line of precedent addressing the conflict between state power and federal rights, but without specific discussion of its holding or reasoning.

cited_decision: Harrison v. St. Louis & San Francisco R. R. Co.
quote: Harrison v. St. Louis & San Francisco R. R. Co., 232 U. S. 318
rationale: The case is listed as part of a series of cases in the line of precedent addressing the conflict between state power and federal rights, but without specific discussion of its holding or reasoning.

cited_decision: Wisconsin v. Philadelphia & Reading Coal & Iron Co.
quote: Wisconsin v. Philadelphia & Reading Coal & Iron Co., 241 U. S. 329
rationale: The case is listed as part of a series of cases in the line of precedent addressing the conflict between state power and federal rights, but without specific discussion of its holding or reasoning.

cited_decision: Lake Shore & Michigan Southern Railway Co. v. Smith
quote: The views therein expressed which are inconsistent with the right of the States to fix reasonable commutation fares when the carrier has itself established fares for such service, must be regarded as overruled by the decision in this case.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the views in Lake Shore that are inconsistent with state authority to fix reasonable commutation fares must be regarded as overruled by this decision.

cited_decision: Penna. R.R. Co. v. Public Ser. Com.
quote: on appeal the Court of Appeals of Maryland affirmed the decree and held that although the order fixing the rates declared the same to be in force for ten years, there should be reserved to the railroad company the right to apply to the Commission after the lapse of a reasonable time for a rescission or modification of its order if experience demonstrated that the revenue derived under the tariff as established by the Commission was not properly compensatory for the services performed. 126 Maryland, 59.
rationale: The Acting Decision merely references the lower court's holding without any critical analysis or treatment that would affect its precedential value.

cited_decision: Interstate Com. Commiss. v. B. & O. RAILROAD
quote: In Interstate Commerce Commission v. Baltimore & Ohio R. R. Co., 145 U. S. 263, this court held that a 'party rate ticket' for the transportation of ten or more persons at a less rate than that charged a single individual did not make a discrimination against an individual charged more for the same service, or amount to an unjust or unreasonable discrimination within the meaning of the Act to Regulate Commerce.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case favorably to support the principle that reduced rates for special services do not constitute discrimination, using it as supportive authority without criticism.

cited_decision: Norfolk and Western Railway Company v. Conley, Attorney General of the State of West Virginia
quote: In Norfolk & Western Ry. Co. v. West Virginia, 236 U. S. 605, 608, after making reference to Northern Pacific Ry. Co. v. North Dakota, 236 U. S. 585, this court said: 'It was recognized [in the North Dakota Case] that the State has a broad field for the exercise .of its discretion in prescribing reasonable rates for common carriers within its jurisdiction; that it is not necessary that there should be uniform rates or the same percentage of profit on every sort of business; and that there is abundant room for reasonable classification and the adaptation of rates to various groups of services.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case approvingly to support the principle that states have broad discretion in prescribing reasonable rates and classifications for different services.

cited_decision: Northern Pacific Railway Co. v. North Dakota Ex Rel. McCue
quote: In Norfolk & Western Ry. Co. v. West Virginia, 236 U. S. 605, 608, after making reference to Northern Pacific Ry. Co. v. North Dakota, 236 U. S. 585, this court said: 'It was recognized [in the North Dakota Case] that the State has a broad field for the exercise .of its discretion in prescribing reasonable rates for common carriers within its jurisdiction'
rationale: The Acting Decision references this case indirectly through the Norfolk & Western case to support the principle of state discretion in rate-setting, without any negative treatment.

quote: In Louisville & Nashville R. R. Co. v. Kentucky (183 U. S. 503), after citing the Smith case and like cases, the court says (at p. 511): Nor, yet, are we ready to carry the doctrine of the cited cases beyond the limits therein established.
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes this case approvingly to show that the Smith case doctrine should not be extended beyond its specific facts, supporting the court's position.

quote: In the Minnesota Rate Case (Simpson v. Shepard, 230 U. S. 352) the legality of an order of the Commission of that State was recognized which fixed a maximum freight rate and passenger rate, the latter at two cents a mile as the maximum fare for passengers twelve years of age or over, and one cent a mile for those under twelve years of age.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case favorably as an example of valid state commission rate-setting authority, using it as supportive precedent.

cited_decision: Interstate Consolidated Street Railway Co. v. Massachusetts
quote: In Interstate R. Co. v. Massachusetts (207 U. S. 79) the Massachusetts law prescribing special rates less than the maximum for school children was held valid.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case approvingly as an example of valid state authority to prescribe special reduced rates for particular classes of passengers.

cited_decision: Friedlander v. Texas & Pacific Railway Co.
quote: We think that the Fried-lander case should be overruled so far as it supports such an exception and that the judgment of the court of appeals should be reversed.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the Friedlander case should be overruled to the extent it supports the exception that employers are not liable for fraudulent acts of agents done for the agent's own benefit.

cited_decision: Roy & Roy v. Northern Pacific Railway Co.
quote: To this extent the case has been often cited and followed. Louisville & Nashville R. R. Co. v. Nat. Park Bk., 188 Ala. 109, 119 ; Roy & Roy v. Northern Pacific Ry Co., 42 Wash. 572, 576
rationale: The Acting Decision merely lists this case as one that has cited and followed the Friedlander case, without any critical analysis or negative treatment of the Roy & Roy decision itself.

cited_decision: Planters' Rice-Mill Co. v. Merchants' National Bank
quote: The state courts, including those of Georgia where the cause of action arose, have very generally reached the opposite conclusion, holding that the liability of the principal for the false statement or other misconduct of the agent acting within the scope of his authority is unaffected by his secret purpose or motives. Planters' Rice-Mill Co. v. Merchants' Nat'l Bank, 78 Ga. 574
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case as an example of state courts that have reached the opposite conclusion from Friedlander, supporting the position that the Acting Decision ultimately adopts, but without detailed analysis of the case itself.

quote: The state courts, including those of Georgia where the cause of action arose, have very generally reached the opposite conclusion, holding that the liability of the principal for the false statement or other misconduct of the agent acting within the scope of his authority is unaffected by his secret purpose or motives. Planters' Rice-Mill Co. v. Merchants' Nat'l Bank, 78 Ga. 574 ; McCord v. Western Union, 39 Minn. 181 ; Havens v. Bank of Tarboro, 132 N. C. 214
rationale: The Acting Decision lists this case among state court decisions that support the principle that principal liability is unaffected by an agent's secret motives, but provides no detailed discussion or analysis of the Havens case specifically.

quote: Our conclusion is that the case of Adkins v. Children's Hospital, supra, should be, and it is, overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Adkins v. Children's Hospital should be and is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value.

cited_decision: Morehead v. New York ex rel. Tipaldo
quote: That view led to the affirmance by this Court of the judgment in the Morehead case, as the Court considered that the only question before it was whether the Adkins case was distinguishable and that reconsideration of that decision had not been sought.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Morehead to explain the procedural context and reasoning behind that case's affirmance, without criticizing or questioning its validity.

quote: In Nebbia v. New York, 291 U. S. 502, dealing with the New York statute providing for minimum prices for milk, the general subject of the regulation of the use of private property and of the making of private contracts received an exhaustive examination and we again declared that if such laws 'have a reasonable relation to a proper legislative purpose, and are neither arbitrary nor discriminatory, the requirements of due process are satisfied'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Nebbia favorably as supporting precedent for the principle that regulations with reasonable relation to proper legislative purpose satisfy due process requirements.

cited_decision: Chicago, Burlington & Quincy Railroad v. McGuire
quote: More than twenty-five years ago we set forth the applicable principle in these words, after referring to the cases where the liberty guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment had been broadly described: 'But it was recognized in the cases cited, as in many others, that freedom of contract is a qualified and not an absolute right.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites McGuire as establishing the foundational principle that freedom of contract is qualified and not absolute, using it as supportive precedent.

quote: The point that has been strongly stressed that adult employees should be deemed competent to make their own contracts was decisively met nearly forty years ago in Holden v. Hardy, supra, where we pointed out the inequality in the footing of the parties.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Holden v. Hardy as precedent that addressed the inequality between employers and employees, supporting the court's reasoning about the need for protective legislation.

quote: It was in virtue of this maxim of the common law that the supreme court of Nevada, in Reno Smelting Works v. Stevenson, 20 Nev. 269 ; 21 Pac. 317 , in a well reasoned opinion, held that the common law doctrine of riparian rights was unsuited to conditions prevailing in -the arid land states and territories of the west, and therefore was without force in Nevada; and that, in respect of the use of water, the applicable rule was based upon the doctrine of prior appropriation for a beneficial use.
rationale: The court cites this case as a positive example of how courts can modify common law rules when they become unsuited to changed conditions, supporting the court's own reasoning about the flexibility of common law.

quote: Petitioner contends that these cases, if not directly contrary to the decisions in Benson v. United States, 146 U.S. 325 , and Rosen v. United States, 245 U.S. 467 , are so in principle.
rationale: The court discusses the Benson case extensively as supporting precedent for the principle that courts can modify common law rules based on changed conditions and modern reasoning, without any negative treatment.

quote: Compare Holden v. Hardy, 169 U.S. 366, 385-387 .
rationale: The case is briefly cited in support of the court's discussion about the flexibility and adaptability of the common law, without any substantive analysis or negative treatment.

quote: In the Logan case it was held that the competency of a witness to testify in a federal court sitting in one state, was not affected by his conviction and sentence for felony in another state; and that the competency of another witness was not affected by his conviction of felony in a Texas state court, where the witness had since been pardoned.
rationale: The court discusses the Logan case as part of its analysis of prior precedent regarding witness competency rules, describing its holding without criticism or negative treatment.

quote: After saying that while the decision in the Reid case had not been specifically overruled, its authority was seriously shaken by the decisions in both the Logan and Benson cases, the court proceeded to dispose of the question, as it had been disposed ofin the Benson case, ' in the light of general authority and sound reason.'
rationale: The court explicitly states that the Reid case's authority was 'seriously shaken' and indicates that later cases rejected its approach in favor of more modern reasoning, showing disagreement with its methodology.

quote: In Hurtado v. California., 110 U.S. 516, 530 , this court, after suggesting that it was better not to go too far back into antiquity for the best securities of our liberties, said: ' It is more consonant to the true philosophy of our historical legal institutions to say that the spirit of personal liberty and individual right, which they embodied, was preserved and developed by a progressive growth and wise adaptation to new circumstances and situations of the forms and processes found fit to give, from time to time, new expression and greater effect to modem ideas of self-government. '
rationale: The court cites Hurtado favorably to support its argument about the adaptability of legal institutions to changing circumstances, using it as positive authority for the principle of legal evolution.

quote: The public policy of one generation may not, under changed conditions, be the public policy of another. Patton v. United States, 281 U.S. 276, 306 .
rationale: The court cites Patton to support the principle that public policy can change over time, using it as authority for the proposition that legal rules should adapt to changing conditions.

quote: Both thé Hendrix and Jin Fuey Moy cases are out of harmony with the Rosen and Benson cases and with the views which we have here expressed. In respect , of the question here under review, both are now) overruled.
rationale: The court explicitly states that the Hendrix case is 'overruled' because it is out of harmony with the court's current views on witness competency, directly nullifying its precedential value.

quote: Petitioner contends that these cases, if not directly contrary to the decisions in Benson v. United States, 146 U.S. 325 , and Rosen v. United States, 245 U.S. 467 , are so in principle.
rationale: The court discusses the Rosen case extensively as supporting precedent for allowing courts to modify common law rules based on modern conditions and reasoning, treating it as favorable authority.

cited_decision: Jin Fuey Moy v. United States
quote: Both thé Hendrix and Jin Fuey Moy cases are out of harmony with the Rosen and Benson cases and with the views which we have here expressed. In respect , of the question here under review, both are now) overruled.
rationale: The court explicitly states that the Jin Fuey Moy case is 'overruled' because it conflicts with the court's current position on witness competency, directly nullifying its precedential value.

cited_decision: Pennsylvania Gas Co. v. Public Service Commission (1919)
quote: This court, following the findings of the highest court of New York ( 225 N. Y. 397, 403-404 ; 122 N. E. 260 ), held that the entire movement of the gas was interstate commerce and that, in the absence of contrary regulation by the Congress, the state commission had jurisdiction to prescribe such rates.
rationale: The Acting Decision references this state court decision as background information to explain the procedural history and findings that led to the Supreme Court's decision in Pennsylvania Gas Co. v. Public Service Commission (1920), without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: West Virginia & Maryland Gas Co. v. Towers
quote: The treatment and division of the large .compressed volume of gas is like the breaking of an original package, after shipment in interstate commerce, in order that its contents may be treated, prepared for sale and sold at retail. State v. Flannelly, 96 Kan. 372, 383-384 ; 152 Pac. 22 ; W. Va. & Md. Gas Co. v. Pub. Serv. Comm., 134 Md. 137, 143-145 ; 106 Atl. 265 .
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case as supportive authority for the analogy that treating and dividing compressed gas is like breaking an original package, without any criticism or negative treatment.

cited_decision: Pennsylvania Gas Co. v. Public Service Commission (1920)
quote: But, however that may be, the opinion in that case must be disapproved to the extent that it is in conflict with our decision here.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the Pennsylvania Gas Co. opinion must be disapproved to the extent it conflicts with the current decision, thereby limiting its precedential scope and applicability.

quote: And, while a State may require payment of an occupation tax by one engaged in both intrastate and interstate commerce, the exaction in order to be valid must be imposed solely on account of the intrastate business without enhancement because of the interstate business done, and it must appear that one engaged exclusively in interstate business would not be subject to the imposition and that the taxpayer could discontinue the intrastate business without withdrawing also from the interstate business. Sprout v. South Bend, 277 U. S. 163, 170-171 , and cases cited.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Sprout v. South Bend as established authority for the legal principle regarding valid state occupation taxes on businesses engaged in both intrastate and interstate commerce, without any negative treatment.

quote: It is elementary that a State can neither lay a tax on the act of engaging in interstate commerce nor on gross receipts therefrom. Pullman Co. v. Richardson, 261 U. S. 330, 338 .
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Pullman Co. v. Richardson as established authority for the elementary principle that states cannot tax interstate commerce or gross receipts therefrom, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Atlantic Coast Line Railroad v. Standard Oil Co. of Kentucky
quote: The treatment and division of the large .compressed volume of gas is like the breaking of an original package, after shipment in interstate commerce, in order that its contents may be treated, prepared for sale and sold at retail. S. 257, 269.

cited_decision: New Jersey Bell Telephone Co. v. State Board of Taxes & Assessments
quote: It is elementary that a State can neither lay a tax on the act of engaging in interstate commerce nor on gross receipts therefrom. Pullman Co. v. Richardson, 261 U. S. 330, 338 . New Jersey Tel. Co. v. Tax Board, 280 U. S. 338, 346 .
rationale: The Acting Decision cites New Jersey Tel. Co. alongside Pullman Co. as established authority for the principle that states cannot tax interstate commerce, without any negative treatment.

quote: In the latter, it was said (p. 308): ' With the delivery of the gas [transported from one State to another] to the distributing companies . . . the interstate movement ends.' Its subsequent sale and delivery by these companies to their customers at retail is intrastate business and subject to state regulatioin.
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes Missouri v. Kansas Gas Co. to support its reasoning about when interstate commerce ends and intrastate business begins in the context of natural gas distribution, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Public Utilities Commission v. Attleboro Steam & Electric Co.
quote: The mere fact that the title or the custody of the gas passes while it is en route from State to State is not determinative of the question where interstate commerce ends. Attleboro Co., 273 U. S. 83, 89 .
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Public Util. Comm. v. Attleboro Co. as supportive authority for the principle that mere passage of title or custody during interstate transport is not determinative of where interstate commerce ends.

cited_decision: Peoples Natural Gas Co. v. Public Service Commission
quote: The mere fact that the title or the custody of the gas passes while it is en route from State to State is not determinative of the question where interstate commerce ends. Public Utilities Comm. v. Landon, 249 U. S. 239 , 245. Missouri v. Kansas Gas Co., 265 U. S. 298, 307-309 . Peoples Gas Co. v. Pub. Serv. Comm., 270 U. S. 550, 554 .
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Peoples Gas Co. v. Pub. Serv. Comm. as supportive authority for the principle that mere passage of title or custody during interstate transport is not determinative of where interstate commerce ends.

quote: The treatment and division of the large .compressed volume of gas is like the breaking of an original package, after shipment in interstate commerce, in order that its contents may be treated, prepared for sale and sold at retail. State v. Flannelly, 96 Kan. 372, 383-384 ; 152 Pac. 22 ; W. Va. & Md. Gas Co. v. Pub. Serv. Comm., 134 Md. 137, 143-145 ; 106 Atl. 265 . Cf. Atlantic Coast Line v. Standard Oil Co., 275 U. S. 257, 269. Brown v. Maryland, 12 Wheat. 419 .
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Brown v. Maryland as supportive authority for the original package doctrine analogy used to explain when interstate commerce ends and local distribution begins.

quote: The treatment and division of the large .compressed volume of gas is like the breaking of an original package, after shipment in interstate commerce, in order that its contents may be treated, prepared for sale and sold at retail. State v. Flannelly, 96 Kan. 372, 383-384 ; 152 Pac. 22 ; W. Va. & Md. Gas Co. v. Pub. Serv. Comm., 134 Md. 137, 143-145 ; 106 Atl. 265 . Cf. Atlantic Coast Line v. Standard Oil Co., 275 U. S. 257, 269. Brown v. Maryland, 12 Wheat. 419 . Leisy v. Hardin, 135 U. S. 100 .
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Leisy v. Hardin as supportive authority for the original package doctrine analogy used to explain when interstate commerce ends and local distribution begins.

cited_decision: Black & White Taxicab & Transfer Co. v. Brown & Yellow Taxicab & Transfer Co.
quote: Criticism of the doctrine became widespread after the decision of Black & White Taxicab Co. v. Brown & Yellow Taxicab Co., 276 U. S. 518. There, Brown and Yellow, a Kentucky corporation owned by Kentuckians, and the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, also a Kentucky corporation, wished that the former should have the exclusive privilege of soliciting passenger and baggage transportation at the Bowling Green, Kentucky, railroad station; and that the Black and White, a competing Kentucky corporation, should be prevented from interfering with that privilege. Knowing that such a contract would be void under the common law of Kentucky, it was arranged that the Brown and Yellow reincorporate under the law of Tennessee, and that the contract with the railroad should be executed there.
rationale: The Acting Decision uses the Black & White Taxicab case as an example of the problematic consequences of the Swift v. Tyson doctrine, criticizing how it allowed manipulation of jurisdiction to avoid unfavorable state law.

quote: As stated by Mr. Justice Field when protesting in Baltimore & Ohio R. Co. v. Baugh, 149 U. S. 368, 401, against ignoring the Ohio common law of fellow servant liability: 'I am aware that what has been termed the general law of the country — which is often little less than what the judge advancing the doctrine thinks at the time should be the general law on a particular subject — has been often advanced in judicial opinions of this court to control a conflicting law of a State.'
rationale: The Acting Decision references Justice Field's dissenting opinion in Baugh to support its argument against the Swift v. Tyson doctrine, but does not criticize the Baugh decision itself, merely using it as supportive authority.

quote: The defendant contended that by the common law of Pennsylvania as declared by its highest court in Falchetti v. Pennsylvania R. Co., 307 Pa. 203; 160 A. 859, the only duty owed to the plaintiff was to refrain from wilful or wanton injury.
rationale: The Acting Decision merely references the Falchetti case as the Pennsylvania law that the defendant claimed should apply, without expressing any opinion about the correctness or validity of that decision.

quote: The question for decision is whether the oft-challenged doctrine of Swift v. Tyson shall now be disapproved... In disapproving that doctrine we do not hold unconstitutional § 34 of the Federal Judiciary Act of 1789 or any other Act of Congress. We merely declare that in applying the doctrine this Court and the lower courts have invaded rights which in our opinion are reserved by the Constitution to the several States.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it is disapproving the doctrine of Swift v. Tyson and declares that the Court's application of this doctrine was unconstitutional, thereby overruling the precedent established in Swift v. Tyson.

quote: Collector v. Day, supra, and New York ex rel. Rogers v. Graves, supra, are overruled so far as they recognize an implied constitutional immunity from income taxation of the salaries of officers or employees of the national or a state government or their instrumentalities.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Collector v. Day is overruled regarding its recognition of constitutional immunity from income taxation of government employee salaries.

quote: In applying these controlling principles in the Gerhardt case the Court held that the salaries of employees of the New York Port Authority, a state instrumentality created by New York and New Jersey, were not immune from federal income tax, even though the Authority be regarded as not subject to federal taxation.
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on and applies the principles established in Helvering v. Gerhardt without criticizing or questioning its precedential value, using it as controlling authority.

quote: McCulloch v. Maryland, 4 Wheat. 316, 432; Van Brocklin v. Tennessee, 117 U. S. 151, 158-159; South Carolina v. United States, 199 U. S. 437, 451—452; Helvering v. Gerhardt, 304 U. S. 405, 412—415.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites McCulloch v. Maryland as established precedent regarding governmental immunity principles without any negative treatment or criticism.

quote: That assumption, made in Collector v. Day, supra, and in New York ex rel. Rogers v. Graves, supra, is contrary to the reasoning and to the conclusions reached in the Gerhardt case and in Metcalf & Eddy v. Mitchell, supra
rationale: The Acting Decision favorably cites Metcalf & Eddy v. Mitchell as supporting authority that contradicts the overruled cases, indicating positive treatment.

cited_decision: New York Ex Rel. Rogers v. Graves
quote: Collector v. Day, supra, and New York ex rel. Rogers v. Graves, supra, are overruled so far as they recognize an implied constitutional immunity from income taxation of the salaries of officers or employees of the national or a state government or their instrumentalities.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that New York ex rel. Rogers v. Graves is overruled regarding its recognition of constitutional immunity from income taxation of government employee salaries.

cited_decision: Dobbins v. Commissioners of Erie County
quote: Neither Dobbins v. Commissioners, 16 Pet. 435, and its offspring, nor Collector v. Day, supra, and its, can stand appeal to the Constitution and its historic purposes. Since both are the starting points of an interdependent doctrine, both should be, as I assume them to be, overruled this day.
rationale: The concurring opinion explicitly states that Dobbins v. Commissioners should be overruled, and the lead opinion's overruling of the immunity doctrine necessarily encompasses this case as well.

quote: From the decision just announced, it is clear that the Court has overruled Dobbins v. Commissioners of Erie County (1842) 16 Pet. 435; Collector v. Day (1871) 11 Wall. 113; New York ex rel. Rogers v. Graves, supra, and Brush v. Commissioner (1937) 300 U. S. 352.
rationale: The dissenting opinion explicitly identifies Brush v. Commissioner as one of the cases that has been overruled by the Court's decision, confirming its overruled status.

cited_decision: Pollock v. Farmers' Loan & Trust Co.
quote: See also the separate opinion of Mr. Justice Field in Pollock v. Farmers' Loan & Trust Co., 157 U. S. 429, 586 , 604 et seq.
rationale: The Acting Decision merely references Justice Field's separate opinion in Pollock as historical support for the constitutional interpretation, without any negative treatment or criticism of the decision itself.

quote: The cases, pro and con, are collected in the recent dissentingopinion by Chief Judge Bond of the Court of Appeals of Maryland in Gordy v. Dennis, 5 A. 2d 69, 82
rationale: The Acting Decision simply cites Gordy v. Dennis as a source that collected cases on both sides of the issue, without expressing any opinion about the correctness or validity of that decision.

quote: But to the extent that what the Court now says is inconsistent with what was said in Miles v. Graham, 268 U. S. 501 , the latter cannot survive.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Miles v. Graham cannot survive to the extent it is inconsistent with the current ruling, which constitutes an express nullification of parts of that precedent.

quote: And in that case he relied on the truth, as put by Chief Justice Marshall in M'Culloch v. Maryland, 4 Wheat. 316, 431 , that 'the power to tax involves the power to destroy.'
rationale: The Acting Decision references M'Culloch v. Maryland only to quote Chief Justice Marshall's famous principle about taxation, without any criticism or negative treatment of the decision itself.

quote: By means of § 22 of the Revenue Act of 1932, Congress sought to avoid, at least in part, the consequences of Evans v. Gore, 253 U. S. 245
rationale: The Acting Decision explains that Congress enacted legislation specifically to avoid the consequences of Evans v. Gore, and the court's ruling upholding that legislation effectively nullifies the precedential value of Evans v. Gore regarding judicial salary taxation.

quote: In view of our conclusions, we look upon the decision in that case as repugnant to the line of reasoning adopted here. As a consequence, Colgate v. Harvey must be and is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Colgate v. Harvey is repugnant to their reasoning and must be overruled, directly nullifying the precedential value of the Cited Decision.

cited_decision: Butchers' Benevolent Ass'n v. Crescent City Live-Stock Landing & Slaughter-House Co.
quote: This Court declared in the Slaughter-House Cases that the Fourteenth Amendment as well as the Thirteenth and Fifteenth were adopted to protect the negroes in their freedom. This almost contemporaneous interpretation extended the benefits of the privileges and immunities clause to other rights which are inherent in national citizenship but denied it to those which spring from state citizenship.
rationale: The Acting Decision references the Slaughter-House Cases to explain the historical interpretation of the Fourteenth Amendment and privileges and immunities clause without criticizing or questioning its precedential value.

quote: They have been described as 'privileges and immunities arising out of the nature and essential character of the national government, and granted or secured by the Constitution of the United States.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Twining v. New Jersey in a footnote as support for describing the nature of privileges and immunities protected by the Constitution, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Haguer v. Committee for Industrial Organization
quote: There is no occasion to attempt again an exposition of the views of this Court as to the proper limitations of the privileges and immunities clause. There is a very recent discussion in Hague v. C. I. O.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Hague v. C.I.O. as containing a recent discussion of the privileges and immunities clause and accepts the appellant's position based on that case, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Procter & Gamble Co. v. United States
quote: In translating these important objectives for effectuating the Congressional scheme to enlarge the independent powers of the Interstate Commerce Commission into a seemingly technical distinction between 'negative' and 'affirmative' orders, the opinion in Procter & Gamble v. United States gave authority to a doctrine which harmonizes neither with the considerations which induced it nor with the course of decisions which have purported to follow it.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly criticizes the Procter & Gamble decision for creating a technical distinction between 'negative' and 'affirmative' orders that does not align with the underlying considerations or subsequent case law.

quote: Thus, the Court has had occasion to find that while an order was 'negative in form' it was 'affirmative in substance.'
rationale: The Acting Decision references the Alton Railroad case as an example of how courts have found orders to be 'affirmative in substance' despite being 'negative in form,' without criticizing or questioning the decision itself.

quote: Under United States v. Corrick, 298 U. S. 435, 440, and United States v. Griffin, 303 U. S. 226, 229, the doctrine of 'negative orders' implies a jurisdictional defect which courts must consider sua sponte.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Corrick as establishing that the negative orders doctrine creates a jurisdictional defect that courts must consider on their own motion, without any negative treatment of the decision.

cited_decision: United States v. Los Angeles & Salt Lake Railroad
quote: The governing considerations which keep such orders without the area of judicial review were thus summarized for the Court by Mr. Justice Brandeis in denying reviewability of a 'final valuation' under the Valuations Act
rationale: The Acting Decision references this case as an example of orders that are not reviewable, quoting Justice Brandeis's summary of the governing considerations, without any criticism or negative treatment.

quote: Since it asserted a legal right under that Act to have the Commission apply different principles of law from those which led the Commission to dismiss the complaint, the ingredients for an adjudication — constituting a case or controversy — were present. rationale: The Acting Decision cites Baird as support for the proposition that certain ingredients constitute a case or controversy for adjudication purposes, without any negative treatment of the decision.

quote: Where a complainant seeks the Commission's authority under the terms of a statute and the Commission's action is followed by legal consequences, as was the case in Lehigh Valley R. Co. v. S. 476, the road to the courts' jurisdiction seems to be clear.
rationale: The Acting Decision references the Intermountain Rate Cases as an example where the path to court jurisdiction is clear when the Commission denies an exemption, without any criticism or negative treatment.

quote: Under United States v. Corrick, 298 U. S. 435, 440, and United States v. Griffin, 303 U. S. 226, 229, the doctrine of 'negative orders' implies a jurisdictional defect which courts must consider sua sponte.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Griffin alongside Corrick as establishing that the negative orders doctrine creates a jurisdictional defect that courts must consider on their own motion, without any negative treatment of the decision.

cited_decision: Helvering v. St. Louis Union Trust Co.

rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly rejects and overrules the distinctions made in the St. Louis Trust cases, finding them untenable and inconsistent with the Klein doctrine that should govern estate tax law.

quote: Freed from the distinctions, introduced by the St. Louis Trust cases, the Klein case furnishes such a harmonizing principle.
rationale: The Acting Decision affirms and relies on Klein as providing the correct harmonizing principle for estate tax law, treating it as the controlling precedent that should be followed.

quote: McCormick v. Burnet followed May v. Heiner. rationale: The Acting Decision references McCormick v. Burnet as part of the historical development of the legal doctrine, providing factual background without expressing disagreement with its holding.

quote: In May v. Heiner, supra, it was held that a transfer in trust under which the income was payable to the transferor's husband for his life and, after his death, to the transferor during her life, with remainder to her children, was not subject to tax as a transfer intended to take effect in possession or enjoyment at or after death.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses May v. Heiner as part of the historical development of estate tax doctrine, referencing it neutrally without criticism or endorsement.

quote: I have been able to find only one case decided contra: Commissioner v. Schwarz, 74 F. 2d 712.
rationale: The Acting Decision merely references Commissioner v. Schwarz as the only contrary case in a footnote within the dissenting opinion, without any substantive analysis or treatment.

quote: The Circuit Court of Appeals held that the trust instrument had conveyed the 'whole interest' of the decedent, subject only to a 'condition subsequent,' which left him nothing 'except a mere possibility of reverter.' Commissioner v. Hallock, 102 F. 2d 1, 3-4.

Poverty and immorality are not synonymous. I agree with what I understand to be the holding of the Court that cases which may indicate the contrary are overruled.

quote: It has been held that an act of misbehavior though covered by the latter provisions may also be a contempt if committed in the 'presence' of the Court. Savin, Petitioner, supra. And see Sinclair v. United States, 279 U. S. 749.

quote: And when .the Act came before this Court in Ex parte Robinson, 19 Wall. 505, 511 , Mr. Justice Field, speaking for the Court, acknowledgéd that it had limited the power of those courts.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Ex parte Robinson as historical support for the view that the Act of 1831 limited contempt power, without any criticism or negative treatment of the decision itself.

quote: So far as the decisions of this Court are concerned, that view persisted to the time when Toledo Newspaper Co. v. United States, supra, was decided. See Ex parte Wall, 107 U. quote: We come, then, to the so-called 'relitigation' cases, the first of which is Dial v. Reynolds, 96 U. S. 340 . The facts of the case are simple... It held that the 'gravamen' of the bills was an injunction to prevent Reynolds from proceeding in the state court. 'Such an injunction, except under the Bankrupt Act, no court of the United States can grant. With this exception, it is expressly forbidden by law.'
rationale: The Acting Decision presents Dial v. Reynolds as the first of the 'relitigation' cases and quotes it approvingly to support the prohibition against federal injunctions staying state court proceedings.

cited_decision: Supreme Tribe of Ben-Hur v. Cauble
quote: The opinion of Mr. Justice Day contains no reference to either the Act of March 2, 1793, or to Dial v. Reynolds. The opinion is devoted almost entirely to a discussion of whether the former decree is res judicata in the state suits. Having determined this question in the affirmative, the Court disposed of the remaining — § 265 — question in one sentence, citing only one case in support of its conclusion, Looney v. Eastern Texas R. Co., supra, which, as we have seen, was not a relitigation case.
rationale: The Acting Decision criticizes the Supreme Tribe case for failing to properly address Section 265 and for relying on an inapplicable precedent, suggesting the decision was inadequately reasoned.

quote: Root v. Woolworth, 150 U. S. 401 , is erroneously regarded as illustrating a 'relitigation' exception to § 265. The case holds merely that courts of equity have jurisdiction to 'effectuate their own decrees by injunctions or writs of assistance in order to avoid the relitigation of questions once settled between the same parties.' 150 U. S. at 411-12 . The Court did not uphold a federal injunction against a state suit to relitigate a claim already settled by a previous federal decree — no such state suit had been brought.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Root v. Woolworth by clarifying that it does not actually support a 'relitigation' exception to Section 265, as no state suit was involved in that case.

quote: The 'first come, first served' rationale of cases like Prout v. Starr, 188 U. S. 537 , was discarded in Kline v. Burke Construction Co., 260 U. S. 226, 235 .
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions Prout v. Starr as an example of cases whose rationale was later discarded by Kline v. Burke Construction Co., providing historical context without direct criticism.

quote: And the determination of the necessity for a given improvement of navigable capacity, and the character and extent of it, is for Congress alone.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Scranton v. Wheeler as authority for the principle that Congress has sole authority to determine navigation improvements, without any negative treatment or criticism.

cited_decision: United States v. Chandler-Dunbar Water Power Co.
quote: The power of Congress extends not only to keeping clear the channels of interstate navigation by the prohibition or removal of actual obstructions located by the riparian owner, or others, but comprehends as well the power to improve and enlarge their navigability.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case as supportive authority for the broad scope of Congressional power over navigation improvements, without any negative treatment.

quote: And we think that, so far as it sanctions such a principle, it is in irreconcilable conflict with our later decisions and cannot be considered as expressing the law.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the Lynah case, insofar as it requires compensation for injury to property in navigable stream beds, conflicts with later decisions and cannot be considered as expressing current law, thus limiting its precedential value.

quote: What was said in the Cress case must be confined to the facts there disclosed. In that case, the Government's improvement in a navigable stream resulted in the flooding of the plaintiff's land in and adjacent to a non-navigable stream.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes the Cress case by confining its holding to its specific facts involving non-navigable streams, indicating it does not apply to the current case involving navigable waters.

quote: For this purpose they are the public property of the nation, and subject to all the requisite legislation by Congress.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Gilman v. Philadelphia as authority for the principle that navigable waters are public property subject to Congressional regulation, without any negative treatment.

quote: Whether, under local law, the title to the bed of the stream is retained by the State or the title of the riparian owner extends to the thread of the stream, or, as in this case, to low-water mark, the rights of the title holder are subordinate to the dominant power of the federal Government in respect of navigation.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Gibson v. United States as authority for the principle that riparian property rights are subordinate to federal navigation power, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: United States v. Appalachian Electric Power Co.
quote: The power of Congress extends not only to keeping clear the channels of interstate navigation by the prohibition or removal of actual obstructions located by the riparian owner, or others, but comprehends as well the power to improve and enlarge their navigability.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case as supportive authority for the broad scope of Congressional power over navigation, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: State of Alabama v. State of Georgia
quote: The bed of a river is 'that portion of its soil which is alternately covered and left bare, as there may be an increase or diminution in the supply of water, and which is adequate to contain it at its average and mean stage during the entire year, without reference to the extraordinary freshets of the winter or spring, or the extreme droughts of the summer or autumn.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case for its definition of a river bed, using it as authoritative guidance without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Greenleaf Johnson Lumber Co. v. Garrison
quote: The exercise of the power within these limits is not an invasion of any private property right in such lands for which the United States must make compensation.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case as authority supporting the principle that federal navigation power can be exercised without compensation for property in stream beds, without any negative treatment.

quote: The exercise of the power within these limits is not an invasion of any private property right in such lands for which the United States must make compensation.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case as authority supporting the principle that federal navigation improvements do not require compensation for affected property in stream beds, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Lewis Blue Point Oyster Cultivation Co. v. Briggs
quote: It is not true, as respondents maintain, that only structures in the bed of a navigable stream which obstruct or adversely affect navigation may be injured or destroyed without compensation by a federal improvement of navigable capacity.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case as authority for the principle that structures in navigable stream beds can be affected without compensation regardless of whether they obstruct navigation, without any negative treatment.

quote: The drift away from Ribnik v. McBride, supra, has been so great that it can no longer be deemed a controlling authority... The Bibnik case, freed from.the test which it employed, can no longer survive.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that Ribnik v. McBride can no longer be deemed controlling authority and cannot survive, effectively overruling its precedential value.

quote: In 1937 Adkins v. Children's Hospital, 261 U. S. 525 , was overruled and a statute ofWashington which authorized the fixing of minimum wages for women and minors was sustained.
rationale: The Court merely mentions that Adkins was overruled by another case (West Coast Hotel) without itself taking any action against Adkins.

quote: That test, labelled by Mr. Justice Holmes in his dissent in the Tyson case (273 U. S. at p. 446) as 'little more than a fiction,' was discarded in Nebbia v. New York... those notions of public policy embedded in earlier decisions of this Court but. which, as Mr. Justice Holmes long admonished, should not be read into the Constitution.
rationale: The Court criticizes the test employed in Tyson & Brother v. Banton, calling it a 'fiction' and stating that its notions of public policy should not be read into the Constitution.

quote: In the fol-lpwing year this Court held that Tennessee had no power to fix prices at which gasoline might be sold in the state. Williams v. Standard Oil Co., 278 U. S. 235 .
rationale: The Court simply mentions Williams v. Standard Oil Co. as an example of a decision limiting price-fixing powers without criticizing or distinguishing it.

cited_decision: Morehead v. New York Ex Rel. Tipaldo
quote: Save for that decision and Morehead v. Tipaldo, 298 U. S. 587 , holding unconstitutional a New York statute authorizing the fixing of women's wages, the subsequent cases in this Court haye given increasingly wider scope to the price-fixing powers of the states and of Congress.
rationale: The Court mentions Morehead as one of the few decisions that limited price-fixing powers, but does not criticize or distinguish it directly.

cited_decision: Tagg Bros. & Moorhead v. United States
quote: Tagg Bros. v. United States, 280 U. S. 420 , decidedv,in 1930, upheld the power of the Secretary of Agriculture under the Packers and Stockyards Act to determine the just and reasonable charges of persons engaged in the business of buying and selling in interstate commerce livestock at a stockyard on a commission basis.
rationale: The Court mentions Tagg Bros. as a positive example of a case that upheld price-fixing powers, supporting the trend away from Ribnik.

cited_decision: O'Gorman & Young, Inc. v. Hartford Fire Ins. Co.
quote: In 1931 a New Jersey statute limiting commissions of agents- of fire insurance companies was sustained by O'Gorman & Young v. Hartford Fire Ins. Co., 282 U. S. 251 .
rationale: The Court mentions O'Gorman & Young as another positive example supporting the expansion of price-fixing powers.

quote: That test, labelled by Mr. Justice Holmes in his dissent in the Tyson case (273 U. S. at p. 446) as 'little more than a fiction,' was discarded in Nebbia v. New York, supra, pp. 531-539.
rationale: The Court mentions Nebbia favorably as the case that discarded the problematic test from earlier decisions.

quote: And see Hegeman Farms Corp. v. Baldwin, 293 U. S. 163
rationale: The Court briefly mentions Hegeman Farms as additional support for the trend toward allowing price-fixing legislation.

rationale: The Court mentions Baldwin v. G. A. F. Seelig in a comparative context without significant discussion.

cited_decision: West Coast Hotel Co. v. Parrish
quote: In 1937 Adkins v. Children's Hospital, 261 U. S. 525 , was overruled and a statute ofWashington which authorized the fixing of minimum wages for women and minors was sustained. West Coast Hotel Co. v. Parrish, 300 U. S. 379 .

quote: In the same year, Townsend v. Yeomans, 301 U. S. 441 , upheld a Georgia statute fixing maximum warehouse charges for the handling and selling of leaf tobacco.
rationale: The Court mentions Townsend favorably as another example of upheld price-fixing legislation.

quote: Cf. Mulford v. Smith, 307 U. S. 38

quote: Cf. Mulford v. Smith, 307 U. S. 38 ; Currin v. Wallace, 306 U. S. 1 .
