rationale: The Court mentions Rock Royal favorably as an example of upheld price-fixing under the commerce clause.

cited_decision: Sunshine Anthracite Coal Co. v. Adkins
quote: The next year the price-fixing provisions of the Bituminous Coal Act of 1937 were sustained. Sunshine Coal Co. v. Adkins, 310 U. S. 381 .
rationale: The Court mentions Sunshine Coal favorably as another example of sustained price-fixing legislation.

quote: And at this term we upheld the minimum wage and maximum hour provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. United States v. Darby, 312 U. S. 100 .
rationale: The Court mentions Darby favorably as a recent example of upheld wage and hour regulation.

quote: Cf. Brazee v. Michigan, 241 U. S. 340 .
rationale: The Court mentions Brazee in a comparative context without significant discussion.

cited_decision: New State Ice Co. v. Liebmann
quote: But see New State Ice Co. v. Liebmann, 285 U. S. 262
rationale: The Court mentions New State Ice Co. in a footnote as a contrary example without detailed discussion.

cited_decision: Old Dearborn Distributing Co. v. Seagram-Distillers Corp.
quote: Old Dearborn Distributing Co. v. Seagram-Distillers Corp., 299 U. S. 183, 192
rationale: The Court mentions Old Dearborn in a footnote as a contrary example without detailed discussion.

quote: Carter v. Carter Coal Co., 298 U. S. 238, 316 .
rationale: The Court mentions Carter v. Carter Coal Co. in a footnote as a contrary example without detailed discussion.

cited_decision: Highland v. Russell Car & Snow Plow Co.
quote: Cf. Highland v. Russell Car & Snow Plow Co., 279 U. S. 253 .
rationale: The Court mentions Highland in a footnote in a comparative context without significant discussion.

quote: And we have recently held that Congress in the exercise of its power to require inspection and grading of tobacco shipped in interstate commerce may compel such inspection and grading of all tobacco sold at local auction rooms from which a substantial part but not all of the tobacco sold is shipped in interstate commerce. Currin v. Wallace, supra, 11
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Currin v. Wallace as supportive precedent for Congress's power to regulate intrastate activities that affect interstate commerce, without any negative treatment.

quote: Congress, following its own conception of public policy concerning the restrictions which may appropriately be imposed on interstate commerce, is free to exclude from the commerce articles whose use in the states for which they are destined it may conceive to be injurious to the public health, morals or welfare, even though the state has not sought to regulate their use. Reid v. Colorado, supra
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Reid v. Colorado as supportive precedent for Congress's broad power to exclude articles from interstate commerce based on public policy considerations.

quote: The distinction on which the decision was rested that Congressional power to prohibit interstate commerce is limited to articles which in themselves have some harmful or deleterious property — a distinction which was novel when made and unsupported by any provision of the Constitution — has long since been abandoned. Brooks v. United States, supra; Kentucky Whip & Collar Co. v. Illinois Central R. Co., supra; Electric Bond & Share Co. v. Securities & Exchange Comm'n, 303 U. S. 419 ; Mulford v. Smith, 307 U. S. 38
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Mulford v. Smith as one of several cases that abandoned the harmful/deleterious property distinction from Hammer v. Dagenhart, supporting the court's reasoning.

cited_decision: Clark Distilling Co. v. Western Maryland Railway Co.
quote: It extends not only to those regulations which aid, foster and protect the commerce, but embraces those which prohibit it. Reid v. Colorado, 187 U. S. 137 ; Lottery Case, 188 U. S. 321 ; United States v. Delaware & Hudson Co., 213 U. S. 366 ; Hoke v. United States, 227 U. S. 308 ; Clark Distilling Co. v. Western Maryland Ry. Co., 242 U. S. 311
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Clark Distilling Co. as supportive precedent for Congress's power to regulate commerce by prohibiting certain activities.

cited_decision: Seven Cases of Eckman's Alternative v. United States
quote: It is no objection to the assertion of the power to regulate interstate commerce that its exercise is attended by the same incidents which attend the exercise of the police power of the states. Seven Cases v. United States, 239 U. S. 510, 514
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Seven Cases as precedent supporting that Congress's commerce power can overlap with traditional state police powers without constitutional objection.

quote: It extends to those activities intrastate which so affect interstate commerce or the exercise of the power of Congress over it as to make regulation of them appropriate means to the attainment of a legitimate end, the exercise of the granted power of Congress to regulate interstate commerce. See McCulloch v. Maryland, 4 Wheat. 316, 421 . Cf. United States v. Ferger, 250 U. S. 199
rationale: The Acting Decision cites United States v. Ferger as supportive precedent for Congress's power to regulate intrastate activities that affect interstate commerce.

quote: Such legislation has often been sustained with respect to powers, other than the commerce power granted to the national government, when the means chosen, although not themselves within the granted power, were nevertheless deemed appropriate aids to the accomplishment of some purpose within an admitted power of the national government. See Jacob Ruppert, Inc. v. Caffey, 251 U. S. 264 ; Everard's Breweries v. Day, 265 U. S. 545, 560
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Everard's Breweries as precedent supporting Congress's ability to use means that aid in accomplishing purposes within its granted powers.

cited_decision: Houston, East & West Texas Railway Co. v. United States
quote: A familiar like exercise of power is the regulation of intrastate transactions which are so commingled with or related to interstate commerce that all must be regulated if the interstate commerce is to be effectively controlled. Shreveport Case, 234 U. S. 342
rationale: The Acting Decision cites the Shreveport Case (Houston, East & West Texas Railway) as precedent for regulating intrastate transactions that are commingled with interstate commerce.

cited_decision: Wisconsin RR Comm. v. C., B. & QRR CO.
quote: A familiar like exercise of power is the regulation of intrastate transactions which are so commingled with or related to interstate commerce that all must be regulated if the interstate commerce is to be effectively controlled. Shreveport Case, 234 U. S. 342 ; Railroad Commission of Wisconsin v. Chicago, B. & Q. R. Co., 257 U. S. 563
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case as supportive precedent for Congress's power to regulate intrastate transactions that are related to interstate commerce.

cited_decision: Local 167, International Brotherhood of Teamsters v. United States
quote: The Sherman Act and the National Labor Relations Act are familiar examples of the exertion of the commerce power to prohibit or control activities wholly intrastate because of their effect on interstate commerce. See as to the Sherman Act, Northern Securities Co. v. United States, 193 U. S. 197 ; Swift & Co. v. United States, 196 U. S. 375 ; United States v. Patten, 226 U. S. 525 ; United Mine Workers v. Coronado Coal Co., 259 U. S. 344 ; Local No. 167 v. United States, 291 U. S. 293
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Local 167 as an example of the Sherman Act being used to control intrastate activities that affect interstate commerce.

cited_decision: Balt. & Ohio RR v. Int. Com. Comm.
quote: The requirement for records even of the intrastate transaction is an appropriate means to the legitimate end. See Baltimore & Ohio R. Co. v. Interstate Commerce Comm'n, 221 U. S. 612
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Baltimore & Ohio as precedent supporting Congress's power to require record-keeping as a means of enforcing valid commerce regulations.

cited_decision: Board of Trade of Chicago v. Olsen
quote: The requirement for records even of the intrastate transaction is an appropriate means to the legitimate end. See Baltimore & Ohio R. Co. v. Interstate Commerce Comm'n, 221 U. S. 612 ; Interstate Commerce Comm'n v. Goodrich Transit Co., 224 U. S. 194 ; Chicago Board of Trade v. Olsen, 262 U. S. 1, 42
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Chicago Board of Trade v. Olsen as supportive precedent for Congress's power to require record-keeping in connection with commerce regulation.

quote: Nor is it any longer open to question that it is within the legislative power to fix maximum hours. Holden v. Hardy, 169 U. S. 366 ; Muller v. Oregon, 208 U. S. 412 ; Bunting v. Oregon, 243 U. S. 426
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Bunting v. Oregon as precedent establishing that fixing maximum hours is within legislative power and constitutional.

quote: The conclusion is inescapable that Hammer v. Dagenhart , was a departure from the principles which have prevailed in the interpretation of the Commerce Clause both before and since the decision and that such vitality, as a precedent, as it then had has long since been exhausted. It should be and now is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Hammer v. Dagenhart should be and now is overruled, finding it inconsistent with established Commerce Clause principles.

quote: But the contention that the due process clause forecloses taxation of an interest in intangibles by the state of its owner when they are held in trust in another state was rejected in Bullen v. Wisconsin, 240 U. S. 625. In that case, a fund had been given in trust reserving to the donor a general power of revocation and the disposition of the trust income during life. This Court held that upon his death an inheritance tax could be levied by the state of his domicile although the trustee and the trust fund were outside the state.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Bullen v. Wisconsin favorably as precedent supporting the principle that intangibles can be taxed at the owner's domicile even when held in trust elsewhere, without criticizing or limiting its holding.

quote: His transfer of interests in intangibles, by virtue of the exercise of a donated power instead of that derived from ownership, stands on the same footing. In both cases the sovereign's control over his person and estate at the place of his domicile, and his duty to contribute to the financial support of government there, afford adequate constitutional basis for the imposition of a tax. Curry v. McCanless, 307 U. S. 357; cf. Graves v. Elliott, 307 U. S. 383.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Graves v. Elliott as supporting authority for the constitutional basis of taxation at domicile, using it to reinforce the court's reasoning without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Wachovia Bank & Trust Co. v. Doughton
quote: The conclusion there reached and the reasons advanced in its support cannot be reconciled with the decision and the reasoning of the Bullen, the McCanless and the Elliott cases. It is plain that if appropriate emphasis be placed on-the orderly administration of justice rather than blind adherence to conflicting precedents, the Wachovia case must be overruled... The Wachovia case should be and now is overruled and the constitutional power of New York to levy the present tax is sustained.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the Wachovia case 'must be overruled' and 'should be and now is overruled,' directly nullifying its precedential value due to irreconcilable conflicts with other established precedents.

quote: His transfer of interests in intangibles, by virtue of the exercise of a donated power instead of that derived from ownership, stands on the same footing. In both cases the sovereign's control over his person and estate at the place of his domicile, and his duty to contribute to the financial support of government there, afford adequate constitutional basis for the imposition of a tax. Curry v. McCanless, 307 U. S. 357; cf. Graves v. Elliott, 307 U. S. 383.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Curry v. McCanless as supporting precedent for the constitutional authority to tax at domicile, reinforcing the court's reasoning without any criticism or limitation.

quote: And such interests taxable at the domicile of the owner have been deemed to include the exercise or relinquishment of a power to dispose of intangibles. Chanler v. Kelsey, 205 U. S. 466; Bullen v. Wisconsin, supra; cf. Orr v. Gilman, 183 U. S. 278; Saltonstall v. Saltonstall, 276 U. S. 260.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Chanler v. Kelsey as precedent supporting the taxation of powers to dispose of intangibles at the owner's domicile, using it as favorable authority without any negative treatment.

quote: And such interests taxable at the domicile of the owner have been deemed to include the exercise or relinquishment of a power to dispose of intangibles. Chanler v. Kelsey, 205 U. S. 466; Bullen v. Wisconsin, supra; cf. Orr v. Gilman, 183 U. S. 278; Saltonstall v. Saltonstall, 276 U. S. 260.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Orr v. Gilman as supporting precedent for the principle that interests in intangibles are taxable at the owner's domicile, referencing it favorably without criticism.

quote: And such interests taxable at the domicile of the owner have been deemed to include the exercise or relinquishment of a power to dispose of intangibles. Chanler v. Kelsey, 205 U. S. 466; Bullen v. Wisconsin, supra; cf. Orr v. Gilman, 183 U. S. 278; Saltonstall v. Saltonstall, 276 U. S. 260.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Saltonstall v. Saltonstall as precedent supporting the taxation of powers to dispose of intangibles at domicile, citing it as favorable authority without any negative treatment.

quote: A transfer in one state of a chose in action or a share of stock may be taxed there even though the transferee in order to enjoy its benefits must depend in part upon the law of the state of the debtor or of the corporation. Blodgett v. Silberman, 277 U. S. 1, 10-17.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Blodgett v. Silberman as precedent supporting the principle that transfers can be taxed in one state even when the transferee must rely on another state's law, using it as favorable authority.

quote: The judgment in Jones v. Opelika has this day been vacated. Freed from that controlling precedent, we can restore to their high, constitutional position the liberties of itinerant evangelists who disseminate their religious beliefs and the tenets of their faith through distribution of literature.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the judgment in Jones v. Opelika has been vacated and refers to being freed from that controlling precedent, indicating that Jones v. Opelika has been overruled.

quote: Furthermore, the present ordinance is not narrowly drawn to safeguard the people of the community in their homes against the evils of solicitations. See Cantwell v. Connecticut, supra, 306.
rationale: The Acting Decision merely cites Cantwell v. Connecticut as a reference point for comparison regarding narrowly drawn ordinances, without any criticism or negative treatment of the decision itself.

quote: The taxes imposed by this ordinance can hardly help but be as severe and telling in their impact on the freedom of the press and religion as the 'taxes on knowledge' at which the First Amendment was partly aimed. Grosjean v. American Press Co., supra, pp. 244-249.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Grosjean v. American Press Co. to support its argument about taxes on knowledge and their impact on First Amendment freedoms, using it as supportive precedent without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Near v. Minnesota Ex Rel. Olson
quote: We do not mean to say that religious groups and the press are free from all financial burdens of government. See Grosjean v. American Press Co., 297 U. S. 233, 250.
rationale: Near v. Minnesota is not actually discussed or cited in the provided text of the Acting Decision. The citation appears to be incorrectly identified in the metadata, as the text only references Grosjean v. American Press Co. in this context.

quote: But we do not think it was. The Haddock case involved a suit for separation and alimony, brought in New York by the wife on personal service of the husband. The husband pleaded in defense a divorce decree obtained by him in Connecticut where he had established a separate domicil. This Court held that New York, the matrimonial domicil where the wife still resided, need not give full faith and credit to the Connecticut decree, since it was obtained by the husband who wrongfully left his wife in the matrimonial domicil, service on her having been obtained by publication and she not having entered an appearance in the action. But we do not agree with the theory of the Haddock case... Haddock v. Haddock is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it does not agree with the theory of the Haddock case and expressly declares 'Haddock v. Haddock is overruled,' thereby nullifying its precedential value.

quote: Atherton v. Atherton held that full faith and credit must be given a decree of divorce granted by the state of the matrimonial domicil on constructive service against the other spouse who was a non-resident of that state.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Atherton v. Atherton to explain existing precedent regarding full faith and credit for divorce decrees, without criticizing or questioning its validity.

quote: It does not purport to challenge or disturb the rule, earlier established by Christmas v. Russell, supra, and subsequently fortified by Fauntleroy v. Lum, supra, that, even though the cause of action could not have been entertained in the state of the forum, a judgment obtained thereon in a sister state is entitled to full faith and credit.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Christmas v. Russell as establishing a rule that supports its reasoning, referencing it positively without any negative treatment.

quote: But there are two reasons why we do not reach that issue in this case... cited_decision: Alaska Packers Assn. v. Industrial Accident Comm'n of Cal.

rationale: The Acting Decision cites Alaska Packers to explain a principle about accommodating conflicting state interests, using it as supportive authority without any negative treatment.

quote: Fall v. Eastin, 215 U. S. 1 ; Olmsted v. Olmsted, 216 U. S. 386 ; Hood v. McGehee, 237 U. S. 611 . These decisions refuse to require courts of one state to allow acts or judgments of another to control the disposition or devolution of realty in the former.
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions Hood v. McGehee as part of a group of cases that establish exceptions to the full faith and credit rule regarding real property, citing it neutrally as existing precedent.

quote: But as stated by Mr. Justice Brandéis in Broderick v. Rosner, 294 U. S. 629, 642 , 'the room left for the play of conflicting policies is a narrow one.'
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes Broderick v. Rosner to support its argument about the limited exceptions to the full faith and credit clause, using it as supportive authority.

quote: Fall v. Eastin, 215 U. S. 1 ; Olmsted v. Olmsted, 216 U. S. 386 ; Hood v. McGehee, 237 U. S. 611 . These decisions refuse to require courts of one state to allow acts or judgments of another to control the disposition or devolution of realty in the former.
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions Fall v. Eastin as part of a group of cases that establish exceptions to the full faith and credit rule regarding real property, citing it neutrally as existing precedent.

quote: It does not purport to challenge or disturb the rule, earlier established by Christmas v. Russell, supra, and subsequently fortified by Fauntleroy v. Lum, supra, that, even though the cause of action could not have been entertained in the state of the forum, a judgment obtained thereon in a sister state is entitled to full faith and credit.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Fauntleroy v. Lum as fortifying the rule established in Christmas v. Russell, referencing it positively as supportive precedent.

quote: There is no constitutional barrier if the form and nature of the substituted service (see Milliken v. Meyer, supra, p. 463 ) meet the requirements of due process.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Milliken v. Meyer regarding due process requirements for substituted service, citing it as established authority without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Johnson v. United States Shipping Bd. Emergency Fleet Corporation
quote: Our conclusion, however, is that that position is untenable and that the Lustgarten case so far as it would prevent a private operator from being sued under the circumstances of this case must be considered as no longei controlling.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the Lustgarten case (a companion case to Johnson) is no longer controlling insofar as it would prevent suits against private operators, thus limiting the scope of the Johnson decision.

quote: We agree with the court below that this was a maritime tort over which the admiralty court has jurisdiction. Vancouver S. S. Co. v. Rice, 288 U. S. 445
rationale: The decision is cited merely to support the proposition that admiralty courts have jurisdiction over maritime torts, without any critical analysis or limitation of its holding.

quote: We agree with the court below that this was a maritime tort over which the admiralty court has jurisdiction. Vancouver S. S. Co. v. Rice, 288 U. S. 445 ; The Admiral Peoples, 295 U. S. 649
rationale: The decision is cited alongside Vancouver S.S. Co. v. Rice to support admiralty jurisdiction over maritime torts, without any substantive discussion or criticism.

cited_decision: Eastern Transportation Co. v. United States
quote: And it is likewise clear that the action in admiralty afforded by § 2 of the Suits in Admiralty Act is the only available remedy against the United States or a corporation whose entire outstanding capital stock is owned by the United States or its representatives. Eastern Transportation Co. v. United States, 272 U. S. 675

cited_decision: United States Shipping Bd. Emergency Fleet Corporation v. Rosenberg Brothers & Co.

rationale: The decision is cited to establish that the two-year statute of limitations applies under the Suits in Admiralty Act, without any criticism or limitation of its holding.

quote: That section was designed to avoid the inconvenience, expense and delay resulting from the holdings in The Florence H., 248 F. 1012 , and The Lake Monroe, 250 U. S. 246 , that libel in rem would lie against vessels owned by the United States.
rationale: The decision is cited to explain the historical background and purpose of Section 1 of the Suits in Admiralty Act, without any critical treatment.

cited_decision: Sloan Shipyards Corp. v. United States Shipping Bd. Emergency Fleet Corporation
quote: As stated in Sloan Shipyards Corp. v. Emergency Fleet Corp., 258 U. S. 549, 567 , 'An instrumentality of government he might be and for the greatest ends, but the agent, because he is agent, does not cease to be answerable for his acts.'
rationale: The decision is cited approvingly to support the principle that agents remain liable for their acts despite being government instrumentalities, without any criticism or limitation.

cited_decision: Keifer & Keifer v. Reconstruction Finance Corp.

rationale: The decision is cited to support the policy that immunity from suit is not favored for government corporations in commercial activities, without any critical analysis.

cited_decision: Federal Housing Administration, Region No. 4 v. Burr
quote: For when it comes to the utilization of corporate facilities in the broadening phases of federal activities in the commercial or business field, immunity from suit is not favored. Keifer & Keifer v. Reconstruction Finance Corp., 306 U. S. 381 ; Federal Housing Administration v. Burr, 309 U. S. 242
rationale: The decision is cited alongside Keifer & Keifer to support the principle that immunity from suit is disfavored for government entities in commercial activities.

quote: That it had the power to grant or withhold immunity from suit on behalf of governmental corporations is plain. Federal Land Bank v. Priddy, 295 U. S. 229
rationale: The decision is cited to establish Congress's power to grant or withhold immunity for governmental corporations, without any critical treatment.

cited_decision: Reconstruction Finance Corporation v. JG Menihan Corp.
quote: That it had the power to grant or withhold immunity from suit on behalf of governmental corporations is plain. Federal Land Bank v. Priddy, 295 U. S. 229 ; Reconstruction Finance Corp. v. Menihan Corp., 312 U. S. 81
rationale: The decision is cited alongside Federal Land Bank v. Priddy to support Congress's authority over governmental corporation immunity, without criticism.

quote: Moreover, if, as apparently was the case here, the claimant was eligible to receive and did receive compensation under the United States Employees Compensation Act ( 39 Stat. 742 , 5 U. S. C. § 751 ), he is barred from suing the United States for the tort. Dahn v. Davis, 258 U. S. 421
rationale: The decision is cited to establish that receipt of compensation under the Employees Compensation Act bars suits against the United States, without any critical analysis.

cited_decision: Guaranty Trust and Safe Deposit Co. v. Green Cove Springs and Melrose Railroad
quote: Immunity from suit on a cause of action which the law creates cannot be so readily obtained. Cf. Guaranty Trust & S. D. Co. v. Green Cove R. Co., 139 U. S. 137, 143
rationale: The decision is cited as a comparison to support the principle that immunity from suit cannot be easily obtained when the law creates a cause of action.

cited_decision: Yearsley v. W. A. Ross Construction Co.

rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the present situation is 'quite different' from Yearsley, distinguishing the cases based on the different legal questions involved.

quote: Furthermore, if the United States were to become the real party in interest by reason of a contract for exoneration or indemnity, a basic alteration in that concept (Minnesota v. Hitchcock, 185 U. S. 373, 387 ) would be made
rationale: The decision is cited to reference the concept of 'real party in interest' without any critical treatment or limitation of its holding.

quote: As to the liability of public officials see generally Dunlop v. Munroe, 7 Cranch 242, 269
rationale: The decision is cited in a general reference to authorities on the liability of public officials, without substantive discussion or criticism.

quote: As to the liability of public officials see generally Dunlop v. Munroe, 7 Cranch 242, 269 ; Osborn v. Bank of United States, 9 Wheat. 738, 842, 843 ; Wilkes v. Dinsman, 7 How. 89, 123 ; Robertson v. Sichel, 127 U. S. 507
rationale: The decision is cited as part of a general list of authorities on public official liability, without any substantive analysis or critical treatment.

quote: As to the liability of public officials see generally Dunlop v. Munroe, 7 Cranch 242, 269 ; Osborn v. Bank of United States, 9 Wheat. 738, 842, 843 ; Wilkes v. Dinsman, 7 How. 89, 123 ; Robertson v. Sichel, 127 U. S. 507 ; Spalding v. Vilas, 161 U. S. 483
rationale: The decision is cited as part of a general reference to authorities on public official liability, without substantive discussion or critical analysis.

cited_decision: Federal Power Commission v. Natural Gas Pipeline Co.
quote: We held in Federal Power Commission v. Natural Gas Pipeline Co., supra, that the Commission was not bound to the use of any single formula or combination of for-mulae in determining rates. Its rate-making function, moreover, involves the making of 'pragmatic adjustments.' Id., p. 586. And when the Commission's order is challenged in the courts, the question is whether that order 'viewed in its entirety' meets the requirements of the Act.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites the Natural Gas Pipeline Co. case to support its holding that the Commission has flexibility in rate-making methodology and that courts should evaluate orders holistically rather than focusing on specific formulas.

cited_decision: United Fuel Gas Co. v. Railroad Commission
quote: Then, as now, the differences were 'due chiefly to the difference in value ascribed by each to the gas rights and leaseholds.' 278 U. S. 300, 311.
rationale: The Acting Decision references this case in Justice Jackson's dissent to illustrate historical disputes over valuation methods in natural gas rate-making, without any negative treatment of the precedent.

cited_decision: Columbus Gas & Fuel Co. v. Public Util. Comm'n of Ohio
quote: Later the 'value' of gas in the field was questioned in determining the amount a regulated company should be allowed to pay an affiliate therefor — a state determination also reviewed under the Fourteenth Amendment. Dayton Power & Light Co. v. Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, 292 U. S. 290 (1934); Columbus Gas & Fuel Co. v. Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, 292 U. S. 398 (1934).
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions this case in Justice Jackson's dissent as part of a historical survey of natural gas valuation cases, without any criticism or negative treatment of the decision.

cited_decision: Los Angeles Gas & Electric Corp. v. Railroad Commission
quote: Under the statutory standard of 'just and reasonable' it is the result reached not the method employed which is controlling. Cf. Los Angeles Gas & Electric Corp. v. Railroad Commission, 289 U. S. 287, 304-305, 314

cited_decision: Dayton Power & Light Co. v. Public Utilities Commission
quote: The incongruity between the actual operations and the return computed on the basis of reproduction cost suggests that the Commission was wholly justified in rejecting the latter as the measure of the rate base. Dayton Power & Light Co. v. Public Utilities Commission, 292 U. S. 290, 312.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case to support the Commission's rejection of reproduction cost as a rate base measure, using it as supportive precedent without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railway Co. v. Minnesota
quote: Foreshadowed nearly sixty years ago, Railroad Commission Cases, 116 U. S. 307,331, it was decided more than fifty years ago that the final say under the Constitution lies with the judiciary and not the legislature. Chicago, M. & St. P. Ry. Co. v. Minnesota, 134 U. S. 418.
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions this case in Justice Frankfurter's dissent as establishing the principle of judicial review over legislative rate-making, without any criticism of the precedent itself.

cited_decision: United Rs. & Elec. Co. of Baltimore v. West

rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states it 'cannot approve' the contrary holding in this case regarding depreciation calculations, directly criticizing and rejecting the precedent's approach to the issue.

quote: But the admiralty rule that the vessel and owner are liable to indemnify a seaman for injury caused by unseaworthiness of the vessel or its appurtenant appliances and equipment, has been the settled law since this Court's ruling to that effect in The Osceola, supra, 175.
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on The Osceola as established precedent supporting the rule of owner liability for unseaworthiness, without criticizing or questioning its authority.

quote: We prefer to follow the latter as the more consonant with principle and authority.
rationale: The Acting Decision follows and relies on Carlisle Packing Co. v. Sandanger as supporting authority for its holding, treating it as consistent with established principles.

quote: We granted certiorari, 320 U. S. 725, upon a petition which urged that the statement quoted from The Pinar Del Rio, supra, does not rule this case, and that the decision below is inconsistent with the decisions in The Osceola, 189 U. S. 158, and in Socony-Vacuum Co. v. Smith, 305 U. S. 424.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Socony-Vacuum Co. v. Smith as supporting precedent that is inconsistent with the lower court's decision, using it as authority for its position.

cited_decision: Plamals v. S. S. "Pinar Del Rio"

rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly disapproves and refuses to follow The Pinar Del Rio decision, stating it cannot follow both that case and established precedent, effectively overruling it.

quote: Whether petitioner knew of the defective condition of the rope does not appear, but in any case the seaman, in the performance of his duties, is not deemed to assume the risk of unseaworthy appliances. The Arizona v. Anelich, supra, 123-124.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites The Arizona v. Anelich as supporting authority for the principle that seamen do not assume the risk of unseaworthy appliances, using it to support its holding.

cited_decision: Board of County Commissioners v. Seber
quote: See the concurring opinion of Mr. Justice Rutledge in Board of Commissioners v. Seber, 318 U. S. 705, 719
rationale: The Acting Decision merely references the Seber case to support a point about the purpose of the 1933 Act, without any negative treatment or criticism of the decision.

cited_decision: Superintendent of Five Civilized Tribes v. Commissioner
quote: We have held that the Indians, like all other citizens, must pay federal income taxes. Superintendent v. Commissioner, supra, 421.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case positively to support its argument that Indians must pay taxes like other citizens, without any negative treatment.

quote: The 43 acres purchased for the intestate from her restricted funds was taxable at the time of her death, Shaw v. Gibson-Zahniser Oil Corp., 276 U. S. 575
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Shaw to establish that certain land was taxable, using it as precedent without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: United States Trust Co. v. Helvering

rationale: The Acting Decision references the principles from this case but ultimately distinguishes it, stating that 'A majority of the Court concludes that this principle does not apply to Indian lands specifically exempted from direct taxation.'

quote: Such power exists to prevent impairment of the manner in, or means by which Congress effectuates its Indian policy, at least so long as Congress has not determined that the interests of the Indians require their complete release from tutelage or the final termination of the United States' guardianship over them. Board of Commissioners v. Seber, 318 U. S. 705 ; cf. Tiger v. Western Investment Co., 221 U. S. 286, 315-16
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Tiger in the dissenting opinion to support the argument about Congress's plenary power over Indians, without negative treatment.

quote: Childers v. Beaver, supra, was in effect overruled by the Mountain Producers decision. The immunity formerly said to rest on constitutional implication cannot now be resurrected in the form of statutory implication.
rationale: The Acting Decision uses Mountain Producers to support its argument that previous tax immunity doctrines have been rejected, citing it positively for this proposition.

quote: Their lands are held in fee, not in trust, as in the Rickert case, and the doctrine of constitutional immunity from taxation for the income of their holdings on the federal instrumentality theory has been renounced
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Rickert by noting that the current case involves lands held in fee rather than in trust, making the Rickert precedent inapplicable.

cited_decision: Graves v. New York Ex Rel. O'Keefe

rationale: The Acting Decision cites Graves positively as part of a trend toward eliminating tax favoritism and promoting equality of taxation.

quote: Such power exists to prevent impairment of the manner in, or means by which Congress effectuates its Indian policy, at least so long as Congress has not determined that the interests of the Indians require their complete release from tutelage or the final termination of the United States' guardianship over them. Board of Commissioners v. Seber, 318 U. S. 705 ; cf. Tiger v. Western Investment Co., 221 U. S. 286, 315-16 ; Brader v. James, 246 U. S. 88, 96

rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case in the dissenting opinion to support the principle of tax immunity for restricted Indian lands, without negative treatment.

quote: That was the basis of decision in Choctaw, O. & G. R. Co. v. Harrison, 235 U. S. 292 ; Indian Territory Oil Co. v. Oklahoma, 240 U. S. 522 ; Jaybird Mining Co. v. Weir, 271 U. S. 609

quote: This immunity for lessees was withdrawn by Helvering v. Mountain Producers Corp., 303 U. S. 376 , which overruled Gillespie v. Oklahoma, supra.

quote: The constitution adopted by the people of Oklahoma renounced any claims to Indian lands (Art. 1, § 3), and exempted from taxation 'such property as may be exempt by reason of treaty stipulations, existing between the Indians and the United States Government, or by Federal laws, during the force and effect of such treaties or Federal laws' (Art. quote: The economic status of the Osages is discussed in McCurdy v. United States, 246 U. S. 263, 265

quote: Childers v. Beaver, supra, was in effect overruled by the Mountain Producers decision. The immunity formerly said to rest on constitutional implication cannot now be resurrected in the form of statutory implication.

quote: We conclude that the Schwimmer, Macintosh and Bland cases do not state the correct rule of law.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the Schwimmer case does not state the correct rule of law, effectively overruling its precedential value regarding naturalization requirements for conscientious objectors.

quote: We conclude that the Schwimmer, Macintosh and Bland cases do not state the correct rule of law.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly groups MacIntosh with the other cases and declares that they do not state the correct rule of law, thereby overruling its precedential authority.

quote: We conclude that the Schwimmer, Macintosh and Bland cases do not state the correct rule of law.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly includes Bland in its declaration that these cases do not state the correct rule of law, effectively overruling its precedential value.

quote: From this it is argued that Congress adopted and reenacted the rule of the Schwimmer, Macintosh and Bland cases. Cf. Apex Hosiery Co. v. Leader, 310 U. S. 469, 488-489.

quote: We did decide, however, United States v. Classic, 313 U. S. 299 . rationale: The Acting Decision references Classic to establish the principle that primaries can be regulated by Congress when they are integral to the election process, using it as supportive precedent without criticism or limitation.

quote: Here we are applying, contrary to the recent decision in Orovey v. Townsend , the well-established principle of the Fifteenth Amendment, forbidding the abridgement by a State of a citizen's right to vote. Orovey v. Townsend is overruled.

quote: This Court again reversed the dismissal of the suit for the reason that the Committee action was deemed to be state action and invalid as discriminatory under the Fourteenth Amendment. rationale: The Acting Decision references Nixon v. Condon as part of the historical development of the law regarding primary elections, using it as supportive precedent without any negative treatment.

quote: The Democratic party of Texas is held by the Supreme Court of that State to be a 'voluntary association,' Bell v. Hill, 123 Tex. 531, 534 , protected by § 27 of the Bill of Rights, Art. 1, Constitution of Texas, from interference by the State

American Patents Corp., supra; Leitch Mfg. Co. v. Barber Co., supra; Morton Salt Co. v. G. S. Suppiger Co., 314 U. S. 488 ; B. B. Chemical Co. v. Ellis, 314 U. S. 495 .

quote: The protection which the Court in that case extended to the phonograph record, which was an unpat-ented part of the patented phonograph, is in substance inconsistent with the view which we have expressed in this case. American Patents Corp., supra; Leitch Mfg. Co. v. Barber Co., supra; Morton Salt Co. v. G. S. Suppiger Co., 314 U. S. 488 ; B. B. Chemical Co. v. Ellis, 314 U. S. 495 .

cited_decision: Motion Picture Co. v. Universal Film Co.
quote: Ever since Henry v. A. B. Dick Co., 224 U. S. 1 , was overruled by Motion Picture Co. v. Universal Film Co., 243 U. S. 602 , this Court has consistently held that the owner of a patent may not employ it to secure a limited monopoly of an unpatented material used in applying the invention.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Motion Picture Co. as the case that overruled Henry v. A.B. Dick Co. and established the principle being applied, treating it as supportive precedent without criticism.

quote: Ever since Henry v. A. B. Dick Co., 224 U. S. 1 , was overruled by Motion Picture Co. v. Universal Film Co., 243 U. S. 602 , this Court has consistently held that the owner of a patent may not employ it to secure a limited monopoly of an unpatented material used in applying the invention. Carbice Corp. v. American Patents Corp., supra; Leitch Mfg. Co. v. Barber Co., supra; Morton Salt Co. v. G. S. Suppiger Co., 314 U. S. 488 ; B. B. Chemical Co. v. Ellis, 314 U. S. 495 .
rationale: The Acting Decision cites B. B. Chemical Co. v. Ellis as part of the consistent line of cases supporting the principle that patents cannot be used to monopolize unpatented materials, without any negative treatment.

quote: The fact that the patentee has the power to refuse a license does not enable him to enlarge the monopoly of the patent by the expedient of attaching conditions to its use. United States v. Masonite Corp., supra, p. 277.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites United States v. Masonite Corp. to support the principle that patentees cannot enlarge patent monopolies through licensing conditions, treating it as supportive precedent without criticism.

quote: The North Carolina Supreme Court, holding that the North Carolina Act of 1933 barred Bullington's suit against Angel, reversed the Superior Court and dismissed the action. 220 N. C. 18 , 16 S. E. 2d 411 .
rationale: The Acting Decision merely references the prior North Carolina Supreme Court decision as factual background without criticizing or questioning its precedential value.

quote: For purposes of diversity jurisdiction a federal court is, 'in effect, only another court of the State.' Guaranty Trust Co. v. York, 326 U. S. 99, 108
rationale: The Acting Decision cites York favorably to support the principle that federal courts in diversity cases must follow state law, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: David Lupton's Sons Co. v. Automobile Club of America (1912)
quote: Cases like Lupton's Sons Co. v. Automobile Club, 225 U. S. 489, are obsolete insofar as they are based on a view of diversity jurisdiction which came to an end with Erie Railroad v. Tompkins, 304 U. S. 64 .
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly declares that Lupton's Sons is obsolete and no longer valid law due to the intervening Erie decision, effectively overruling its precedential value.

quote: Cases like Lupton's Sons Co. v. Automobile Club, 225 U. S. 489, are obsolete insofar as they are based on a view of diversity jurisdiction which came to an end with Erie Railroad v. Tompkins, 304 U. S. 64 . That decision drastically limited the power of federal district courts to entertain suits in diversity cases that could not be brought in the respective State courts or were barred by defenses controlling in the State courts.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Erie favorably as the controlling precedent that changed diversity jurisdiction law, using it to support the court's reasoning without any negative treatment.

quote: The Caldarola case, 332 U. S. 155, undermined the foundations of Hust. Caldarola held that the general agents under the standard form contract were not in possession and control of the vessel so as to make them liable under New York law to an invitee for injuries arising from negligence in its maintenance.
rationale: The Acting Decision uses Caldarola to support its reasoning and relies on its holding to distinguish liability principles, without criticizing or questioning the decision itself.

quote: Notwithstanding there may be some undesirable results in overruling Hust, such as loss of rights under the Suits in Admiralty Act by reliance on Hust, we think that in view of Caldarola, the uncertainty as to remedies that the two decisions generate, and the desirability of clarifying the position of the United States as an employer through the War Shipping Administration, that case should be and is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Hust is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value due to inconsistencies with later decisions and the need for legal clarity.

quote: On appeal the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed. McAllister v. Cosmopolitan Shipping Co., 169 F. 2d 4... The judgment of the Supreme Court of the State of Washington is Affirmed. Reversed.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly overturns the Court of Appeals decision in the same case, as indicated by the final 'Reversed' ruling at the end of the opinion.

cited_decision: National Labor Relations Board v. Hearst Publications, Inc.
quote: We assume, without deciding, that the rule of the Hearst case applies, that is, the word 'employment' should be construed so as to give protection to seamen for torts committed against them by those standing in the proximate relation of employer, and the rules of private agency should not be rigorously applied.
rationale: The Acting Decision references the Hearst case to discuss employment interpretation principles but assumes its applicability without deciding the issue, indicating a neutral mention rather than any negative treatment.

quote: As welfare legislation, this statute is entitled to a liberal construction to accomplish its beneficent purposes. Compare Aguilar v. Standard Oil Co., 318 U. S. 724; American Stevedores v. Porello, 330 U. S. 446.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Porello as a comparative example to support the principle of liberal construction for welfare legislation, without any criticism or negative treatment.

quote: As to the first conclusion, we think it arises from a misconception of the ruling of the Brady case. The Brady case decided no more, directly or by implication, than that an action could be maintained against agents of the United States at common law for the agents' own torts. The case did not involve the right to recover against employers under the Jones Act.
rationale: The Acting Decision narrows the scope and applicability of Brady by clarifying that it was misconstrued in Hust and limiting its holding to a specific narrow issue, thereby restricting its broader application.

quote: Here, unlike the situation presented in Williams v. North Carolina, 325 U. S. 226 (1945), the finding of the requisite jurisdictional facts was made in proceedings in which the defendant appeared and participated.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly distinguishes Williams v. North Carolina (1945) by noting that unlike that case, here the defendant appeared and participated in the proceedings, making it a different factual situation requiring different legal treatment.

quote: Thus in Stoll v. Gottlieb, 305 U. S. 165, 172 (1938), it was said: 'Courts to determine the rights of parties are an integral part of our system of government. It is just as important that there should be a place to end as that there should be a place to begin litigation.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Stoll v. Gottlieb to support the general principle of res judicata and the importance of finality in litigation, without criticizing or questioning the precedent.

quote: If in its application local policy must at times be required to give way, such 'is part of the price of our federal system.' Williams v. North Carolina, 317 U. S. 287, 302 (1942).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Williams v. North Carolina (1943) to support the principle that local policy must sometimes yield to federal constitutional requirements, using it as supportive authority without negative treatment.

quote: We believe that the decision of this Court in the Davis case and those in related situations are clearly indicative of the result to be reached here. Those cases stand for the proposition that the requirements of full faith and credit bar a defendant from collaterally attacking a divorce decree on jurisdictional grounds in the courts of a sister State where there has been participation by the defendant in the divorce proceedings.
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on Davis v. Davis as supportive precedent for its holding, treating it as clearly indicative authority without any negative commentary or limitation.

quote: This Court has also held that the doctrine of res judicata must be applied to questions of jurisdiction in cases arising in state courts involving the application of the full faith and credit clause where, under the law of the state in which the original judgment was rendered, such adjudications are not susceptible to collateral attack.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Treinies v. Sunshine Mining Co. as part of a string citation supporting the application of res judicata principles to jurisdictional questions, without any critical analysis.

quote: But insofar as the rule of that case may be said to be inconsistent with the judgment herein announced, it must be regarded as having been superseded by subsequent decisions of this Court. The Andrews case was decided prior to the considerable modern development of the law with respect to finality of jurisdictional findings.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly limits the precedential value of Andrews v. Andrews by stating that insofar as it is inconsistent with the current decision, it has been superseded by subsequent developments in the law.

quote: Under such circumstances, there is nothing in the concept of due process which demands that a defendant be afforded a second opportunity to litigate the existence of jurisdictional facts. Chicago Life Insurance Co. v. Cherry, 244 U. S. 25 (1917).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Chicago Life Insurance v. Cherry as supportive authority for the principle that due process does not require a second opportunity to litigate jurisdictional facts, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Baldwin v. Iowa State Traveling Men's Assn. (1931)

Chicago Life Insurance Co. v. Cherry, 244 U. S. 25 (1917); Baldwin v. Iowa Traveling Men's Assn., 283 U. S. 522 (1931).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Baldwin v. Iowa State Traveling Men's Assn. as part of a string citation supporting the due process principle, without any critical commentary or negative treatment.

cited_decision: Chicot County Drainage District v. Baxter State Bank (1940)
quote: Baldwin v. Iowa State Traveling Men's Association, 283 U. S. 522 (1931); Stoll v. Gottlieb, 305 U. S. 165 (1938); Chicot County Drainage District v. Baxter State Bank, 308 U. S. 371 (1940).
rationale: The Acting Decision includes Chicot County Drainage District v. Baxter State Bank in a string citation supporting the application of res judicata principles to jurisdictional determinations, without any negative treatment.

quote: In the light of the broad groundings of the Mountain Producers decision and of later decisions, we cannot say that the Gipsy Oil, Large Oil and Barnsdall Refineries decisions remain immune to the effects of the Mountain Producers decision and others which have followed it. They 'are out of harmony with correct principle,' as were the Gillespie and Coronado decisions and, accordingly, they should be, and they now are, overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the Barnsdall Refineries decision is overruled along with the Gipsy Oil and Large Oil decisions because they are out of harmony with correct principle established by the Mountain Producers decision.

quote: The opportunity to reexamine the Gillespie and Coronado cases arose in 1938 in Helvering v. Mountain Producers Corp., 303 U. S. 376, the decision upon which the Oklahoma commission relies most strongly to secure reversal of the judgments in the present cases.
rationale: The Acting Decision extensively discusses and relies upon the Mountain Producers decision as controlling precedent that undermines earlier immunity decisions, using it as the foundation for overruling other cases without criticizing or questioning its validity.

cited_decision: Choctaw, Oklahoma & Gulf Railroad v. Harrison
quote: Moreover, since the decisions in Choctaw, O. & G. R. Co. v. Harrison, supra, and Indian Territory Illuminating Oil Co. v. Oklahoma, supra, rest upon the same foundations as those underlying the Gipsy Oil, Large Oil and Barnsdall Refineries decisions, indeed supplied those foundations, we think they too should be, and they now are, overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly overrules the Choctaw decision because it rests upon the same foundations as the other overruled decisions and actually supplied the foundations for those later decisions.

quote: Later this Court sustained a state tax on the gross receipts of a contractor with the Federal Government, James v. Dravo Contracting Co., 302 U. S. 134; Silas Mason Co. v. rationale: The Acting Decision cites James v. Dravo Contracting Co. as part of a series of cases that sustained various state taxes on contractors with the Federal Government, using it as supportive precedent without any negative treatment.

quote: In the light of the broad groundings of the Mountain Producers decision and of later decisions, we cannot say that the Gipsy Oil, Large Oil and Barnsdall Refineries decisions remain immune to the effects of the Mountain Producers decision and others which have followed it. They 'are out of harmony with correct principle,' as were the Gillespie and Coronado decisions and, accordingly, they should be, and they now are, overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the Gipsy Oil decision is overruled along with the Large Oil and Barnsdall Refineries decisions because they are out of harmony with correct principle established by the Mountain Producers decision.

quote: In the light of the broad groundings of the Mountain Producers decision and of later decisions, we cannot say that the Gipsy Oil, Large Oil and Barnsdall Refineries decisions remain immune to the effects of the Mountain Producers decision and others which have followed it. They 'are out of harmony with correct principle,' as were the Gillespie and Coronado decisions and, accordingly, they should be, and they now are, overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the Large Oil decision is overruled along with the Gipsy Oil and Barnsdall Refineries decisions because they are out of harmony with correct principle established by the Mountain Producers decision.

cited_decision: Mutual Film Corp. v. Industrial Commission of Ohio
quote: To the extent that language in the opinion in Mutual Film Corp. v. Industrial Comm'n, supra, is out of harmony with the views here set forth, we no longer adhere to it.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it no longer adheres to language in the Mutual Film decision that conflicts with its holding that motion pictures are protected by the First Amendment, effectively overruling that portion of the precedent.

cited_decision: Near v. Minnesota Ex Rel. Olson
quote: This Court recognized many years ago that such a previous restraint is a form of infringement upon freedom of expression to be especially condemned. Near v. Minnesota ex rel. Olson, 283 U. S. 697 (1931).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Near favorably as establishing the principle that prior restraints on expression are especially condemned, using it to support its constitutional analysis without criticism or limitation.

quote: See Lovell v. Griffin, 303 U. S. 444, 452 (1938).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Lovell in a footnote as part of a series of cases establishing First Amendment principles, without any negative treatment or significant discussion.

quote: E. g., Feiner v. New York, 340 U. S. 315 (1951); Kovacs v. Cooper, 336 U. S. 77 (1949); Chaplinsky v. New Hampshire, 315 U. S. 568 (1942); Cox v. New Hampshire, 312 U. S. 569 (1941).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Kovacs as one of several examples demonstrating that the Constitution does not require absolute freedom for every form of expression, using it neutrally to support its analysis.

quote: In Cantwell v. Connecticut, 310 U. S. 296, 310 (1940), Mr. Justice Roberts, speaking for the whole Court, said: 'In the realm of religious faith, and in that of political -belief, sharp differences arise. In both fields the tenets of one man may seem the rankest error to his neighbor.'
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes Cantwell approvingly to support its reasoning about religious differences and the difficulty of defining what constitutes sacrilege, using it as supportive authority.

quote: We fail to see why operation for profit should have any different effect in the case of motion pictures. See Grosjean v. American Press Co., 297 U. S. 233 (1936); Thomas v. Collins, 323 U. S. 516, 531 (1945).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Grosjean to support the principle that commercial operation does not disqualify expression from First Amendment protection, using it as favorable precedent.

cited_decision: MATTER OF JOSEPH BURSTYN, INC. v. Wilson
quote: Reversed.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly reverses the New York Court of Appeals decision, which had upheld the Board of Regents' determination that the film was sacrilegious and could be banned.

cited_decision: Ayer & Lord Tie Co. v. Kentucky

S. 18 , first applied to railroad cars in interstate commerce.
rationale: The decision is referenced positively as establishing the apportionment formula that was applied to inland water transportation, without any negative treatment.

Old Dominion S. S. Co. v. Virginia, 198 U. S. 299 ), Ohio, the state of the domicile, would have a strong claim to the whole of the tax that has been levied.

cited_decision: New York Central R. Co. v. Miller
quote: New York Central R. Co. v. Miller, 202 U. S. 584 , sustained a tax by the domiciliary state on all the rolling stock.of a railroad. But in that case it did not appear that 'any specific cars or any average of cars' was so continuously in another state as to be taxable there.
rationale: The court distinguishes this case by noting the factual difference that in Miller, the rolling stock was not continuously in another state, unlike the present case where the vessels were almost continuously outside Ohio.

quote: Under the earlier view governing the taxability of vessels moving in the inland waters (St. Louis v. Ferry Co., 11 Wall. 423 ; Ayer & Lord Tie Co. v. Kentucky, 202 U. S. 409 ; cf. Old Dominion S. S. Co. v. Virginia, 198 U. S. 299 ), Ohio, the state of the domicile, would have a strong claim to the whole of the tax that has been levied.
rationale: The decision is referenced as part of the earlier view on vessel taxation without negative treatment, serving as background for the legal framework that was later modified.

cited_decision: Ott v. Mississippi Barge Line Co.
quote: But the rationale of those cases was rejected in Ott v. Mississippi Barge Line Co., 336 U. S. 169 , where we held that vessels moving in interstate operations along the inland waters were taxable by the same standards as those which Pullman's Car Co. v. Pennsylvania, 141 U. S. 18 , first applied to railroad cars in interstate commerce.
rationale: The decision is cited approvingly as establishing the current standard for taxing vessels in interstate operations, with the court applying its apportionment principle to the present case.

quote: Northwest Airlines, Inc. v. Minnesota, 322 U. S. 292 , allowed the domiciliary state to tax the entire fleet: of airplanes operating interstate; but in that case, as in the Miller case, it was not shown that 'a. defined part of the domiciliary corpus' had acquired a. taxable situs elsewhere.
rationale: The court distinguishes this case by noting that unlike Northwest Airlines, where no defined part had acquired a taxable situs elsewhere, in the present case the vessels were almost continuously outside Ohio and could be taxed by other states.

quote: The rule which permits taxatioft by two or more states on. an apportionment basis precludes taxation of all of the property by the state of the domicile. See Union Transit Co. v. Kentucky, 199 U. S. 194 .
rationale: The decision is cited to support the principle that apportionment taxation by multiple states precludes full taxation by the domiciliary state, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Pacific Employers Insurance Co. v. Industrial Accident Comm'n
quote: Pacific Employers Insurance Co. v. Commission, 306 U. S. 493, departed, however, from the Clapper decision. There a resident of Massachusetts regularly employed in Massachusetts by a Massachusetts corporation was injured while doing temporary duty in California. The Massachusetts Compensation Act purported to give an exclusive remedy, even for injuries incurred beyond its borders. But California also had a Compensation Act which undertook to fix liability on employers, irrespective of any contract, rule, or regulation, a provision which the California courts strictly enforced. The Court, therefore, held that the exclusive nature of the Massachusetts Act was 'obnoxious' to the policy of California.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Pacific Employers as establishing precedent that allows the state where injury occurs to override the compensation act of the home state, using it as supportive authority without criticism or limitation.

cited_decision: Bradford Electric Light Co. v. Clapper
quote: It was indeed held in the Clapper case that a Vermont Compensation Act, which purported to give an exclusive remedy, barred a common-law action on the same claim in the New Hampshire courts by a Vermont employee against a Vermont employer, even though the injury occurred in New Hampshire. The Clapper case allowed a State to fix one exclusive remedy for personal injuries involving its residents, and required the other States to refuse to enforce any inconsistent remedy.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Clapper by noting that it involved different factual circumstances (Vermont employee against Vermont employer) and explains how the Pacific Employers case departed from Clapper's approach.

quote: This is not a case like Hughes v. Fetter, 341 U. S. 609, where the State of the forum seeks to exclude from its courts actions arising under a foreign statute. In that case, we held that Wisconsin could not refuse to entertain a wrongful death action under an Illinois statute for an injury occurring in Illinois, since we found no sufficient policy considerations to warrant such refusal. And see Broderick v. Rosner, 294 U. S. 629.
rationale: The Acting Decision merely references Broderick v. Rosner as additional support for the principle established in Hughes v. Fetter, without any critical analysis or limitation of its precedential value.

quote: The Missouri Supreme Court has construed the Missouri Compensation Act as providing the exclusive remedy, even when, as here, the employee of the subcontractor sues the general contractor for common-law damages. Bunner v. Patti, 343 Mo. 274, 283, 121 S. W. 2d 153, 156-157.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Bunner v. Patti to establish Missouri law regarding the exclusivity of the compensation act, using it as factual background without challenging its precedential value.

quote: This is not a case like Hughes v. Fetter, 341 U. S. 609, where the State of the forum seeks to exclude from its courts actions arising under a foreign statute. In that case, we held that Wisconsin could not refuse to entertain a wrongful death action under an Illinois statute for an injury occurring in Illinois, since we found no sufficient policy considerations to warrant such refusal.
rationale: The Acting Decision uses Hughes v. Fetter to distinguish the present case, explaining that Arkansas is not adopting a policy of hostility but rather applying its own law, without criticizing the cited decision's reasoning or precedential value.

quote: If it is due process for Nevada to adjudicate the marriage status of a domiciliary without personal service over the absent spouse (as it clearly is, see Williams v. North Carolina, I, 317 U. S. 287 ), I see no reason why Nevada cannot, at least for the purposes of her own law, also adjudicate the incidents of that status.
rationale: The dissenting opinion references Williams v. North Carolina as established precedent regarding Nevada's power to adjudicate marriage status without personal service, using it as support for an argument without criticizing or questioning its validity.

quote: It has long been the constitutional rule that a court cannot adjudicate a personal claim or obligation unless it has jurisdiction over the person of the defendant.
rationale: The lead opinion cites Pennoyer v. Neff as establishing the foundational constitutional rule regarding personal jurisdiction, treating it as settled precedent without any negative commentary.

quote: For the reasons given in a concurring opinion in Armstrong v. Armstrong, 350 U. S. 568, 575 , at 580-581, the Thompson case, insofar as it held that an ex parte divorce destroyed alimony rights, can no longer be considered controlling.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that Thompson v. Thompson 'can no longer be considered controlling' regarding its holding on ex parte divorce destroying alimony rights, thereby limiting its precedential scope and applicability.

quote: In Estin v. Estin, 334 U. S. 541 , this Court decided that a Nevada divorce court, which had no personal jurisdiction over the wife, had no power to terminate a husband's obligation to provide her support as required in a preexisting New York separation decree.
rationale: The Court references Estin v. Estin as precedent that supports its reasoning in the current case, treating it as established authority without any criticism or limitation of its holding.

quote: We hold that all evidence obtained by searches and seizures in violation of the Constitution is, by that same authority, inadmissible in a state court.
rationale: The Court explicitly overrules Wolf v. Colorado by extending the federal exclusionary rule to state courts, directly contradicting Wolf's holding that states were not required to exclude illegally obtained evidence.

quote: Likewise, time has set its face against what Wolf called the 'weighty testimony' of People v. Defore, 242 N. Y. 13, 150 N. E. 585 (1926). There Justice (then Judge) Cardozo, rejecting adoption of the Weeks exclusionary rule in New York, had said that '[t]he Federal rule as it stands is either too strict or too lax.' However, the force of that reasoning has been largely vitiated by later decisions of this Court.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that time has set its face against Defore and that the force of its reasoning has been largely vitiated, indicating strong disagreement with the decision's reasoning and conclusions.

quote: The philosophy of each Amendment and of each freedom is complementary to, although not dependent upon, that of the other in its sphere of influence — the very least that together they assure in either sphere is that no man is to be convicted on unconstitutional evidence. Cf. Rochin v. California, 342 U. S. 165, 173 (1952).
rationale: The Court merely cites Rochin as a comparison point to support its broader argument about constitutional protections, without any negative treatment or significant analysis of the decision itself.

quote: Only last year the Court itself recognized that the purpose of the exclusionary rule 'is to deter — to compel respect for the constitutional guaranty in the only effectively available way — by removing the incentive to disregard it.' Elkins v. United States, supra, at 217.
rationale: The Court favorably cites Elkins to support its reasoning about the purpose of the exclusionary rule, using it as authority for the Court's current holding without any negative treatment.

quote: Less than 30 years after Boyd, this Court, in Weeks v. United States, 232 U. S. 383 (1914), stated that 'the Fourth Amendment . . . put the courts of the United States and Federal officials, in the exercise of their power and authority, under limitations and restraints [and] . . . forever secure [d] the people, their persons, houses, papers and effects against all unreasonable searches and seizures under the guise of law . . . and the duty of giving to it force and effect is obligatory upon all entrusted under our Federal system with the enforcement of the laws.'
rationale: The Court extensively discusses and relies upon Weeks as foundational precedent for the exclusionary rule in federal courts, using it as the basis for extending the rule to state courts without any criticism or limitation.

quote: The obvious futility of relegating the Fourth Amendment to the protection of other remedies has, moreover, been recognized by this Court since Wolf. See Irvine v. California, 347 U. S. 128, 137 (1954).
rationale: The Court cites Irvine as support for its argument that alternative remedies to the exclusionary rule have proven futile, using it to bolster the case for overruling Wolf without any negative treatment of Irvine itself.

quote: Significantly, among those now following the rule is California, which, according to its highest court, was 'compelled to reach tha(t conclusion because other remedies have completely failed to secure compliance with the constitutional provisions . . . .' People v. Cohan, 44 Cal. 2d 434, 445, 282 P. 2d 905, 911 (1955).
rationale: The Court favorably cites Cahan as an example of a state court that adopted the exclusionary rule due to the failure of other remedies, using it to support the argument for applying the rule nationwide.

quote: Seventy-five years ago, in Boyd v. United States, 116 U. S. 616, 630 (1886), considering the Fourth and Fifth Amendments as running 'almost into each other' on the facts before it, this Court held that the doctrines of those Amendments 'apply to all invasions on the part of the government and its employés of the sanctity of a man's home and the privacies of life.'
rationale: The Court cites Boyd as foundational precedent establishing the constitutional basis for privacy rights and the exclusionary principle, using it as historical support for the current holding without any negative treatment.

quote: We believe that Wilcox was wrongly decided and we find nothing in congressional history since then to persuade us that Congress intended to legislate the rule. Thus, we believe that we should now correct the error and the confusion resulting from it, certainly if we do so in a manner that will not prejudice those who might have relied on it.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Wilcox was wrongly decided and should be corrected, and later confirms that 'Since Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Frankfurter, and Mr. Justice Clark agree with us concerning Wilcox, that case is overruled.'

quote: Six years later, this Court held, in Rutkin v. United States, 343 U. S. 130, that extorted money does constitute taxable income to the extortionist in the year that the money is received under § 22 (a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1939.
rationale: The Acting Decision uses Rutkin to demonstrate inconsistency with Wilcox and to support its reasoning for overruling Wilcox, but does not criticize or question Rutkin's precedential value.

cited_decision: McKnight v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue
quote: When a law-abiding taxpayer mistakenly receives income in one year, which receipt is assailed and found to be invalid in a subsequent year, the taxpayer must nonetheless report the amount as 'gross income' in the year received. United States v. Lewis, supra; Healy v. Commissioner, supra.
rationale: The case is referenced in passing as support for the principle that taxpayers must report income in the year received even if later found invalid, without any negative treatment.

quote: In such case, the taxpayer has 'actual command over the property taxed — the actual benefit for which the tax is paid,' Corliss v. Bowers, supra.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Corliss v. Bowers to support its standard for determining taxable income based on actual command over property, without questioning its precedential value.

quote: Thereafter, the Court held that gains from illicit traffic in liquor are includible within 'gross income.' Ibid. See also Johnson v. United States, 318 U. S. 189; United States v. Johnson, 319 U. S. 503.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Sullivan as precedent supporting the taxation of unlawful gains, using it to bolster the argument that illegal income should be taxed.

quote: But the fact that Congress has remained silent or has re-enacted a statute which we have construed, or that congressional attempts to amend a rule announced by this Court have failed, does not necessarily debar us from re-examining and correcting the Court's own errors. Girouard v. United States, 328 U. S. 61, 69-70; Helvering v. Hallock, 309 U. S. 106, 119-122.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Helvering v. Hallock as precedent supporting the Court's authority to correct its own errors despite congressional silence, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: North American Oil Consolidated v. Burnet
quote: When a taxpayer acquires earnings, lawfully or unlawfully, without the consensual recognition, express or implied, of an obligation to repay and without restriction as to their disposition, 'he has received income which he is required to return, even though it may still be claimed that he is not entitled to retain the money, and even though he may still be adjudged liable to restore its equivalent.' North American Oil v. Burnet, supra, at p. 424.
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes North American Oil to establish the standard for when receipts constitute taxable income, using it as supportive precedent without questioning its validity.

quote: When a law-abiding taxpayer mistakenly receives income in one year, which receipt is assailed and found to be invalid in a subsequent year, the taxpayer must nonetheless report the amount as 'gross income' in the year received. United States v. Lewis, supra; Healy v. Commissioner, supra.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Lewis as precedent for the principle that income must be reported in the year received even if later determined to be invalid, without any negative treatment.

quote: In Gideon v. Wainwright, 372 U. S. 335 , we held that every person accused of a crime, whether state or federal, is entitled to a lawyer at trial.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Gideon as established precedent for the right to counsel at trial, using it as foundational support without criticism or limitation.

quote: We conclude, for the reasons stated below, that it was not and, accordingly, we reverse the judgment of conviction.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly overturns the outcome of the Illinois Supreme Court's decision in the same case, reversing the conviction.

quote: In Massiah v. United States, 377 U. S. 201 , this Court observed that 'a Constitution which guarantees a defendant the aid of counsel at . . . trial could surely vouchsafe no less to an indicted defendant under interrogation by the police in a completely extrajudicial proceeding.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Massiah favorably as supporting precedent for extending the right to counsel to pre-trial interrogation, building upon its reasoning without criticism.

quote: In any event, to the extent that Cicenia or Crooker may be inconsistent with the principles announced today, they are not to be regarded as controlling.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Cicenia should not be regarded as controlling to the extent it conflicts with the new rule, thereby limiting its precedential value.

quote: It was a stage surely as critical as was the arraignment in Hamilton v. Alabama, 368 U. S. 52 , and the preliminary hearing in White v. Maryland, 373 U. S. 59 .
rationale: The Acting Decision cites White v. Maryland as an example of a critical stage requiring counsel, using it as supportive precedent without any negative treatment.

quote: When petitioner requested, and was denied, an opportunity to consult with his lawyer, the investigation had ceased to be a general investigation of 'an unsolved crime.' Spano v. New York, 360 U. S. 315, 327 (Stewart, J., concurring).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Spano favorably to support the distinction between general investigation and focused interrogation, using it as supportive authority.

quote: In any event, to the extent that Cicenia or Crooker may be inconsistent with the principles announced today, they are not to be regarded as controlling.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Crooker should not be regarded as controlling to the extent it conflicts with the new rule, thereby limiting its precedential value.

quote: It was a stage surely as critical as was the arraignment in Hamilton v. Alabama, 368 U. S. 52 , and the preliminary hearing in White v. Maryland, 373 U. S. 59 .
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Hamilton v. Alabama as an example of a critical stage requiring counsel, using it as supportive precedent without any negative treatment.

quote: The doctrine that prevailed in Lochner, Coppage, Adkins, Burns, and like cases — that due process authorizes courts to hold laws unconstitutional when they believe the legislature has acted unwisely- — -has long since been discarded.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the doctrine from Adkins has been discarded and criticizes the approach of using due process to strike down laws based on judicial views of legislative wisdom.

quote: The doctrine that prevailed in Lochner, Coppage, Adkins, Burns, and like cases — that due process authorizes courts to hold laws unconstitutional when they believe the legislature has acted unwisely- — -has long since been discarded.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly criticizes Lochner as part of a discarded doctrine that improperly allowed courts to substitute their judgment for that of legislatures.

quote: Dissenting from the Court's invalidating a state statute which regulated the resale price of theatre and other tickets, Mr. Justice Holmes said, 'I think the proper course is to recognize that a state legislature can do whatever it sees fit to do unless it is restrained by some express prohibition in the Constitution'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Justice Holmes' dissent in Tyson favorably to support the principle of judicial restraint, using it as authority for the court's current position.
