cited_decision: Olsen v. Nebraska Ex Rel. Western Reference & Bond Assn., Inc.
quote: As this Court stated in a unanimous opinion in 1941, 'We are not concerned . . . with the wisdom, need, or appropriateness of the legislation.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Olsen approvingly to support the principle that courts should not concern themselves with the wisdom of legislation, using it as authority for judicial restraint.

quote: this Court does not sit to 'subject the State to an intolerable supervision hostile to the basic principles of our Government and wholly beyond the protection which the general clause of the Fourteenth Amendment was intended to secure.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Sproles favorably to support the principle that courts should not engage in excessive supervision of state legislation, reinforcing the court's position on judicial restraint.

cited_decision: Lincoln Federal Labor Union v. Northwestern Iron & Metal Co.
quote: It is now settled that States 'have power to legislate against what are found to be injurious practices in their internal commercial and business affairs, so long as their laws do not run afoul of some specific federal constitutional prohibition, or of some valid federal law.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Lincoln Federal Labor Union approvingly to establish the settled principle that states have broad power to regulate business practices, supporting the court's deference to legislative judgment.

cited_decision: Williamson v. Lee Optical of Oklahoma, Inc.
quote: we emphatically refuse to go back to the time when courts used the Due Process Clause 'to strike down state laws, regulatory of business and industrial conditions, because they may be unwise, improvident, or out of harmony with a particular school of thought.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Williamson favorably to support its rejection of substantive due process review of economic legislation, using it as authority for judicial restraint.

cited_decision: Home Budget Service, Inc. v. Boston Bar Association
quote: Massachusetts and Virginia prohibit debt pooling by laymen by declaring it to constitute the practice of law. Mass. Gen. Laws Ann. (1958) c. 221, § 46C; Va. Code Ann. (1958) §54-44.1. The Massachusetts statute was upheld in Home Budget Service, Inc., v. Boston Bar Assn., 335 Mass. 228, 139 N. E. 2d 387 (1957).
rationale: The Acting Decision merely references Home Budget Service as an example of a court upholding a similar statute, providing factual context without any critical analysis of the decision.

quote: reliance on Adams v. Tanner is as mistaken as would be adherence to Adkins v. Children's Hospital, overruled by West Coast Hotel Co. v. Parrish, 300 U. S. 379 (1937). Not only has the philosophy of Adams been abandoned, but also this Court almost 15 years ago expressly pointed to another opinion of this Court as having 'clearly undermined' Adams.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly criticizes Adams v. Tanner, stating that reliance on it is mistaken, that its philosophy has been abandoned, and that it has been undermined by subsequent decisions.

quote: We overrule Brown v. United States, supra, and reverse and remand this case for proceedings under Rule 42 (b).
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it overrules Brown v. United States, directly nullifying the precedential value of that decision.

quote: In more than one instance in the Southern District of New York, from which this case comes, witnesses cited for testimonial contempt before the grand jury were given hearings under Rule 42 (b). E. g., United States v. Castaldi, 338 F. 2d 883 ; United States v. Tramunti, 343 F. 2d 548 ; United States v. Shillitani, 345 F. 2d 290; United States v. Pappadio, 346 F. 2d 5 .
rationale: The case is merely cited as an example of instances where Rule 42(b) procedures were followed, without any significant discussion or analysis of its holding.

quote: In more than one instance in the Southern District of New York, from which this case comes, witnesses cited for testimonial contempt before the grand jury were given hearings under Rule 42 (b). E. g., United States v. Castaldi, 338 F. 2d 883 ; United States v. Tramunti, 343 F. 2d 548 ; United States v. Shillitani, 345 F. 2d 290; United States v. Pappadio, 346 F. 2d 5 .
rationale: The case is merely cited as an example of instances where Rule 42(b) procedures were followed, without any significant discussion or analysis of its holding.

quote: Summary contempt is for 'misbehavior' (Ex parte Terry, 128 U. S. 289, 314 ) in the 'actual presence of the court.'
rationale: The case is cited to support the definition of summary contempt for misbehavior, providing clarification without challenging its precedential value.

quote: Brown v. United States was reaffirmed and followed in Levine v. United States, 362 U. S. 610 .
rationale: The case is mentioned in the dissenting opinion as having reaffirmed Brown, but this is merely a factual reference without any treatment by the majority opinion.

quote: In more than one instance in the Southern District of New York, from which this case comes, witnesses cited for testimonial contempt before the grand jury were given hearings under Rule 42 (b). E. g., United States v. Castaldi, 338 F. 2d 883 ; United States v. Tramunti, 343 F. 2d 548 ; United States v. Shillitani, 345 F. 2d 290; United States v. Pappadio, 346 F. 2d 5 .
rationale: The case is merely cited as an example of instances where Rule 42(b) procedures were followed, without any significant discussion or analysis of its holding.

quote: In more than one instance in the Southern District of New York, from which this case comes, witnesses cited for testimonial contempt before the grand jury were given hearings under Rule 42 (b). E. g., United States v. Castaldi, 338 F. 2d 883 ; United States v. Tramunti, 343 F. 2d 548 ; United States v. Shillitani, 345 F. 2d 290; United States v. Pappadio, 346 F. 2d 5 .
rationale: The case is merely cited as an example of instances where Rule 42(b) procedures were followed, without any significant discussion or analysis of its holding.

quote: The Ross approach that the Constitution has no applicability abroad has long since been directly repudiated by numerous cases. That approach is obviously erroneous if the United States Government, which has no power except that granted by the Constitution, can and does try citizens for crimes committed abroad. Thus the Ross case rested, at least in substantial part, on a fundamental misconception and the most that can be said in support of the result reached there is that the consular court jurisdiction had a long history antedating the adoption of the Constitution.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly criticizes the Ross case as being based on a fundamental misconception and states that its approach has been repudiated by numerous cases.

cited_decision: United States ex rel. Toth v. Quarles
quote: Just last Term, this Court held in United States ex rel. Toth v. Quarles, 350 U. S. 11, that military courts could not constitutionally try a discharged serviceman for an offense which he had allegedly committed while in the armed forces.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Toth v. Quarles to support its reasoning about the limits of military jurisdiction over civilians, without criticizing or questioning its precedential value.

quote: See Dorr v. United States, 195 U. S. 138, 144-148.
rationale: The Acting Decision merely cites Dorr v. United States in a footnote regarding constitutional rights that are considered 'fundamental' for Americans abroad, without significant discussion or criticism.

quote: The two cases were consolidated and argued last Term and a majority of the Court, with three Justices dissenting and one reserving opinion, held that military trial of Mrs. Smith and Mrs. Covert for their alleged offenses was constitutional. 351 U. S. 470, 487. Subsequently, the Court granted a petition for rehearing, 352 U. S. 901. Now, after further argument and consideration, we conclude that the previous decisions cannot be permitted to stand.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the previous decisions in these same cases cannot be permitted to stand and overrules them after rehearing.

quote: The 'Insular Cases' can be distinguished from the present cases in that they involved the power of Congress to provide rules and regulations to govern temporarily territories with wholly dissimilar traditions and institutions whereas here the basis for governmental power is American citizenship. Moreover, it is our judgment that neither the cases nor their reasoning should be given any further expansion.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes the Insular Cases and explicitly states that their reasoning should not be given any further expansion, thereby limiting their scope and applicability.

quote: The 'Insular Cases,' which arose at the turn of the century, involved territories which had only recently been conquered or acquired by the United States. Moreover, it is our judgment that neither the cases nor their reasoning should be given any further expansion.
rationale: As part of the Insular Cases, the Acting Decision limits Hawaii v. Mankichi by stating that these cases should not be given any further expansion in their reasoning or application.

quote: Nothing said here contravenes the rule laid down in McCulloch v. Maryland, 4 Wheat. 316, at 421, that: 'Let the end be legitimate, let it be within the scope of the constitution, and all means which are appropriate, which are plainly adapted to that end, which are not prohibited, but consist with the letter and spirit of the constitution, are constitutional.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites McCulloch v. Maryland approvingly to clarify that its holding does not contradict the established rule about the Necessary and Proper Clause, without any negative treatment.

quote: In re Di Bartolo, 50 F. Supp. 929.
rationale: The Acting Decision merely cites In re Di Bartolo in a footnote as one of several cases involving military trial of civilians performing services for the armed forces during wartime, without significant discussion.

quote: Madsen v. Kinsella, 343 U. S. 341, is not controlling here. It concerned trials in enemy territory which had been conquered and held by force of arms and which was being governed at the time by our military forces.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly distinguishes Madsen v. Kinsella based on the different factual circumstances involving conquered enemy territory, thereby limiting its applicability to the present case.

quote: Ex parte Milligan, 4 Wall. 2, one of the great landmarks in this Court's history, held that military authorities were without power to try civilians not in the military or naval service by declaring martial law in an area where the civil administration was not deposed and the courts were not closed.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Ex parte Milligan approvingly as a landmark case supporting the principle that military jurisdiction over civilians is limited, using it to support its reasoning without any negative treatment.

quote: The 'Insular Cases' can be distinguished from the present cases in that they involved the power of Congress to provide rules and regulations to govern temporarily territories with wholly dissimilar traditions and institutions whereas here the basis for governmental power is American citizenship. Moreover, it is our judgment that neither the cases nor their reasoning should be given any further expansion.
rationale: As part of the Insular Cases, the Acting Decision limits Balzac v. Porto Rico by stating that these cases should not be given any further expansion in their reasoning or application.

quote: The two cases were consolidated and argued last Term and a majority of the Court, with three Justices dissenting and one reserving opinion, held that military trial of Mrs. Smith and Mrs. Covert for their alleged offenses was constitutional. 351 U. S. 470, 487. Subsequently, the Court granted a petition for rehearing, 352 U. S. 901. Now, after further argument and consideration, we conclude that the previous decisions cannot be permitted to stand.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly overrules its own previous decision in Reid v. Covert from 1956, stating that the previous decision cannot be permitted to stand after rehearing and further consideration.

quote: This case is not necessarily controlled by Douds. For to prove its assertion that § 9 (h) was preventive rather than retributive in purpose, the Court in Douds focused on the fact that members of the Communist Party could escape from the class of persons specified by Congress simply by resigning from the Party... Section 504, unlike § 9 (h), disqualifies from the holding of union office not only present members of the Communist Party, but also anyone who has within the past five years been a member of the Party.
rationale: The Court distinguishes Douds by noting key factual differences between the statutes, particularly that Section 504 includes a five-year lookback period that prevents escape from the class through resignation, unlike the statute in Douds.

cited_decision: Communist Party of United States v. Subversive Activities Control Bd.
quote: Communist Party v. Subversive Activities Control Board, 367 U. S. 1, lends support to our conclusion. That case involved an appeal from an order by the Control Board ordering the Communist Party to register as a 'Communist-action organization,' under the Subversive Activities Control Act of 1950... the majority clearly implied that if the Act had applied to the Communist Party by name, it would have been a bill of attainder
rationale: The Court cites this decision to support its conclusion about bill of attainder analysis, using it as precedential support for the principle that naming specific organizations would constitute a bill of attainder.

cited_decision: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System v. Agnew
quote: We find this argument without merit. First, we note that § 504, unlike § 32 of the Banking Act, inflicts its deprivation upon the members of a political group thought to present a threat to the national security... Second, § 32 incorporates no judgment censuring or condemning any man or group of men... Third, we cannot accept the suggestion that § 32 constitutes an exercise in specification rather than rule-making.
rationale: The Court distinguishes Agnew by identifying three key differences between the conflict-of-interest statute in that case and Section 504, rejecting the government's argument that they are analogous.

quote: The approach which Chief Justice Marshall had suggested was followed in the twin post-Civil War cases of Cummings v. Missouri, 4 Wall. 277, and Ex parte Garland, 4 Wall. 333. Cummings involved the constitutionality of amendments to the Missouri Constitution of 1865 which provided that no one could engage in a number of specified professions (Cummings was a priest) unless he first swore that he had taken no part in the rebellion against the Union.
rationale: The Court cites Cummings as historical precedent supporting its interpretation of the Bill of Attainder Clause, using it to establish the principle that legislative punishment of specific groups constitutes a bill of attainder.

quote: The next extended discussion of the Bill of Attainder Clause came in 1946, in United States v. Lovett, 328 U. S. 303, where the Court invalidated § 304 of the Urgent Deficiency Appropriation Act, 1943, 57 Stat. 431, 450, which prohibited payment of further salary to three named federal employees, as a bill of attainder.
rationale: The Court cites Lovett as precedential support for its bill of attainder analysis, using it to establish the principle that legislative acts targeting specific individuals without judicial trial constitute bills of attainder.

quote: The leading case is Hawker v. New York, 170 U. S. 189, which upheld a provision prohibiting convicted felons from practicing medicine against a claim that, as applied to one convicted before its enactment, it was an ex post facto law.
rationale: The Court mentions Hawker in the dissenting opinion as an example of legitimate legislative classification that would be threatened by the majority's approach, but does not directly engage with or criticize the decision itself.

quote: We summarized the relevant considerations in Kennedy v. Mendoza-Martinez, supra: 'Whether the sanction involves an affirmative disability or restraint, whether it has historically been regarded as a punishment, whether it comes into play only on a finding of scienter, whether its operation will promote the traditional aims of punishment— retribution and deterrence, whether the behavior to which it applies is already a crime, whether an alternative purpose to which it may rationally be connected is assignable for it, and whether it appears excessive in relation to the alternative purpose assigned are all relevant to the inquiry, and may often point in differing directions.'
rationale: The Court cites Kennedy v. Mendoza-Martinez in the dissenting opinion to outline the traditional multi-factor test for determining whether a statute constitutes punishment, without criticizing the decision itself.

quote: Perez v. Brownell is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Perez v. Brownell is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value.

cited_decision: United States v. Wong Kim Ark
quote: And this was the unequivocal statement of the Court in the case of United States v. Wong Kim Ark, 169 U. S. 649. The issues in that case were whether a person born in the United States to Chinese aliens was a citizen of the United States and whether, nevertheless, he could be excluded under the Chinese Exclusion Act, 22 Stat. 58. The Court first held that within the terms of the Fourteenth Amendment, Wong Kim Ark was a citizen of the United States, and then pointed out that though he might 'renounce this citizenship, and become a citizen of . . . any other country,' he had never done so.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Wong Kim Ark to support its position on citizenship rights under the Fourteenth Amendment, providing additional analysis without questioning its precedential value.

quote: his general understanding of the statute was approved by this Court in Kurtz v. Moffitt, 115 U. S. 487, 501.
rationale: The Acting Decision merely references Kurtz v. Moffitt in the dissenting opinion as supporting evidence for a particular interpretation of a statute, without any negative treatment.

quote: Moreover, in the other cases decided with and since Perez, this Court has consistently invalidated on a case-by-case basis various other statutory sections providing for involuntary expatriation.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Trop v. Dulles as one of the cases that cast doubt on Perez, but does not directly treat or analyze the decision itself.

quote: Finally, the dictum must be read in light of the subsequent opinion for the Court, written by Mr. Justice McKenna, in Mackenzie v. Hare, 239 U. S. 299. Despite counsel's invocation of Wong Kim Ark, id., at 302 and 303, the Court held in Mackenzie that marriage between an American citizen and an alien, unaccompanied by any intention of the citizen to renounce her citizenship, nonetheless permitted Congress to withdraw her nationality.
rationale: The Acting Decision references MacKenzie v. Hare in the dissenting opinion to illustrate a point about prior precedent, without expressing any negative treatment toward the decision.

quote: Having concluded that Frank v. Maryland, to the extent that it sanctioned such warrantless inspections, must be overruled, we reverse.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that Frank v. Maryland must be overruled to the extent it sanctioned warrantless inspections, directly nullifying the precedential value of that decision.

cited_decision: Ohio Ex Rel. Eaton v. Price
quote: In Eaton v. Price, 364 U. S. 263, a similar conviction was affirmed by an equally divided Court.
rationale: The decision is referenced factually as background information about similar cases, without any critical analysis or negative treatment of its holding.

quote: As such, the Fourth Amendment is enforceable against the States through the Fourteenth Amendment. Ker v. California, 374 U. S. 23, 30.
rationale: The decision is cited as supportive authority for the established principle that the Fourth Amendment applies to states through the Fourteenth Amendment, without any criticism or limitation.

quote: Relying on Frank v. Maryland, Eaton v. Price, and decisions in other States, the District Court of Appeal held that § 503 does not violate Fourth Amendment rights
rationale: The decision is mentioned as one of the state court decisions that the lower court relied upon, but there is no direct treatment or analysis of this decision by the Acting Decision.

quote: except in certain carefully defined classes of cases, a search of private property without proper consent is 'unreasonable' unless it has been authorized by a valid search warrant. See, e. g., Stoner v. California, 376 U. S. 483
rationale: The decision is cited as an example supporting the general principle that searches without warrants are unreasonable, without any criticism or negative treatment.

quote: except in certain carefully defined classes of cases, a search of private property without proper consent is 'unreasonable' unless it has been authorized by a valid search warrant. See, e. g., Stoner v. California, 376 U. S. 483; United States v. Jeffers, 342 U. S. 48; McDonald v. United States, 335 U. S. 451
rationale: The decision is cited as supportive authority for the established warrant requirement principle, without any criticism or limitation of its precedential value.

cited_decision: Paquette v. City of Fall River
quote: numerous courts have upheld the police power of municipalities to impose and enforce such minimum standards even upon existing structures
rationale: The decision is mentioned as one of several cases supporting the municipal police power to enforce housing standards, without any critical analysis or negative treatment.

quote: See also State v. Rees, 258 Iowa 813, 139 N. W. 2d 406 (1966); Commonwealth v. Hadley, 351 Mass. 439, 222 N. E. 2d 681 (1966)
rationale: The decision is listed among other state court cases that have addressed similar issues, without any substantive discussion or treatment of its holding.

quote: numerous courts have upheld the police power of municipalities to impose and enforce such minimum standards even upon existing structures
rationale: The decision is mentioned as one of several cases supporting municipal authority to enforce housing standards, without any critical analysis or negative treatment.

quote: the question is not whether the public interest justifies the type of search in question, but whether the authority to search should be evidenced by a warrant, which in turn depends in part upon whether the burden of obtaining a warrant is likely to frustrate the governmental purpose behind the search. See Schmerber v. California, 384 U. S. 757, 770-771.
rationale: The decision is cited as supportive authority for the principle about balancing warrant requirements against governmental purposes, without any criticism or limitation.

quote: Only last Term we sustained the validity of such an authorization, holding that, under sufficiently 'precise and discriminate circumstances,' a federal court may empower government agents to employ a concealed electronic device 'for the narrow and particularized purpose of ascertaining the truth of the . . . allegations' of a 'detailed factual affidavit alleging the commission of a specific criminal offense.' Osborn v. United States, 385 U. S. 323, 329-330. Discussing that holding, the Court in Berger v. New York, 388 U. S. 41, said that 'the order authorizing the use of the electronic device' in Osborn 'afforded similar protections to those ... of conventional warrants authorizing the seizure of tangible evidence.'
rationale: The Court references Berger v. New York to support its discussion of proper electronic surveillance procedures and warrant requirements, without criticizing or questioning the decision's validity.

quote: But '[t]he premise that property interests control the right of the Government to search and seize has been discredited.' Warden v. Hayden, 387 U. S. 294, 304.
rationale: The Court cites Warden v. Hayden to support its argument that Fourth Amendment protections extend beyond property interests, using it as authority for expanding Fourth Amendment coverage.

quote: Indeed, we have expressly held that the Fourth Amendment governs not only the seizure of tangible items, but extends as well to the recording of oral statements, overheard without any 'technical trespass under . . . local property law.' Silverman v. United States, 365 U. S. 505, 511.
rationale: The Court cites Silverman as precedent supporting the extension of Fourth Amendment protections to oral statements and recordings, using it to bolster its argument against the trespass doctrine.

quote: In previous eases, which are undisturbed by today's decision, the Court has upheld, as reasonable under the Fourth Amendment, admission at trial of evidence obtained (1) by an undercover police agent to whom a defendant speaks without knowledge that he is in the employ of the police, Hoffa v. United States, 385 U. S. 293 (1966); (2) by a recording device hidden on the person of such an informant, Lopez v. United States, 373 U. S. 427 (1963)
rationale: The Court mentions Lopez v. United States as an example of previously upheld surveillance methods that remain valid, distinguishing it from the current case without criticizing the decision.

quote: But if Osborn had been told in advance that federal officers intended to record his conversations, the point of making such recordings would obviously have been lost; the evidence in question could not have been obtained. In omitting any requirement of advance notice, the federal court that authorized electronic surveillance in Osborn simply recognized, as has this Court, that officers need not announce their purpose before conducting an otherwise authorized search if such an announcement would provoke the escape of the suspect or the destruction of critical evidence. See Ker v. California, 374 U. S. 23, 37-41.
rationale: The Court cites Ker v. California to support the principle that advance notice is not always required for searches when it would defeat the purpose, using it as supporting authority without criticism.

quote: But what he seeks-to preserve as private, even in an area accessible to the public, may be constitutionally protected. See Rios v. United States, 364 U. S. 253; Ex parte Jackson, 96 U. S. 727, 733.
rationale: The Court cites Rios v. United States as supporting precedent for the principle that privacy can be constitutionally protected even in publicly accessible areas, using it to support its reasoning without negative treatment.

quote: We conclude that the underpinnings of Olmstead and Goldman have been so eroded by our subsequent decisions that the 'trespass' doctrine there enunciated can no longer be regarded as controlling.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that Goldman's trespass doctrine can no longer be regarded as controlling and that its underpinnings have been eroded, effectively overruling the precedential value of Goldman.

quote: We conclude that the underpinnings of Olmstead and Goldman have been so eroded by our subsequent decisions that the 'trespass' doctrine there enunciated can no longer be regarded as controlling.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that Olmstead's trespass doctrine can no longer be regarded as controlling and that its underpinnings have been eroded, effectively overruling the precedential value of Olmstead.

quote: Moreover, to the extent that Adler sustained the provision of the Feinberg Law constituting membership in an organization advocating forceful overthrow of government a ground for disqualification, pertinent constitutional doctrines have since rejected the premises upon which that conclusion rested. Adler is therefore not dispositive of the constitutional issues we must decide in this case.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that constitutional doctrines have rejected the premises upon which Adler's conclusion rested, making it not dispositive and effectively overruling its holding regarding membership-based disqualification.

quote: We cannot gainsay the potential effect of this obscure wording on 'those with a conscientious and scrupulous regard for such undertakings.' Baggett v. Bullitt, 377 U. S. 360, 374.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Baggett v. Bullitt to support its analysis of vague statutory language and its chilling effect, using it as supportive authority without criticism or limitation.

quote: In Elfbrandt v. Russell, 384 U. S. 11, we said, 'Those who join an organization but do not share its unlawful purposes and who do not participate in its unlawful activities surely pose no threat, either as citizens or as public employees.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Elfbrandt v. Russell favorably to establish the governing standard that mere knowing membership without specific intent is insufficient for constitutional exclusion from employment.

quote: We emphasize once again that '[precision of regulation must be the touchstone in an area so closely touching our most precious freedoms,' N. A. A. C. P. v. Button, 371 U. S. 415, 438
rationale: The Acting Decision cites N.A.A.C.P. v. Button as supportive authority for the principle that regulations affecting First Amendment freedoms must be precisely crafted, using it to support its constitutional analysis.

quote: When one must guess what conduct or utterance may lose him his position, one necessarily will 'steer far wider of the unlawful zone . . . .' Speiser v. Randall, 357 U. S. 513, 526.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Speiser v. Randall to illustrate the chilling effect of vague regulations on constitutional rights, using it as supportive precedent for its vagueness analysis.

quote: But 'even though the governmental purpose be legitimate and substantial, that purpose cannot be pursued by means that broadly stifle fundamental personal liberties when the end can be more narrowly achieved.' Shelton v. Tucker, 364 U. S. 479, 488.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Shelton v. Tucker favorably to establish the principle that legitimate governmental purposes cannot justify overly broad restrictions on fundamental liberties when narrower means are available.

quote: It may well prohibit the employment of one who merely advocates the doctrine in the abstract without any attempt to indoctrinate others, or incite others to action in furtherance of unlawful aims. See Herndon v. Lowry, 301 U. S. 242 ; Yates v. United States, 354 U. S. 298
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Yates v. United States as supportive authority for the distinction between abstract advocacy and incitement to action, using it to support its analysis of the statute's overbreadth.

cited_decision: Cramp v. Board of Public Instruction
quote: The regulatory maze created by New York is wholly lacking in 'terms susceptible of objective measurement.' Cramp v. Board of Public Instruction, supra, at 286.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Cramp v. Board of Public Instruction to support its finding that the New York regulatory scheme lacks the objective measurement standards required for constitutional validity in the area of First Amendment rights.

quote: The federal habeas corpus statute does not require this result, and Parker v. Ellis must be overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Parker v. Ellis must be overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value regarding habeas corpus jurisdiction when a petitioner is released from custody.

cited_decision: United States of America Ex Rel. James P. Carafas v. J. Edwin Lavallee, Warden, Auburn Prison, Auburn, New York
quote: 334 F. 2d 331 (1964); petition for writ of certiorari denied, 381 U. S. 951 (1965). On November 5, 1965, the United States District Court, as directed by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ( 334 F. 2d 331 (1964)), heard petitioner's claim on the merits.
rationale: The decision is referenced as part of the procedural history without any substantive analysis or treatment of its legal reasoning.

quote: In Nowakowski , we held that 'when a district judge grants ... a certificate [of probable cause], the court of appeals must grant an appeal in forma pauperis (assuming the requisite showing of poverty), and proceed to a disposition of the appeal in accord with its ordinary procedure.'
rationale: The decision is cited favorably and applied to the facts of the case, with the court following its holding without criticism or modification.

quote: Because of these 'disabilities or burdens [which] may flow from' petitioner's conviction, he has 'a substantial stake in the judgment of conviction which survives the satisfaction of the sentence imposed on him.' Fiswick v. United States, 329 U. S. 211, 222 (1946).
rationale: The decision is cited supportively to establish the principle that collateral consequences prevent a case from becoming moot, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Nathan Thomas v. W. K. Cunningham, Jr., Superintendent of the Virginia State Penitentiary
quote: See Thomas v. Cunningham, 335 F. 2d 67 (C. A. 4th Cir. 1964).
rationale: The decision is merely referenced in a footnote without substantive discussion or analysis of its holding.

quote: Although Nowakowski was decided after the Court of Appeals dismissed petitioner's appeal, its holding applies to a habeas corpus proceeding which, like this one, was not concluded at the time Nowakowski was decided. Cf. Eskridge v. Washington Prison Board, 357 U. S. 214 (1958); see also Linkletter v. Walker, 381 U. S. 618, 628 , n. 13 and 639, n. 20 (1965)
rationale: The decision is cited as a supporting reference for the principle of retroactive application of decisions, without any negative treatment.

quote: On direct appeal (following Mapp v. Ohio, 367 U. S. 643 (1961)), petitioner claimed that illegally obtained evidence had been introduced against him at trial.
rationale: The decision is referenced only as part of the procedural history to provide context for the petitioner's claim, without substantive legal analysis.

quote: On account of these 'collateral consequences,' the case is not moot. Ginsberg v. New York, 390 U. S. 629, 633-634, n. 2 (1968)
rationale: The decision is cited supportively as authority for the collateral consequences doctrine that prevents mootness, without any criticism or negative treatment.

quote: If there has been, or will be, an unconditional release from custody before inquiry can be made into the legality of detention, it has been held that there is no habeas corpus jurisdiction. See Parker v. Ellis, supra, at 582, n. 8 (WARREN, C. J., dissenting); Ex parte Baez, 177 U. S. 378 (1900)
rationale: The decision is cited as an example of the traditional rule that habeas corpus jurisdiction is lost upon release from custody, but this is presented as background rather than endorsed.

cited_decision: United States Ex Rel. Rivera v. Reeves
quote: If there has been, or will be, an unconditional release from custody before inquiry can be made into the legality of detention, it has been held that there is no habeas corpus jurisdiction. See Parker v. Ellis, supra, at 582, n. 8 (WARREN, C. J., dissenting); Ex parte Baez, 177 U. S. 378 (1900); United States ex rel. Rivera v. Reeves, 246 F. Supp. 599 (D. C. S. D. N. Y. 1965)
rationale: The decision is cited as an example of the traditional rule regarding loss of habeas corpus jurisdiction upon release, presented as background information rather than endorsed.

quote: On account of these 'collateral consequences,' the case is not moot. Ginsberg v. New York, 390 U. S. 629, 633-634, n. 2 (1968); Fiswick v. United States, supra, at 222, n. 10; United States v. Morgan, 346 U. S. 502, 512-513 (1954).
rationale: The decision is cited supportively as authority for the collateral consequences doctrine that prevents mootness, without any negative treatment.

quote: At one point, the new § 2244 (b) (1964 ed., Supp. II) speaks in terms of 'release from custody or other remedy.' See Peyton v. Rowe, supra; Walker v. Wainwright, 390 U. S. 335 (1968).
rationale: The decision is cited as supporting authority for the proposition that habeas corpus relief can include remedies other than immediate release from custody.

cited_decision: Eskridge v. Washington State Board of Prison Terms & Paroles
quote: Although Nowakowski was decided after the Court of Appeals dismissed petitioner's appeal, its holding applies to a habeas corpus proceeding which, like this one, was not concluded at the time Nowakowski was decided. Cf. Eskridge v. Washington Prison Board, 357 U. S. 214 (1958)
rationale: The decision is cited as a supporting reference for the principle of retroactive application of decisions to pending cases, without any negative treatment.

quote: At one point, the new § 2244 (b) (1964 ed., Supp. II) speaks in terms of 'release from custody or other remedy.' See Peyton v. Rowe, supra; Walker v. Wainwright, 390 U. S. 335 (1968). Cf. Ex parte Hull, 312 U. S. 546 (1941).
rationale: The decision is cited as a comparative reference supporting the broad remedial power of habeas corpus courts, without substantive analysis or negative treatment.

quote: In view of the Nardone and Benanti decisions, the doctrine of Schwartz v. Texas cannot survive the demise of Wolf v. Colorado, supra.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the doctrine of Schwartz v. Texas cannot survive, effectively overruling its precedential value regarding the admissibility of intercepted communications in state courts.

quote: That doctrinal underpinning of the Schwartz decision was, of course, completely removed by Mapp v. Ohio, 367 U. S. 643, which overruled Wolf and squarely held that evidence obtained by state officers in an unreasonable search is inadmissible in a state criminal trial.
rationale: The Acting Decision acknowledges that Wolf v. Colorado was overruled by Mapp v. Ohio, removing the doctrinal foundation that previously supported allowing state courts to accept illegally obtained evidence.

quote: In Nardone v. United States, 302 U. S. 379, the Court was first called upon to decide whether § 605 had indeed served to render evidence of intercepted communications inadmissible in a federal trial.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Nardone favorably as establishing the principle that § 605 forbids divulgence of intercepted communications in federal courts, using it as supportive precedent without criticism.

quote: Indeed, evidence obtained by a state officer by means which would constitute an unlawful search and seizure under the Fourth Amendment to the Federal Constitution is nonetheless admissible in a state court, Wolf v. Colorado, 338 U. S. 25, while such evidence, if obtained by a federal officer, would be clearly inadmissible in a federal court. Weeks v. United States, 232 U. S. 383.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Weeks as establishing the exclusionary rule in federal courts for illegally obtained evidence, using it as background precedent without any negative treatment.

quote: But the decision we reach today is not based upon language and doctrinal symmetry alone. It is buttressed as well by the 'imperative of judicial integrity.' Elkins v. United States, 364 U. S. 206, 222.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Elkins favorably to support the principle of judicial integrity and the need for mandatory exclusion of illegal evidence, using it as supportive authority for the court's reasoning.

quote: We overrule McNally and hold that a prisoner serving consecutive sentences is 'in custody' under any one of them for purposes of § 2241 (c)(3).
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it overrules McNally v. Hill, finding that the decision was neither compelled by statute nor history and represents an indefensible barrier to prompt adjudication of constitutional claims.

quote: What we said of the writ in a similar context in Jones v. Cunningham, 371 U. S. 236 (1963), is equally applicable here. '[The writ] is not now and never has been a static, narrow, formalistic remedy; its scope has grown to achieve its grand purpose — the protection of individuals against erosion of their right to be free from wrongful restraints upon their liberty.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Jones v. Cunningham favorably to support its interpretation of the evolving nature of habeas corpus, using it to reinforce the Court's reasoning without any negative treatment.

quote: Third, at least tentatively in Frank v. Mangum, 237 U. S. 309 (1915), and more clearly in Moore v. Dempsey, 261 U. S. 86 (1923), this Court had recognized that a district court was authorized to look behind the bare record of a trial proceeding and conduct a factual hearing to determine the merits of alleged deprivations of constitutional rights
rationale: The Acting Decision references Moore v. Dempsey positively as establishing precedent for factual hearings in habeas corpus proceedings, supporting the Court's analysis of the writ's development without any criticism.

quote: Ex parte Bollman, 4 Cranch 75 (1807); Ex parte Lange, 18 Wall. 163 (1874); Moore v. Dempsey, 261 U. S. 86 (1923); Johnson v. Zerbst, 304 U. S. 458 (1938); Brown v. Allen, 344 U. S. 443 (1953); Fay v. Noia, 372 U. S. 391 (1963).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Fay v. Noia as part of a series of cases that established habeas corpus as a symbol and guardian of individual liberty, referencing it positively without any negative treatment.

quote: We think that neither Shapiro nor the cases upon which it relied are applicable here. Each of the three principal elements of the doctrine, as it is described in Shapiro, is absent from this situation.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Shapiro is not applicable to the current case and distinguishes it by identifying three principal elements of the Shapiro doctrine that are absent from the present situation.

quote: We conclude that nothing in the Court's opinions in Kahriger and Lewis now suffices to preclude petitioner's assertion of the constitutional privilege as a defense to the indictments under which he was convicted. To this extent Kahriger and Lewis are overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Kahriger is overruled to the extent that it would preclude the petitioner's assertion of the Fifth Amendment privilege as a defense.

quote: Neither reason suffices to prevent this petitioner's assertion of the privilege. The first is, as we have indicated, inapplicable, and we find the second unpersuasive in this situation.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Sullivan by finding that the reasoning from Sullivan does not apply to the current case, noting that the circumstances are different and Sullivan's rationale is inapplicable or unpersuasive here.

quote: We conclude that nothing in the Court's opinions in Kahriger and Lewis now suffices to preclude petitioner's assertion of the constitutional privilege as a defense to the indictments under which he was convicted. To this extent Kahriger and Lewis are overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Lewis is overruled to the extent that it would preclude the petitioner's assertion of the Fifth Amendment privilege as a defense.

cited_decision: Albertson v. Subversive Activities Control Board
quote: Every aspect of petitioner's wagering activities thus subjected him to possible state or federal prosecution. By any standard, in Connecticut and throughout the United States, wagering is 'an area permeated with criminal statutes,' and those engaged in wagering are a group 'inherently suspect of criminal activities.' Albertson v. SACB, 382 U. S. 70, 79.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Albertson for the proposition that wagering activities constitute an area permeated with criminal statutes and involve groups inherently suspect of criminal activities, using it as supportive authority without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Murphy v. Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor
quote: It is suggested that these restrictions might be similar to those imposed by the Court in Murphy v. Waterfront Commission, 378 U. S. 52.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Murphy as a potential model for restrictions that could be imposed, but ultimately decides against implementing such restrictions in this case. The citation is merely referential without negative treatment of the decision itself.

quote: In Malloy v. Hogan, supra, the Court rejected Palko's discussion of the self-incrimination clause. Respectfully, we reject the prior dicta regarding jury trial in criminal cases.
rationale: The Court explicitly rejects Palko's dicta regarding jury trial, stating that the observations in Palko about jury trial not being essential to ordered liberty are unsupported by holdings and should be rejected.

quote: The claim before us is that the right to trial by jury guaranteed by the Sixth Amendment meets these tests. The position of Louisiana, on the other hand, is that the Constitution imposes upon the States no duty to give a jury trial in any criminal case, regardless of the seriousness of the crime or the size of the punishment which may be imposed.
rationale: Malloy v. Hogan is cited as establishing the test for determining fundamental rights under the Fourteenth Amendment, without any negative treatment or criticism of the decision itself.

quote: and whether it is 'a fundamental right, essential to a fair trial,' Gideon v. Wainwright, 372 U. S. 335, 343-344 (1963); Malloy v. Hogan, 378 U. S. 1, 6 (1964); Pointer v. Texas, 380 U. S. 400, 403 (1965).
rationale: Pointer v. Texas is cited as one of the cases establishing the test for fundamental rights essential to a fair trial, with no criticism or negative treatment of the decision.

quote: The question has been asked whether a right is among those ' fundamental principles of liberty and justice which lie at the base of all our civil and political institutions, ' Powell v. Alabama, 287 U. S. 45, 67 (1932)
rationale: Powell v. Alabama is cited approvingly as establishing one of the tests for determining whether a right is fundamental under the Fourteenth Amendment, with no negative treatment.

quote: The penalty authorized by the law of the locality may be taken 'as a gauge of its social and ethical judgments,' 300 U. S., at 628 , of the crime in question. In Clawans the defendant was jailed for 60 days, but it was the 90-day authorized punishment on which the Court focused in determining that the offense was not one for which the Constitution assured trial by jury.
rationale: The Court cites Clawans approvingly as guidance for determining the line between petty offenses and serious crimes based on authorized penalties, using it as precedential support.

quote: and whether it is 'a fundamental right, essential to a fair trial,' Gideon v. Wainwright, 372 U. S. 335, 343-344 (1963); Malloy v. Hogan, 378 U. S. 1, 6 (1964); Pointer v. Texas, 380 U. S. 400, 403 (1965).
rationale: Gideon v. Wainwright is cited as establishing the test for fundamental rights essential to a fair trial, with no criticism or negative treatment of the decision.

quote: Maxwell held that no provision of the Bill of Rights applied to the States— a position long since repudiated — and that the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment did not prevent a State from trying a defendant for a noncapital offense with fewer than 12 men on the jury.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that Maxwell's position that no provision of the Bill of Rights applied to the States has been 'long since repudiated,' effectively overruling that aspect of the decision.

quote: See also Irvin v. Dowd, 366 U. S. 717, 721-722 (1961); United States ex rel. Toth v. Quarles, 350 U. S. 11, 16 (1955); Ex parte Milligan, 4 Wall. 2 , 122-123 (1866); People v. Garbutt, 17 Mich. 9, 27 (1868).
rationale: Irvin v. Dowd is cited in a string citation supporting the historical importance of jury trial, with no negative treatment or criticism of the decision.

quote: Only last Term we found that the right to trial by jury in criminal cases was 'fundamental to the American scheme of justice,' Duncan v. Louisiana, 391 U. S. 145, 149 (1968), and held that the Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial was applicable to the States through the Fourteenth Amendment.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Duncan v. Louisiana as supportive precedent for applying Bill of Rights guarantees to the States, using it to establish the framework for finding double jeopardy protections fundamental and applicable to states.

quote: Insofar as it is inconsistent with this holding, Palko v. Connecticut is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly overrules Palko v. Connecticut, stating that it represented an approach to constitutional rights that the Court's recent decisions have rejected, and that its 'watered-down' approach to applying Bill of Rights protections to states is no longer valid.

quote: This argument was answered here over 70 years ago in United States v. Ball, 163 U. S. 662 (1896). In that case Millard Fillmore Ball was indicted, together with two other men, for the murder of one William T. Box in the Indian Territory. He was acquitted and his codefendants were convicted.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites United States v. Ball as controlling precedent that supports petitioner's double jeopardy claim, using it to establish that a defendant cannot be retried after acquittal even when the original indictment was technically defective.

quote: In Sibron v. New York, 392 U. S. 40 (1968), we held that a criminal case did not become moot upon the expiration of the sentence imposed. We noted 'the obvious fact of life that most criminal convictions do in fact entail adverse collateral legal consequences.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Sibron v. New York to establish that criminal cases remain justiciable even when sentences have expired due to potential collateral consequences, supporting the Court's jurisdiction to hear the case despite concurrent sentences.

quote: In an increasing number of cases, the Court 'has rejected the notion that the Fourteenth Amendment applies to the States only a "watered-down, subjective version of the individual guarantees of the Bill of Rights ...."' Malloy v. Hogan, 378 U. S. 1, 10-11 (1964)
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Malloy v. Hogan as part of the line of precedent supporting the incorporation of Bill of Rights protections against the states, using it to build the foundation for applying the Double Jeopardy Clause to state proceedings.

quote: But in Dennis v. United States, 341 U. S. 494 , we opened wide the door, distorting the 'clear and present danger' test beyond recognition.
rationale: The concurring opinion explicitly criticizes Dennis for distorting the clear and present danger test and describes it as making the trial an 'all-out political trial which was part and parcel of the cold war that has eroded substantial parts of the First Amendment.'

quote: The Court in Herndon v. Lowry, 301 U. S. 242 , overturned a conviction for exercising First Amendment rights to incite insurrection because of lack of evidence of incitement.
rationale: The decision is referenced positively as an example of proper application of First Amendment principles, but without any negative treatment or criticism of the cited decision itself.

quote: Advocacy and teaching of forcible overthrow of government as an abstract principle is immune from prosecution. Yates v. United States, 354 U. S. 298, 318 .
rationale: The decision is cited approvingly as establishing the principle that abstract advocacy is protected speech, without any criticism or negative treatment.

quote: Frohwerk v. United States, 249 U. S. 204 , also authored by Mr. Justice Holmes, involved prosecution and punishment for publication of articles very critical of the war effort in World War I.
rationale: The decision is mentioned as part of the historical development of the clear and present danger test during World War I, without expressing approval or disapproval of the decision itself.

quote: Debs v. United States, 249 U. S. 211 , was the third of the trilogy of the 1918 Term. Debs was convicted of speaking in opposition to the war where his 'opposition was so expressed that its natural and intended effect would be to obstruct recruiting.'
rationale: The decision is mentioned as part of the World War I trilogy of cases that established the clear and present danger test, without expressing criticism or approval of the specific decision.

quote: The contrary teaching of Whitney v. California, supra, cannot be supported, and that decision is therefore overruled.
rationale: The lead opinion explicitly states that Whitney v. California is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value regarding the constitutionality of criminal syndicalism statutes.

quote: Rabinowitz and Harris have been the subject of critical commentary for many years, and have been relied upon less and less in our own decisions. It is time, for the reasons we have stated, to hold that on their own facts, and insofar as the principles they stand for are inconsistent with those that we have endorsed today, they are no longer to be followed.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that Rabinowitz is no longer to be followed insofar as its principles are inconsistent with the new rule established in Chimel, effectively overruling it.

quote: Since that time, the rule of Weeks, Marron, Harris, and Rabinowitz has clearly been the law. E. g., Abel v. United States, 362 U. S. 217 (1960) (Frankfurter, J., writing for the Court) ; Ker v. California, 374 U. S. 23 (1963).
rationale: The case is merely cited as an example of decisions that followed the Rabinowitz rule, without any critical analysis or negative treatment by the Acting Decision.

quote: Since that time, the rule of Weeks, Marron, Harris, and Rabinowitz has clearly been the law. E. g., Abel v. United States, 362 U. S. 217 (1960) (Frankfurter, J., writing for the Court) ; Ker v. California, 374 U. S. 23 (1963).
rationale: The case is merely cited as an example of decisions that followed the Rabinowitz rule, without any critical analysis or negative treatment by the Acting Decision.

quote: Approval of a warrantless search incident to a lawful arrest seems first to have been articulated by the Court in 1914 as dictum in Weeks v. United States, 232 U. S. 383, in which the Court stated: 'What then is the present case? Before answering that inquiry specifically, it may be well by a process of exclusion to state what it is not. It is not an assertion of the right on the part of the Government, always recognized under English and American law, to search the person of the accused when legally arrested to discover and seize the fruits or evidences of crime.'
rationale: The Court discusses Weeks as the historical starting point for search incident to arrest doctrine, providing context without criticizing or overruling the decision.

quote: Only a year after Harris, however, the pendulum swung again. In Trupiano v. United States, 334 U. S. 699, agents raided the site of an illicit distillery, saw one of several conspirators operating the still, and arrested him, contemporaneously 'seiz[ing] the illicit distillery.' Id., at 702. The Court held that the arrest and others made subsequently had been valid, but that the unexplained failure of the agents to procure a search warrant — in spite of the fact that they had had more than enough time before the raid to do so — rendered the search unlawful.
rationale: The Court discusses Trupiano as part of the historical development of search incident to arrest doctrine, noting how it was later overruled by Rabinowitz, without expressing any negative treatment toward Trupiano itself.

quote: And in Marron v. United States, 275 U. S. 192, two years later, the dictum of Agnello appeared to be the foundation of the Court's decision. In that case federal agents had secured a search, warrant authorizing the seizure of liquor and certain articles used in its manufacture.
rationale: The Court discusses Marron as part of the historical development of search incident to arrest doctrine, explaining how it expanded the scope of searches, without expressing criticism or negative treatment.

cited_decision: Go-Bart Importing Co. v. United States
quote: That the Marron opinion did not mean all that it seemed to say became evident, however, a few years later in Go-Bart Importing Co. v. United States, 282 U. S. 344, and United States v. Lefkowitz, 285 U. S. 452. In each of those cases the opinion of the Court was written by Mr. Justice Butler, the author of the opinion in Marron.
rationale: The Court discusses Go-Bart as part of the historical development showing how it limited the Marron decision, without expressing any negative treatment toward Go-Bart itself.

quote: Only last Term in Terry v. Ohio, 392 U. S. 1, we emphasized that 'the police must, whenever practicable, obtain advance judicial approval of searches and seizures through the warrant procedure,' id., at 20, and that '[t]he scope of [a] search must be 'strictly tied to and justified by' the circumstances which rendered its initiation permissible.'
rationale: The Court cites Terry favorably to support its reasoning about the warrant requirement and the need for searches to be strictly tied to their justifying circumstances.

quote: Eleven years later the case of Carroll v. United States, 267 U. S. 132, brought the following embellishment of the Weeks statement: 'When a man is legally arrested for an offense, whatever is found upon his person or in his control which it is unlawful for him to have and which may be used to prove the offense may be seized and held as evidence in the prosecution.'
rationale: The Court discusses Carroll as part of the historical development of search incident to arrest doctrine, showing how it expanded upon Weeks, without expressing any negative treatment.

quote: Rabinowitz and Harris have been the subject of critical commentary for many years, and have been relied upon less and less in our own decisions. It is time, for the reasons we have stated, to hold that on their own facts, and insofar as the principles they stand for are inconsistent with those that we have endorsed today, they are no longer to be followed.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that Harris is no longer to be followed insofar as its principles are inconsistent with the new rule established in Chimel, effectively overruling it.

quote: Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U. S. 533 , held that a State in an apportionment of state representatives and senators among districts and counties could not deprive voters in the more populous counties of their proportionate share of representatives and senators. 'The right to vote freely for the candidate of one's choice is of the essence of a democratic society, and any restrictions on that right strike at the heart of representative government. And the right of suffrage can be denied by a debasement or dilution of the weight of a citizen's vote just as effectively as by wholly prohibiting the free exercise of the franchise.' 377 U. S., at 555.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Reynolds v. Sims favorably to support its reasoning about equal protection and voting rights, using it as precedential authority without any negative treatment.

quote: We have said enough to indicate why MacDougall v. Green is out of line with our recent apportionment cases... MacDougall v. Green is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that MacDougall v. Green is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value after finding it inconsistent with recent apportionment cases.

quote: Dusch v. Davis, 387 U. S. 112 , is not relevant to the problem of this case. There each councilman was required to be a resident of the borough from which he was elected. Like the residence requirement for state senators from a multi-district county (Fortson v. Dorsey, 379 U. S. 433 ), the place of residence did not mark the voting unit; for in Dusch all the electors in the city voted for each councilman.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Dusch v. Davis is not relevant to the current case and explains the factual differences that make it distinguishable from the present situation.

quote: While the majority cited Colegrove v. Green, 328 U. S. 549 , as their authority for denying relief and while a few who took part in Colegrove put this type of question in the 'political' as distinguished from the 'justiciable' category, 328 U. S., at 552 , that matter was authoritatively resolved in Baker v. Carr, 369 U. S. 186, 202.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Colegrove v. Green in the context of explaining how the justiciability issue it raised was later resolved by Baker v. Carr, without directly criticizing or overruling it.

quote: that matter was authoritatively resolved in Baker v. Carr, 369 U. S. 186, 202 . When a State makes classifications of voters which favor residents of some counties over residents of other counties, a justiciable controversy is presented. 369 U. S., at 198-204.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Baker v. Carr favorably as having authoritatively resolved the justiciability question and establishing that voter classification cases present justiciable controversies.

quote: Whatever the present validity of the position taken by the majority on that issue — a question rendered largely academic by Title II of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 78 Stat. 243 (see Heart of Atlanta Motel v. United States, 379 U. S. 241 ; Katzenbach v. McClung, 379 U. S. 294 ) — we note that the entire Court agreed upon at least one proposition: .The Thirteenth Amendment authorizes Congress not only to outlaw all forms of slavery and involuntary servitude but also to eradicate the last vestiges and incidents of a society half slave and half free, by securing to all citizens, of every race and color, 'the same right to make and enforce contracts, to sue, be parties, give evidence, and to inherit, purchase, lease, sell and convey property, as is enjoyed by white citizens.'
rationale: The Court distinguishes the Civil Rights Cases by noting that while the earlier case dealt with public accommodations, the entire Court in that case agreed that the Thirteenth Amendment authorizes Congress to secure property rights for all citizens, which supports the Court's interpretation of § 1982.

quote: The basic source of the injury in Hurd was, of course, the action of private individuals — white citizens who had agreed to exclude Negroes from a residential area. But an arm of the Government — in that case, a federal court — had assisted in the enforcement of that agreement. Thus Hurd v. Hodge, supra, did not present the question whether purely private discrimination, unaided by any action on the part of government, would violate § 1982 if its effect were to deny a citizen the right to rent or buy property solely because of his race or color.
rationale: The Court distinguishes Hurd v. Hodge by noting that while it involved private discrimination, it also involved governmental assistance through judicial enforcement, whereas the present case involves purely private discrimination without any governmental involvement.

quote: The conclusion of the majority in Hodges rested upon a concept of congressional power under the Thirteenth Amendment irreconcilable with the position taken by every member of this Court in the Civil Rights Cases and incompatible with the history and purpose of the Amendment itself. Insofar as Hodges is inconsistent with our holding today, it is hereby overruled.
rationale: The Court explicitly overrules Hodges v. United States, stating that its narrow interpretation of the Thirteenth Amendment is incompatible with the Amendment's history and purpose and inconsistent with the Court's current holding.

quote: Even if Corrigan should be regarded as an adjudication that 42 U. S. C. § 1982 (then § 1978 of the Revised Statutes) does not prohibit private individuals from agreeing not to sell their property to Negroes, Corrigan would not settle the question whether § 1982 prohibits an actual refusal to sell to a Negro. Moreover, since the appellants in Corrigan had not even argued in this Court that the statute prohibited private agreements of the sort there involved, it would be a mistake to treat the Corrigan decision as a considered judgment even on that narrow issue.
rationale: The Court distinguishes Corrigan v. Buckley by noting that even if it held that § 1982 doesn't prohibit private agreements not to sell to Negroes, it doesn't address whether § 1982 prohibits actual refusals to sell, and the decision wasn't a considered judgment on the statutory interpretation issue.

quote: Two of this Court's early opinions contain dicta to the general effect that § 1982 is limited to state action. Virginia v. Rives, 100 U. S. 313, 317-318 ; Civil Rights Cases, 109 U. S. 3 , 16-17. But all that Virginia v. Rives, supra, actually held was that § 641 of the Revised Statutes of 1874 (derived from § 3 of the Civil Rights Act of 1866 and currently embodied in 28 U. S. C. § 1443 (1)) did not authorize the removal of a state prosecution where the defendants, without pointing to any statute discriminating against Negroes, could only assert that a denial of their rights might take place and might go uncorrected at trial.
rationale: The Court distinguishes Virginia v. Rives by clarifying that its statements about § 1982 being limited to state action were merely dicta, and the case actually held something much narrower about removal of state prosecutions under a different statutory provision.

quote: The judgment of the Supreme Court of California is vacated and the case is remanded to that court for further proceedings not inconsistent with this opinion.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly overturns the outcome of the California Supreme Court's decision in favor of Adkins, vacating the judgment and remanding for proceedings consistent with the new ruling that overrules licensee estoppel.

cited_decision: Compco Corp. v. Day-Brite Lighting, Inc. (1964)
quote: We granted certiorari in the present case, 391 U. S. 912 , to reconsider the validity of the Hazeltine rule in the light of our recent decisions emphasizing the strong federal policy favoring free competition in ideas which do not merit patent protection. Sears, Roebuck v. Stiffel Co., 376 U. S. 225 (1964); Compco Corp. v. Day-Brite Lighting, Inc., 376 U. S. 234 (1964).
rationale: The Cited Decision is referenced as supporting precedent for the federal policy favoring free competition in ideas, without any criticism or limitation of its holding.

cited_decision: Automatic Radio Manufacturing Co. v. Hazeltine Research, Inc (1950)
quote: We are satisfied that Automatic Radio Manufacturing Co. v. Hazeltine Research, Inc., supra, itself the product of a clouded history, should no longer be regarded as sound law with respect to its 'estoppel' holding, and that holding is now overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly nullifies the estoppel holding of the Cited Decision, stating it should no longer be regarded as sound law and explicitly overruling it.

cited_decision: Sears, Roebuck & Co. v. Stiffel Co. (1964)
quote: We granted certiorari in the present case, 391 U. S. 912 , to reconsider the validity of the Hazeltine rule in the light of our recent decisions emphasizing the strong federal policy favoring free competition in ideas which do not merit patent protection. Sears, Roebuck v. Stiffel Co., 376 U. S. 225 (1964); Compco Corp. v. Day-Brite Lighting, Inc., 376 U. S. 234 (1964).
rationale: The Cited Decision is referenced as supporting precedent for the federal policy favoring free competition in ideas, without any criticism or limitation of its holding.

cited_decision: Westinghouse Electric & Manufacturing Co. v. Formica Insulation Co. (1924)
quote: Workable or not, the result proved to be an anomaly: if a patent had some novelty Formica permitted the old owner to defend an infringement action by showing that the invention's novel aspects did not extend to the inclusion of the old owner's products; on the other hand, if a patent had no novelty at all, the old owner could not defend successfully since he would be obliged to launch the direct attack on the patent that Formica seemed to forbid. The incongruity of this position compelled at least one court of appeals to carry the reasoning of the Formica exception to its logical conclusion.
rationale: The Acting Decision criticizes the Cited Decision as creating an anomalous and incongruous result that undermined the basis of patent estoppel doctrine.

cited_decision: Scott Paper Co. v. Marcalus Manufacturing Co. (1945)
quote: In Scott Paper Co. v. Marcalus Manufacturing Co., 326 U. S. 249 (1945), this Court adopted a position similar to the Seventh Circuit's, undermining the basis of patent estoppel even more than Formica had done.
rationale: The Cited Decision is referenced as part of the historical development that undermined patent estoppel doctrine, but without direct criticism of its reasoning or result.

quote: In McGoldrick v. Compagnie Generale Transatlantique, 309 U. S. 430 (1940), the Court, while recognizing it had jurisdiction to determine whether a New York tax was an unconstitutional burden on interstate commerce, refused to consider whether the tax was a prohibited impost or duty on imports and exports
rationale: The Cited Decision is referenced as precedent for the principle that courts should decline to consider questions not urged or considered in lower courts, without any criticism of its holding.

quote: Wilson v. Cook, 327 U. S. 474 (1946), reached a similar conclusion. There the Court denied a government contractor the benefit of the implied constitutional immunity of the Federal Government from taxation by the State, but at the same time declined to consider whether the state tax at issue placed a forbidden tax directly on the United States.
rationale: The Cited Decision is referenced as supporting precedent for the principle that courts should not consider grounds not presented to or decided by lower courts, without any criticism.

quote: This possibility and others serve to indicate the wisdom of refraining from any pronouncement now, and particularly from any rigid line drawing, in advance of consideration by the courts below and by the parties. Cf. Brulotte v. Thys Co., 379 U. S. 29, 31 (1964).
rationale: The Cited Decision is briefly referenced in the concurring opinion as a comparison point regarding post-patent royalties, without any substantive discussion or criticism of its holding.

quote: Having concluded that Sinclair was erroneously decided and that subsequent events have undermined its continuing validity, we overrule that decision and reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Sinclair was erroneously decided and overrules that decision, directly nullifying its precedential value.

cited_decision: Textile Workers v. Lincoln Mills of Ala.
quote: Lincoln Mills held generally that 'the substantive law to apply in suits under § 301 (a) is federal law, which the courts must fashion from the policy of our national labor laws,' 353 U. S., at 456, and more specifically that a union can obtain specific performance of an employer's promise to arbitrate grievances.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Lincoln Mills to explain established precedent regarding federal labor law and arbitration, without criticizing or questioning its validity.

cited_decision: Avco Corp. v. Aero Lodge No. 735, International Ass'n of MacHinists & Aerospace Workers
quote: Furthermore, in light of developments subsequent to Sinclair, in particular our decision in Avco Corp. v. Aero Lodge 735, 390 U. S. 557 (1968), it has become clear that the Sinclair decision does not further but rather frustrates realization of an important goal of our national labor policy.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Avco as a subsequent development that undermined Sinclair, but does not criticize Avco itself; rather uses it as support for overruling Sinclair.

quote: [S]tare decisis is a principle of policy and not a mechanical formula of adherence to the latest decision, however recent and questionable, when such adherence involves collision with a prior doctrine more embracing in its scope, intrinsically sounder, and verified by experience.
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes Helvering v. Hallock to support its position on when stare decisis should not prevent reconsideration of precedent, using it as authority without any negative treatment.

quote: The rationale of the Green holding applies here. The concept of continuing jeopardy implicit in the Ball case would allow petitioner's retrial for voluntary manslaughter after his first conviction for that offense had been reversed. But, as the Kepner and Green cases illustrate, this Court has consistently refused to rule that jeopardy for an offense continues after an acquittal, whether that acquittal is express or implied by a conviction on a lesser included offense when the jury was given a full opportunity to return a verdict on the greater charge.
rationale: The Acting Decision applies the rationale from Green v. United States to support its holding, treating it as controlling precedent without criticism or limitation.

quote: The Georgia Court of Appeals then heard the appeal and affirmed the second conviction, rejecting petitioner's argument, among others, that his retrial for murder constituted double jeopardy... We granted the writ, 395 U. S. 975 (1969), and now reverse.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly overturns the Georgia Court of Appeals decision that affirmed petitioner's second conviction, explicitly stating 'and now reverse.'

quote: While the Brantley holding may have had some vitality at the time the Georgia courts rendered their decisions in this case, it is no longer a viable authority and must now be deemed to have been overruled by subsequent decisions of this Court.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Brantley is no longer viable authority and must be deemed overruled by subsequent Supreme Court decisions.

quote: In United States v. Ball, 163 U. S. 662, 669 (1896), this Court observed: 'The Constitution of the United States, in the Fifth Amendment, declares, 'nor shall any person be subject [for the same offense] to be twice put in jeopardy of life or limb.' The prohibition is not against being twice punished, but against being twice put in jeopardy . . . .'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Ball to establish foundational principles about double jeopardy without criticizing or limiting its precedential value.

quote: but that court transferred the case to the Court of Appeals of Georgia, declaring that '[o]nly questions as to the application of plain and unambiguous provisions of the Constitution of the United States being involved, . . the case is one for the consideration of the Court of Appeals . . . Price v. State, 224 Ga. 306, 307 , 161 S. E. 2d 825, 826 (1968).
rationale: The Acting Decision merely references this procedural decision by the Georgia Supreme Court to transfer the case without any substantive treatment or analysis.

cited_decision: United States ex rel. Hetenyi v. Wilkins
quote: Further, and perhaps of more importance, we cannot determine whether or not the murder charge against petitioner induced the jury to find him guilty of the less serious offense of voluntary manslaughter rather than to continue to debate his innocence. See United States ex rel. Hetenyi v. Wilkins, 348 F. 2d 844 (C. A. 2d Cir. 1965), cert. denied, 383 U. S. 913 (1966).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Hetenyi v. Wilkins as supporting authority for the proposition that murder charges may influence jury verdicts on lesser offenses, without any negative treatment.

quote: The doctrine of Benton v. Maryland, 395 U. S. 784 , puts the issues in the present case in a perspective quite different from that in which the issues were perceived in Hoag v. New Jersey, supra. The question is no longer whether collateral estoppel is a requirement of due process, but whether it is a part of the Fifth Amendment's guarantee against double jeopardy.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Hoag by explaining that the constitutional framework has changed since Benton v. Maryland, making the analysis different from what was applied in Hoag, even though the factual circumstances are virtually identical.

quote: The two prosecutions, the first for the robbery of Knight and the second for the robbery of Roberts, grew out of one criminal episode, and therefore I think it clear on the facts of this case that the Double Jeopardy Clause prohibited Missouri from prosecuting petitioner for each robbery at a different trial. Abbate v. United States, 359 U. S. 187, 196-201 (1959) (separate opinion).
rationale: The concurring opinion references Abbate to support the position that prosecutions arising from a single criminal episode should be barred, but does not criticize or question the precedential value of the decision.

quote: For whatever else that constitutional guarantee may embrace, North Carolina v. Pearce, 395 U. S. 711, 717 , it surely protects a man who has been acquitted from having to 'run the gantlet' a second time.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Pearce as support for the broader principle of double jeopardy protection without any negative treatment or criticism of the decision.

quote: In Benton v. Maryland, 395 U. S. 784 , the Court held that the Fifth Amendment guarantee against double jeopardy is enforceable against the States through the Fourteenth Amendment.
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on Benton as the foundational precedent that makes the Fifth Amendment's double jeopardy guarantee applicable to state proceedings, treating it as established controlling law.

quote: For whatever else that constitutional guarantee may embrace, North Carolina v. Pearce, 395 U. S. 711, 717 , it surely protects a man who has been acquitted from having to 'run the gantlet' a second time. Green v. United States, 355 U. S. 184, 190 .
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Green favorably to support the principle that the double jeopardy guarantee protects against having to 'run the gantlet' a second time, using it as supportive authority without any negative treatment.

quote: The constitutionality of § 1985 (3) might once have appeared to have been settled adversely by United States v. Harris, 106 U. S. 629 , and Baldwin v. Franks, 120 U. S. 678 , which held unconstitutional its criminal counterpart, then § 5519 of the Revised Statutes.
