The Court in those cases, however, followed a severability rule that required invalidation of an entire statute if any part of it was unconstitutionally overbroad, unless its different parts could be read as wholly independent provisions. This Court has long since firmly rejected that rule in such cases as United States v. Raines, 362 U. S. 17, 20-24 .
rationale: The Court distinguishes Harris by explaining that the severability rule applied in that case has been rejected, allowing the current Court to uphold § 1985(3) even if some applications might be unconstitutional.

quote: Our cases have firmly established that the right of interstate travel is constitutionally protected, does not necessarily rest on the Fourteenth Amendment, and is assertable against private as well as governmental interference. Shapiro v. Thompson, 394 U. S. 618, 629-631 ; id., at 642-644 (concurring opinion); United States v. Guest, 383 U. S. 745 , 757-760 and n. 17
rationale: The Court cites Guest as supportive authority for the proposition that the right of interstate travel is constitutionally protected and can be asserted against private interference, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Jones v. Alfred H. Mayer Co.
quote: The approach of this Court to other Reconstruction civil rights statutes in the years since Collins has been to 'accord [them] a sweep as broad as [their] language.' United States v. Price, 383 U. S. 787, 801 ; Jones v. Alfred H. Mayer Co., 392 U. S. 409, 437 .
rationale: The Court cites Jones favorably as support for giving civil rights statutes broad interpretation, and later relies on it for Thirteenth Amendment authority without any criticism or limitation.

quote: The 'right to pass freely from State to State' has been explicitly recognized as 'among the rights and privileges of National citizenship.' Twining v. New Jersey, supra, at 97 . That right, like other rights of national citizenship, is within the power of Congress to protect by appropriate legislation.
rationale: The Court cites Twining as supportive authority for the principle that interstate travel is a right of national citizenship that Congress can protect, without any negative treatment.

quote: Whether or not Collins v. Hardyman was correctly decided on its own facts is a question with which we need not here be concerned. But it is clear, in the light of the evolution of decisional law in the years that have passed since that case was decided, that many of the constitutional problems there perceived simply do not exist. Little reason remains, therefore, not to accord to the words of the statute their apparent meaning.
rationale: The Court significantly narrows the scope and applicability of Collins by explaining that constitutional developments have eliminated the problems that led to its restrictive interpretation, effectively limiting its precedential value.

quote: We can no longer adhere to the aberrational doctrine of Kesler and Reitz that state law may frustrate the operation of federal law as long as the state legislature in passing its law had some purpose in mind other than one of frustration.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states it can no longer adhere to the doctrine of Reitz and characterizes it as 'aberrational,' directly overruling the precedential value of the Cited Decision.

quote: In Schecter v. Killingsworth, 93 Ariz. 273, 380 P. 2d 136 (1963), the Supreme Court of Arizona held that [t]he Financial Responsibility Act has for its principal purpose the protection of the public using the highways from financial hardship which may result from the use of automobiles by financially irresponsible persons.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Schecter to establish the Arizona Supreme Court's construction of the state statute's purpose, using it as authoritative precedent without criticism or negative treatment.

quote: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed and the case is remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly reverses the Court of Appeals judgment in the same case, directly overturning the lower court's ruling.

cited_decision: Kesler v. Department of Public Safety of Utah
quote: We can no longer adhere to the aberrational doctrine of Kesler and Reitz that state law may frustrate the operation of federal law as long as the state legislature in passing its law had some purpose in mind other than one of frustration.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states it can no longer adhere to the doctrine of Kesler and characterizes it as 'aberrational,' directly overruling the precedential value of the Cited Decision.

quote: There can be no doubt, given Lewis v. Roberts, 267 U. S. 467 (1925), that Congress intended this 'new opportunity' to include freedom from most kinds of pre-existing tort judgments.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Lewis v. Roberts as supportive authority for the proposition that Congress intended bankruptcy discharge to provide freedom from pre-existing tort judgments, without any negative treatment.

quote: In view of these developments since Ahrens v. Clark, we can no longer view that decision as establishing an inflexible jurisdictional rule, dictating the choice of an inconvenient forum even in a class of cases which could not have been foreseen at the time of our decision.
rationale: The Court explicitly narrows the scope and applicability of Ahrens v. Clark by stating it cannot be viewed as establishing an inflexible jurisdictional rule, thereby limiting its precedential value and authority.

quote: alleging denial of his constitutional right to a speedy trial, Smith v. Hooey, 393 U. S. 374 (1969), and praying that an order issue directing respondent to afford him an immediate trial on a then three-year-old Kentucky indictment.
rationale: The Court references Smith v. Hooey as establishing the constitutional right to a speedy trial that forms the basis of petitioner's claim, without criticizing or limiting the decision's precedential value.

quote: Prior to our decision in Peyton v. Rowe, 391 U. S. 54 (1968), the 'prematurity doctrine' of McNally v. Hill, 293 U. S. 131 (1934), would, of course, have barred his petition for relief. But our decision in Peyton v. Rowe discarded the prematurity doctrine
rationale: The Court cites Peyton v. Rowe favorably as the decision that discarded the prematurity doctrine and enabled the current action, providing additional clarification of its application without questioning its precedential value.

quote: It is also true, as our Brother Rehnquist points out in dissent, that federal habeas corpus does not lie, absent 'special circumstances,' to adjudicate the merits of an affirmative defense to a state criminal charge prior to a judgment of conviction by a state court. Ex parte Royall, 117 U. S. 241, 253 (1886). Petitioner does not, however, seek at this time to litigate a federal defense to a criminal charge, but only to demand enforcement of the Commonwealth's affirmative constitutional obligation to bring him promptly to trial.
rationale: The Court distinguishes Ex Parte Royall by explaining that the current case involves different facts - petitioner is not seeking to litigate a defense but to enforce the state's obligation to provide a speedy trial, thus requiring a different application of the law.

quote: Nor does petitioner challenge the 'present effect being given the [Kentucky] detainer by the [Alabama] authorities . . . .' Nelson v. George, 399 U. S. 224, 225 (1970).
rationale: The Court references Nelson v. George to clarify what petitioner is not challenging in this case, using it for additional clarification without affecting its precedential value.

cited_decision: Carmichael v. Southern Coal & Coke Co.
quote: Thus, in Carmichael v. Southern Coal Co., 301 U. S. 495 , the Court, in sustaining an unemployment tax on employers, said: 'A state legislature, in the enactment of laws, has the widest possible latitude within the limits of the Constitution. In the nature of the case it cannot record a complete catalogue of, the considerations which move its members to enact laws. In the absence of such a record courts cannot assume that its action is capricious, or that, with its informed acquaintance with local conditions to which the legis lation is to be applied, it was not aware of facts which afford reasonable basis for its action. Only by faithful adherence to this guiding principle of judicial review of legislation is it possible to preserve to the legislative branch its rightful independence and its ability to function.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Carmichael favorably to support the principle that courts should defer to legislative judgment in taxation matters, using it as precedential authority without criticism or limitation.

cited_decision: Lake Shore Auto Parts Co. v. Korzen
quote: All respondents in both cases appealed to the Illinois Supreme Court, which held that Art. IX-A did not affect all forms of real and personal property taxes but only personal property taxes on individuals, which it construed to mean 'ad valorem taxation of personal property owned by a natural person or by two or more natural persons as joint tenants or tenants in common.' 49 Ill. 2d 137, 148 , 273 N. E. 2d 592, 597 . As so construed, the Illinois Supreme Court held that the tax violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly overturns the Illinois Supreme Court's ruling that found the tax violated the Equal Protection Clause, as evidenced by the final word 'Reversed' in the opinion.

cited_decision: Madden v. Kentucky Ex Rel. Commissioner
quote: In Madden v. Kentucky, 309 U. S. 83 , a State laid an ad valorem tax of 50$ per $100 on deposits in banks outside the State and only 10(i per $1,000 on deposits within the State. The classification was sustained against the charge of invidious discrimination, the Court noting that 'in taxation, even more than in other fields, legislatures possess the greatest freedom in classification.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Madden favorably as precedential support for the principle that legislatures have great freedom in tax classification and that there is a presumption of constitutionality.

quote: Each of these dissenters thought Flint v. Stone Tracy Co., 220 U. S. 107 , should govern Quaker City Cab. The Flint case involved a federal tax upon the privilege of doing business in a corporate capacity, but it was not laid on businesses carried on by a partnership or private individual.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Flint as precedent that supports differential taxation between corporations and individuals, citing it favorably for the principle that corporations have distinctive privileges that justify separate tax treatment.

cited_decision: Quaker City Cab Co. v. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania
quote: Quaker City Cab Co. v. Pennsylvania is only a relic of a bygone era. We cannot follow it and stay within the narrow confines of judicial review, which is an important part of our constitutional tradition.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly declares that Quaker City Cab is 'only a relic of a bygone era' and states they 'cannot follow it,' effectively overruling its precedential value.

cited_decision: Louis K. Liggett Co. v. Baldridge
quote: The Liggett case, being a derelict in the stream of the law, is hereby overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the Liggett case is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value and characterizing it as inconsistent with current constitutional doctrine.

quote: Mills v. Alabama, 384 U. S. 214 , involved the constitutionality of a state statute in effect making it a crime for a newspaper editor on election day to urge people to vote a certain way on the issues being submitted. The state court held the act did not violate the Federal Constitution and remanded the case for trial. It was argued that the judgment was not 'final' for purposes of 28 U. S. C. § 1257 . We noted that the point had 'a surface plausibility, since it is true the judgment of the State Supreme Court did not literally end the case.' 384 U. S., at 217 . We held it 'final,' however, because if the Act were constitutional the editor wbuld in reality have no defense.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Mills v. Alabama as precedent supporting the finality analysis without any criticism or limitation, using it to support the court's reasoning on jurisdictional requirements.

quote: The exceptions noted have a long lineage dating back to Mr. Chief Justice Taney's opinion in Forgay v. Conrad, 6 How. 201 , where the Court held 'final' an interlocutory decree requiring a litigant 'to deliver up property which he claims,' even though a final accounting has yet to be made.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Forgay v. Conrad as historical precedent establishing exceptions to the finality requirement, referencing it neutrally to trace the lineage of the legal doctrine without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Radio Station Wow, Inc. v. Johnson
quote: Mr. Justice Frankfurter, writing for the Court in Radio Station WOW v. Johnson, 326 U. S. 120, 124 , summarized the requirement by Congress that in appeals from federal district courts as well as in review of state court decisions the judgments be 'final': 'This requirement has the support of considerations generally applicable to good judicial administration.'
rationale: The Acting Decision references Radio Station WOW v. Johnson as authoritative precedent explaining the finality requirement, quoting it approvingly to support the court's jurisdictional analysis without any criticism or limitation.

quote: In Duncan v. Louisiana, 391 U. S. 145 (1968), we held that the Fourteenth Amendment guarantees a right to trial by jury in all criminal cases that — were they to be tried in a federal court — would come within the Sixth Amendment's guarantee.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Duncan v. Louisiana as establishing precedent for the right to jury trial, using it as foundational authority without criticizing or questioning its validity.

quote: The leading case so construing the Sixth Amendment is Thompson v. Utah, 170 U. S. 343 (1898)... Noticeably absent was any discussion of the essential step in the argument: namely, that every feature of the jury as it existed at common law — whether incidental or essential to that institution — was necessarily included in the Constitution wherever that document referred to a 'jury.'
rationale: The Acting Decision criticizes Thompson v. Utah for its lack of analysis and reasoning, pointing out that it made assumptions without proper justification for equating constitutional and common-law characteristics of juries.

quote: See Capital Traction Co. v. Hof, 174 U. S. 1, 13-14 (1899); American Publishing Co. v. Fisher, 166 U. S. 464, 468 (1897).
rationale: The Acting Decision merely cites Capital Traction Co. v. Hof as an example of cases that interpret Seventh Amendment jury trial provisions, without significant discussion or analysis.

quote: Given Malloy v. Hogan, 378 U. S. 1 (1964), I join that part of the Court's opinion in No. 927 relating to the Florida 'alibi' procedure.
rationale: Justice Harlan references Malloy v. Hogan as a basis for joining part of the Court's opinion regarding the alibi procedure, treating it as established precedent without criticism.

quote: See Patton v. United States, 281 U. S. 276, 288 (1930); Rassmussen v. United States, 197 U. S. 516, 519 (1905); Maxwell v. Dow, 176 U. S. 581, 586 (1900).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Rassmussen v. United States as one of several cases that reaffirmed the 12-person jury requirement, without significant analysis or criticism of the decision itself.

quote: It is to the distinction between 'petty' and 'serious' offenses, rooted in the common law, that this Court has looked to ascertain the metes and bounds of the federal right guaranteed by the Sixth Amendment. See District of Columbia v. Clawans, 300 U. S. 617 (1937); Schick v. United States, 195 U. S. 65 (1904); Callan v. Wilson, 127 U. S. 540, 552 (1888).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Callan v. Wilson as precedent for distinguishing between petty and serious offenses in determining jury trial rights, treating it as established authority.

quote: In Ker v. California, 374 U. S. 23 (1963), I noted in an opinion concurring in the result that: 'The rule [of 'incorporation'] is unwise because the States, with their differing law enforcement problems, should not be put in a constitutional strait jacket....'
rationale: Justice Harlan references his own concurring opinion in Ker v. California to support his argument against the incorporation doctrine, using it as precedent for his position without criticizing the case itself.

quote: It is to the distinction between 'petty' and 'serious' offenses, rooted in the common law, that this Court has looked to ascertain the metes and bounds of the federal right guaranteed by the Sixth Amendment. See District of Columbia v. Clawans, 300 U. S. 617 (1937); Schick v. United States, 195 U. S. 65 (1904); Callan v. Wilson, 127 U. S. 540, 552 (1888).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites District of Columbia v. Clawans as precedent for the distinction between petty and serious offenses in jury trial rights, treating it as established authority without criticism.

quote: Although I have disagreed with particular holdings like Gilbert v. California, supra, where the Court held that the States must arrange presence of counsel at lineups, see Mr. Justice White's separate opinion in United States v. Wade, 388 U. S. 218, 250 (1967), which I joined...
rationale: Justice Harlan references United States v. Wade in the context of discussing his agreement with Justice White's separate opinion, treating it as precedent without criticism of the case itself.

quote: To the extent that Durham v. United States, 401 U. S. 481 (1971), may be inconsistent with this ruling, Durham is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Durham is overruled to the extent it may be inconsistent with the current ruling, which directly nullifies parts of the Cited Decision's precedential value.

cited_decision: Nancy Dukes, D/B/A Louisiana Concessions v. The City of New Orleans
quote: The Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reversed. 501 F. 2d 706 (1974). We postponed the question of this Court's jurisdiction to a hearing on the merits, 421 U. S. 908 (1975). We hold that we have jurisdiction of appellant's appeal, and on the merits reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it reverses the judgment of the Court of Appeals, which is the same case being appealed to the Supreme Court.

quote: Actually, the reliance on the statutes potential irrationality in Morey v. Doud, as the dissenters in that case correctly pointed out, see 354 U. S., at 474-475 (Frankfurter, J., joined by Harlan, J., dissenting), was a needlessly intrusive judicial infringement on the States legislative powers, and we have concluded that the equal protection analysis employed in that opinion should no longer be followed. Morey was the only case in the last half century to invalidate a wholly economic regulation solely on equal protection grounds, and we are now satisfied that the decision was erroneous... the decision so far departs from proper equal protection analysis in cases of exclusively economic regulation that it should be, and it is, overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Morey v. Doud was erroneous and should be overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value.

cited_decision: Williamson v. Lee Optical of Oklahoma, Inc.
quote: Legislatures may implement their program step by step, Katzenbach v. Morgan, 384 U. S. 641 (1966), in such economic areas, adopting regulations that only partially ameliorate a perceived evil and deferring complete elimination of the evil to future regulations. See, e. g., Williamson v. Lee Optical Co., 348 U. S. 483, 488-489 (1955).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Williamson v. Lee Optical as supportive authority for the principle that legislatures may implement programs step by step, without any negative treatment or criticism.

quote: in the local economic sphere, it is only the invidious discrimination., the wholly arbitrary act, which cannot stand consistently with the Fourteenth Amendment. See, e. g., Ferguson v. Skrupa, 372 U. S. 726, 732 (1963).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Ferguson v. Skrupa as supportive authority for the principle regarding equal protection analysis in economic regulation cases, without any negative treatment.

quote: The governing constitutional principle was stated in Katzenbach v. Morgan, supra, at 657: '[W]e are guided by the familiar principles that a statute is not invalid under the Constitution because it might have gone farther than it did,' Roschen v. Ward, 279 U. S. 337, 339, that a legislature need not strike at all evils at the same time,' Semler v. Dental Examiners, 294 U. S. 608, 610, and that reform may take one step at a time, addressing itself to the phase of the problem which seems most acute to the legislative mind,' Williamson v. Lee Optical Co., 348 U. S. 483, 489.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Katzenbach v. Morgan as establishing the governing constitutional principle that supports the city's gradual approach to regulation, treating it as authoritative precedent.

quote: It was the Marsh case that in 1968 provided the foundation for the Court's decision in Amalgamated Food Employees Union v. Logan Valley Plaza, 391 U. S. 308.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Marsh v. Alabama as foundational precedent for Logan Valley Plaza without criticizing or questioning its validity, merely explaining its historical role in the development of First Amendment jurisprudence.

cited_decision: Amalgamated Food Employees Union Local 590 v. Logan Valley Plaza, Inc.
quote: But the fact is that the reasoning of the Court's opinion in Lloyd cannot be squared with the reasoning of the Court's opinion in Logan Valley... we make clear now, if it was not clear before, that the rationale of Logan Valley did not survive the Court's decision in the Lloyd case.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Logan Valley's rationale did not survive Lloyd Corp. v. Tanner and makes clear that Logan Valley is effectively overruled, nullifying its precedential value.

quote: Four years later the Court had occasion to reconsider the Logan Valley doctrine in Lloyd Corp. v. Tanner, 407 U. S. 551. That case involved a shopping center covering some 50 acres in downtown Portland, Ore.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Lloyd Corp. v. Tanner extensively as controlling precedent that effectively overruled Logan Valley, treating it as authoritative law without criticism or limitation.

cited_decision: National Labor Relations Board v. Babcock & Wilcox Co.
quote: The Babcock & Wilcox opinion established the basic objective under the Act: accommodation of § 7 rights and private property rights 'with as little destruction of one as is consistent with the maintenance of the other.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Babcock & Wilcox as establishing the controlling standard for balancing Section 7 rights with property rights under the National Labor Relations Act, treating it as authoritative precedent.

cited_decision: Central Hardware Co. v. National Labor Relations Board
quote: Under the Act the task of the Board, subject to review by the courts, is to resolve conflicts between § 7 rights and private property rights, 'and to seek a proper accommodation between the two.' Central Hardware Co. v. NLRB, 407 U. S., at 543.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Central Hardware as supporting authority for the Board's task of accommodating competing rights under the National Labor Relations Act, treating it as established precedent without criticism.

quote: A three-judge court convened under 28 U. S. C. § 2281 sustained the constitutionality of the statutory differential and dismissed the action. 399 F. Supp. 1304 (1975). We noted probable jurisdiction of appellants' appeal, 423 U. S. 1047 (1976). We reverse.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly overturns the outcome of the District Court's decision in Walker v. Hall, which had sustained the constitutionality of Oklahoma's gender-based beer statute.

quote: And only two Terms ago, Stanton v. Stanton, 421 U. S. 7 (1975), expressly stating that Reed v. Reed was 'controlling,' 421 U. S., at 13, held that Reed required invalidation of a Utah differential age-of-majority statute
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Stanton v. Stanton as supportive precedent that follows Reed v. Reed in invalidating gender-based statutory classifications, without criticizing or questioning its authority.

quote: Analysis may appropriately begin with the reminder that Reed emphasized that statutory classifications that distinguish between males and females are 'subject to scrutiny under the Equal Protection Clause.' 404 U. S., at 75. To withstand constitutional challenge, previous cases establish that classifications by gender must serve important governmental objectives and must be substantially related to achievement of those objectives.
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on Reed v. Reed as controlling precedent that establishes the standard for gender-based classifications under equal protection analysis, applying its principles to the case at hand.

quote: our decisions have settled that limitations on a litigant's assertion of jus tertii are not constitutionally mandated, but rather stem from a salutary 'rule of self-restraint' designed to minimize unwarranted intervention into controversies where the applicable constitutional questions are ill-defined and speculative. See, e. g., Barrows v. Jackson, 346 U. S. 249, 255, 257 (1953)
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Barrows v. Jackson as supportive precedent regarding third-party standing doctrine, using it to support the vendor's standing to assert equal protection claims on behalf of young males.

quote: Decisions following Reed similarly have rejected administrative ease and convenience as sufficiently important objectives to justify gender-based classifications. See, e. g., Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U. S. 645, 656 (1972)
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Stanley v. Illinois as an example of cases following Reed that reject administrative convenience as justification for gender-based classifications, supporting the Court's analysis.

quote: Kahn v. Shevin, 416 U. S. 351 (1974) and Schlesinger v. Ballard, 419 U. S. 498 (1975), upholding the use of gender-based classifications, rested upon the Court's perception of the laudatory purposes of those laws as remedying disadvantageous conditions suffered by women in economic and military life. See 416 U. S., at 353-354; 419 U. S., at 508. Needless to say, in this case Oklahoma does not suggest that the age-sex differential was enacted to ensure the availability of 3.2% beer for women as compensation for previous deprivations.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Kahn v. Shevin by noting that unlike that case, which involved remedial purposes for women's disadvantages, Oklahoma's statute serves no such compensatory purpose.

quote: Decisions following Reed similarly have rejected administrative ease and convenience as sufficiently important objectives to justify gender-based classifications. See, e. g., Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U. S. 645, 656 (1972); Frontiero v. Richardson, 411 U. S. 677, 690 (1973)
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Frontiero v. Richardson as an example of cases following Reed that reject administrative convenience as justification for gender-based classifications, supporting the Court's equal protection analysis.

quote: Indeed, the jus tertii question raised here is answered by our disposition of a like argument in Eisenstadt v. Baird, supra. There, as here, a state statute imposed legal duties and disabilities upon the claimant, who was convicted of distributing a package of contraceptive foam to a third party.
rationale: The Acting Decision uses Eisenstadt v. Baird as controlling precedent to resolve the third-party standing issue, drawing parallels between the vendor's situation and Baird's standing to defend third-party privacy interests.

quote: Kahn v. Shevin, 416 U. S. 351 (1974) and Schlesinger v. Ballard, 419 U. S. 498 (1975), upholding the use of gender-based classifications, rested upon the Court's perception of the laudatory purposes of those laws as remedying disadvantageous conditions suffered by women in economic and military life. See 416 U. S., at 353-354; 419 U. S., at 508. Needless to say, in this case Oklahoma does not suggest that the age-sex differential was enacted to ensure the availability of 3.2% beer for women as compensation for previous deprivations.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Schlesinger v. Ballard by noting that unlike that case, which involved remedial purposes for women's disadvantages in military life, Oklahoma's statute serves no such compensatory purpose.

quote: Insofar as Goesaert v. Cleary, 335 U. S. 464 (1948), may be inconsistent, that decision is disapproved.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly disapproves Goesaert v. Cleary, indicating that its equal protection analysis regarding gender-based classifications in alcohol regulation is no longer valid precedent.

quote: While Furman did not hold that the infliction of the death penalty per se violates the Constitutions ban on cruel and unusual punishments, it did recognize that the penalty of death is different in kind from any other punishment imposed under our system of criminal justice. Because of the uniqueness of the death penalty, Furman held that it could not be imposed under sentencing procedures that created a substantial risk that it would be inflicted in an arbitrary and capricious manner.
rationale: The Court distinguishes Furman by explaining that while Furman found constitutional problems with arbitrary sentencing procedures, it did not hold the death penalty unconstitutional per se, and the new Georgia procedures address Furman's concerns about arbitrariness.

quote: As Mr. Chief Justice Warren said, in an oft-quoted phrase, '[t]he Amendment must draw its meaning from the evolving standards of decency that mark the progress of a maturing society.' Trop v. Dulles, supra, at 101.
rationale: The Court cites Trop v. Dulles for the well-established principle that the Eighth Amendment must be interpreted according to evolving standards of decency, without any negative treatment of the precedent.

quote: As a result, while some jury discretion still exists, 'the discretion to be exercised is controlled by clear and objective standards so as to produce non-discriminatory application.' Coley v. State, 231 Ga. 829, 834, 204 S. E. 2d 612, 615 (1974).
rationale: The Court cites Coley favorably to demonstrate that the Georgia Supreme Court has interpreted the new sentencing procedures as providing adequate guidance to control jury discretion.

quote: On the other hand, the court expressly reversed a finding of great risk when the victim was simply kid-naped in a parking lot. See Jarrell v. State, 234 Ga. 410, 424, 216 S. E. 2d 258, 269 (1975).
rationale: The Court cites Jarrell as an example of how the Georgia Supreme Court has narrowly construed statutory aggravating circumstances, demonstrating that the court provides meaningful review to prevent arbitrary application.

quote: The Supreme Court of Georgia affirmed the convictions and the imposition of the death sentences for murder. 233 Ga. 117, 210 S. E. 2d 659 (1974).
rationale: This is simply a factual reference to the lower court decision in the same case, noting that the Georgia Supreme Court affirmed the death sentences that are now under review.

quote: The Court early recognized that 'a principle to be vital must be capable of wider application than the mischief which gave it birth.' Weems v. United States, 217 U. S. 349, 373 (1910). Thus the Clause forbidding 'cruel and unusual' punishments 'is not fastened to the obsolete but may acquire meaning as public opinion becomes enlightened by a humane justice.'
rationale: The Court cites Weems favorably to support the principle that the Eighth Amendment should be interpreted dynamically rather than being limited to 18th century understandings of cruel and unusual punishment.

quote: In the only statewide referendum occurring since Furman and brought to our attention, the people of California adopted a constitutional amendment that authorized capital punishment, in effect negating a prior ruling by the Supreme Court of California in People v. Anderson, 6 Cal. 3d 628, 493 P. 2d 880, cert. denied, 406 U. S. 958 (1972), that the death penalty violated the California Constitution.
rationale: The Court mentions Anderson as an example of a state court decision that was overturned by popular referendum, using it to demonstrate public support for capital punishment rather than criticizing the decision itself.

quote: The court on another occasion stated that 'we view it to be our duty under the similarity standard to assure that no death sentence is affirmed unless in similar cases throughout the state the death penalty has been imposed generally . . .' Moore v. State, 233 Ga. 861, 864, 213 S. E. 2d 829, 832 (1975).
rationale: The Court cites Moore favorably to demonstrate that the Georgia Supreme Court takes its proportionality review responsibilities seriously in ensuring death sentences are not disproportionate.

quote: The Ehrlich study, in short, is of little, if any, assistance in assessing the deterrent impact of the death penalty. Accord, Commonwealth v. O'Neal, -Mass. -, -, 339 N. E. 2d 676, 684 (1975).
rationale: This citation appears in Justice Marshall's dissenting opinion, where he cites Commonwealth v. O'Neal in agreement with his view that empirical studies do not support the deterrent effect of capital punishment.

quote: The substantive limits imposed by the Eighth Amendment on what can be made criminal and punished were discussed in Robinson v. California, 370 U. S. 660 (1962). The Court found unconstitutional a state statute that made the status of being addicted to a narcotic drug a criminal offense.
rationale: The Court cites Robinson as an example of how the Eighth Amendment has been applied to find certain punishments unconstitutional, using it to illustrate the evolution of Eighth Amendment jurisprudence without any negative treatment.

quote: In McGautha v. California, supra, this Court held that the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment did not require that a jury be provided with standards to guide its decision whether to recommend a sentence of life imprisonment or death or that the capital-sentencing proceeding be separated from the guilt-determination process. McGautha was not an Eighth Amendment decision, and to the extent it purported to deal with Eighth Amendment concerns, it must be read in light of the opinions in Furman v. Georgia.
rationale: The Court limits McGautha by explaining that it was a Due Process case rather than an Eighth Amendment case, and that Furman has substantially undermined McGautha's assumptions about standardless sentencing procedures.

cited_decision: National Labor Relations Board v. Insurance Agents' International Union
quote: Insurance Agents, supra, involved a charge of a refusal by the union to bargain in good faith in violation of § 8 (b) (3) of the Act. The charge was based on union activities that occurred during good-faith bargaining over the terms of a collective-bargaining agreement.
rationale: The Court extensively discusses Insurance Agents as supportive precedent for its holding that certain union activities are protected from state regulation because Congress intended them to be controlled by free economic forces, without criticizing or limiting the decision.

cited_decision: International Union, U. A. W. A., A. F. of L., Local 232 v. Wisconsin Employment Relations Board
quote: We hold today that the ruling of Briggs-Stratton, permitting state regulation of partial strike activities such as are involved in this case is likewise 'no longer of general application.' ... Briggs-Stratton is expressly overruled.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that Briggs-Stratton is 'expressly overruled' because it conflicts with the federal policy of leaving certain economic weapons unregulated by both federal and state authorities.

cited_decision: San Diego Building Trades Council v. Garmon
quote: Federal labor policy as reflected in the National Labor Relations Act, as amended, has been construed not to preclude the States from regulating aspects of labor relations that involve 'conduct touch [ing] interests so deeply rooted in local feeling and responsibility that ... we could not infer that Congress had deprived the States of the power to act.' San Diego Unions v. Garmon, 359 U. S. 236, 244 (1959).
rationale: The Court cites Garmon as establishing the framework for federal preemption analysis in labor law, using it as foundational precedent without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Hanna Mining Co. v. District 2, Marine Engineers Beneficial Ass'n
quote: '[T]he legislative purpose may . . . dictate that certain activity neither protected nor prohibited' be deemed privileged against state regulation.' Hanna Mining Co. v. Marine Engineers, 382 U. S. 181, 187 (1965).
rationale: The Court cites Hanna Mining as support for the principle that Congress may intend certain activities to be privileged against state regulation even when they are neither explicitly protected nor prohibited by federal law.

cited_decision: Local 20, Teamsters, Chauffeurs & Helpers Union v. Morton
quote: Central to Morton's analysis was the observation that ' [i] n selecting which forms of economic pressure should be prohibited . . . , Congress struck the 'balance . . . between the uncontrolled power of management and labor to further their respective interests,' ' id,., at 258-259
rationale: The Court relies on Morton as precedent supporting the principle that Congress struck a balance between labor and management interests, and that state interference with this balance frustrates federal policy.

cited_decision: Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Jacksonville Terminal Co.
quote: Whether self-help economic activities are employed by employer or union, the crucial inquiry regarding pre-emption is the same: whether 'the exercise of plenary state authority to curtail or entirely prohibit self-help would frustrate effective implementation of the Act's processes.' Railroad Trainmen v. Jacksonville Terminal Co., 394 U. S., at 380.
rationale: The Court cites Railroad Trainmen as establishing the test for determining when state authority is preempted in labor relations, using it as supportive precedent for the preemption analysis.

quote: But the opinion in Brown v. Maryland cannot properly be read to propose such a broad definition of 'imposts' or 'duties.' The tax there held to be prohibited by the Import-Export Clause was imposed under a Maryland statute that required importers of foreign goods, and wholesalers selling the same by bale or package, to obtain a license and pay a $50 fee therefor, subject to certain forfeitures and penalties for noncompliance.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Brown v. Maryland by clarifying that its holding was limited to license fees on importers and did not establish a broad prohibition against all nondiscriminatory ad valorem property taxes on imported goods.

quote: We hold that, in any event, Georgia's assessment of a nondiscriminatory ad valorem property tax against the imported tires is not within the constitutional prohibition against laying 'any Imposts or Duties on Imports . . and that insofar as Low v. Austin, 13 Wall. 29 (1872) is to the contrary, that decision is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly overrules Low v. Austin, stating that it was wrongly decided and misread the precedent in Brown v. Maryland regarding the scope of prohibited imposts and duties.

cited_decision: Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Bowers
quote: Taxes imposed after an initial sale, after the breakup of the shipping packages, or the moment goods imported for use are committed to current operational needs are also all likely to have an incidental effect on the volume of goods imported; yet all are permissible. See, e. g., Waring v. The Mayor, 8 Wall. 110 (1869) (taxation after initial sale); May v. New Orleans, supra (taxation after breakup of shipping packages); Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Bowers, 358 U. S. 534 (1959) (taxation of goods committed to current operational needs by manufacturer).
rationale: The Acting Decision merely cites Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Bowers as an example of permissible taxation without any critical analysis or challenge to its precedential value.

quote: Low v. Austin quoted this excerpt, 13 Wall., at 33-34, as supporting the holding, id., at 34, that 'a tax upon [imported goods], in any shape, is within the constitutional prohibition.' But Mr. Chief Justice Taney said much more in his opinion in the License Cases, and what he said further makes crystal clear that the prohibition applied only to state exactions upon imports as imports and did not apply to nondiscriminatory ad valorem property taxes.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes the License Cases (which includes Thurlow v. Massachusetts) by showing that Chief Justice Taney's complete opinion actually supported nondiscriminatory property taxes, contrary to how Low v. Austin had interpreted and quoted only a portion of his reasoning.

cited_decision: Memphis Natural Gas Co. v. Stone
quote: The narrowing of the rule to one of draftsmanship and phraseology began with another Mississippi case, Memphis Gas Co. v. Stone, 335 U. S. 80 (1948).
rationale: The Court references Memphis Gas as an example of how the Spector rule was narrowed to draftsmanship issues, but does not criticize or question the decision itself.

quote: The unsatisfactory operation of the Spector rule is well demonstrated by our recent case of Colonial Pipeline Co. v. Traigle, 421 U. S. 100 (1975).
rationale: The Court uses Colonial Pipeline as an example to demonstrate problems with the Spector rule, but affirms and relies on Colonial Pipeline's reasoning without criticizing the decision itself.

cited_decision: Spector Motor Service, Inc. v. O'Connor
quote: Accordingly, we now reject the rule of Spector Motor Service, Inc. v. O'Connor, that a state tax on the 'privilege of doing business' is per se unconstitutional when it is applied to interstate commerce, and that case is overruled.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that it is overruling Spector Motor Service, directly nullifying the precedential value of that decision's rule regarding privilege taxes on interstate commerce.

cited_decision: Western Live Stock v. Bureau of Revenue
quote: It is a truism that the mere act of carrying on business in interstate commerce does not exempt a corporation from state taxation. It was not the purpose of the commerce clause to relieve those engaged in interstate commerce from their just share of state tax burden even though it increases the cost of doing business.' Western Live Stock v. Bureau of Revenue, 303 U. S. 250, 254 (1938).
rationale: The Court favorably cites Western Live Stock to support its position that interstate commerce should pay its fair share of state taxes, using it as authority without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Railway Express Agency, Inc. v. Virginia
quote: In upholding the statute, the Court's opinion recognized that the rule against taxing the 'privilege' of doing interstate business had created a situation where 'the use of magic words or labels' could 'disable an otherwise constitutional levy.' Id., at 441.
rationale: The Court references Railway Express II to illustrate how the Spector rule had become merely a matter of draftsmanship, but does not criticize the Railway Express decision itself.

cited_decision: United States v. Arnold, Schwinn & Co. (1967)
quote: Accordingly, we conclude that the per se rule stated in Schwinn must be overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the per se rule established in Schwinn must be overruled, directly nullifying the precedential value of that decision's core holding.

cited_decision: Gte Sylvania Incorporated v. Continental T v. Inc., a Corporation (1976)
quote: Accordingly, the decision of the Court of Appeals is Affirmed.
rationale: This is the lower court decision in the same case that the Acting Decision is reviewing on appeal, and the Supreme Court affirmed the Court of Appeals decision, which had reversed the District Court's ruling.

cited_decision: Northern Pacific Railway Co. v. United States (1958)
quote: We revert to the standard articulated in Northern Pac. R. Co., and reiterated in White Motor, for determining whether vertical restrictions must be 'conclusively presumed to be unreasonable and therefore illegal without elaborate inquiry as to the precise harm they have caused or the business excuse for their use.'
rationale: The Acting Decision references Northern Pacific Railway to establish the standard for determining when per se rules are appropriate, using it as authoritative precedent without criticism or limitation.

cited_decision: United States v. Arnold, Schwinn & Co. (1965)
quote: The District Court rejected the price-fixing allegation because of a failure of proof and held that Schwinn's limitation of retail bicycle sales to franchised retailers was permissible under § 1.
rationale: The Acting Decision references the District Court decision in Schwinn to provide factual background and context for understanding the Supreme Court's Schwinn decision, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Pittsburgh Press Co. v. Pittsburgh Commission on Human Relations
quote: The Court, however, upheld the ordinance on the ground that the restriction it imposed was permissible because the discriminatory hirings proposed by the advertisements, and by their newspaper layout, were themselves illegal.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Pittsburgh Press by noting that case involved advertisements for illegal discriminatory hiring, whereas the present case involves entirely lawful prescription drug transactions.

quote: Last Term, in Bigelow v. Virginia, 421 U. S. 809 (1975), the notion of unprotected 'commercial speech' all but passed from the scene.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Bigelow as precedent that moved away from the commercial speech exception, using it to support the evolution of First Amendment protection for commercial speech.

cited_decision: New York Times Co. v. Sullivan
quote: It is clear, for example, that speech does not lose its First Amendment protection because money is spent to project it, as in a paid advertisement of one form or another.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites New York Times Co. v. Sullivan as established precedent that paid advertisements can receive First Amendment protection, supporting the argument for protecting commercial speech.

quote: The District Court seized on the identity of the plaintiff-appellees as consumers as a feature distinguishing the present case from Patterson Drug Co. v. Kingery, supra. Because the unsuccessful plaintiffs in that earlier case were pharmacists, the court said, 'theirs was a prima facie commercial approach.'
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Patterson Drug by noting that the earlier case involved pharmacists as plaintiffs with commercial interests, while the present case involves consumers asserting health-related interests.

quote: The interests of the contestants in a labor dispute are primarily economic, but it has long been settled that both the employee and the employer are protected by the First Amendment when they express themselves on the merits of the dispute in order to influence its outcome.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Thornhill as precedent showing that economic interests do not disqualify speech from First Amendment protection, supporting the argument for protecting commercial speech.

cited_decision: Virginia Citizens Consumer Council, Inc. v. State Board of Pharmacy
quote: The three-judge District Court declared the quoted portion of the statute 'void and of no effect,' Jurisdictional Statement, App. 1, and enjoined the defendant-appellants, the Virginia State Board of Pharmacy and the individual members of that Board, from enforcing it. 373 F. Supp. 683 (ED Va. 1974).
rationale: The Acting Decision simply references the lower court decision that it is reviewing on appeal, providing procedural background without expressing any treatment of the decision's reasoning.

quote: Chrestensen's continued validity was questioned, and its holding was described as 'distinctly a limited one' that merely upheld 'a reasonable regulation of the manner in which commercial advertising could be distributed.'
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly limits the scope and applicability of Valentine v. Chrestensen, narrowing its precedential value by describing it as having limited validity and a narrow holding.

cited_decision: Williamson v. Lee Optical of Oklahoma, Inc.
quote: The District Court recognized that this Court had upheld — against federal constitutional challenges other than on First Amendment grounds — state restrictions on the advertisement of prices for optometrists' services, Head v. New Mexico Board, 374 U. S. 424 (1963), for eyeglass frames, Williamson v. Lee Optical Co., 348 U. S. 483 (1955), and for dentists' services, Semler v. Dental Examiners, 294 U. S. 608 (1935).
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Williamson by noting it involved challenges on grounds other than the First Amendment, whereas the present case is based on First Amendment grounds.

cited_decision: National Labor Relations Board v. Gissel Packing Co.
quote: The interests of the contestants in a labor dispute are primarily economic, but it has long been settled that both the employee and the employer are protected by the First Amendment when they express themselves on the merits of the dispute in order to influence its outcome.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Gissel Packing as precedent showing that economic interests in labor disputes receive First Amendment protection, supporting the argument that commercial speech should also be protected.

quote: To this end, the free flow of commercial information is indispensable. See Dun & Bradstreet, Inc. v. Grove, 404 U. S. 898, 904-906 (1971) (Douglas, J., dissenting from denial of certiorari).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Justice Douglas's dissent in Dun & Bradstreet to support the argument that free flow of commercial information serves important societal interests.

quote: In New York v. United States, 326 U. S. 572 (1946), Mr. Chief Justice Stone, speaking for four Members of an eight-Member Court in rejecting the proposition that Congress could impose taxes on the States so long as it did so in a nondiscriminatory manner, observed: 'A State may, like a private individual, own real property and receive income. But in view of our former decisions we could hardly say that a general non-discriminatory real estate tax (apportioned), or an income tax laid upon citizens and States alike could be constitutionally applied to the State's capitol, its State-house, its public school houses, public parks, or its revenues from taxes or school lands, even though all real property and all income of the citizen .is taxed.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites New York v. United States as supportive precedent for the principle that there are limits on Congress's power to regulate states, without criticizing or questioning its validity.

quote: With regard to Fry, we disagree with appellee. There the Court held that the Economic Stabilization Act of 1970 was constitutional as applied to temporarily freeze the wages of state and local government employees... We think our holding today quite consistent with Fry. The enactment at issue there was occasioned by an extremely serious problem which endangered the well-being of all the component parts of our federal system and which only collective action by the National Government might forestall.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Fry by explaining that the circumstances in Fry were different - it involved a temporary emergency measure that did not interfere with state choices about governmental operations, unlike the permanent FLSA amendments at issue.

quote: We are therefore persuaded that Wirtz must be overruled... we do not believe the reasoning in Wirtz may any longer be regarded as authoritative.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Wirtz must be overruled and that its reasoning is no longer authoritative, directly nullifying the precedential value of the Cited Decision.

quote: We think the dicta from United States v. California, simply wrong.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the dicta from United States v. California is 'simply wrong,' directly criticizing the reasoning of the Cited Decision.

quote: This Court unanimously upheld the Act as a valid exercise of congressional authority under the commerce power in United States v. Darby, 312 U. S. 100 (1941), observing: 'Whatever their motive and purpose, regulations of commerce which do not infringe some constitutional prohibition are within the plenary power conferred on Congress by the Commerce Clause.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Darby as established precedent supporting Congress's commerce power authority without any negative treatment or criticism.

quote: That authority is, in the words of Mr. Chief Justice Marshall in Gibbons v. Ogden, 9 Wheat. 1 (1824), 'the power to regulate; that is, to prescribe the rule by which commerce is to be governed.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Gibbons v. Ogden as foundational authority for defining Congress's commerce power without any criticism or negative treatment.

quote: It also seems appropriate to note that Case v. Bowles, 327 U. S. 92 (1946), has not been overruled as the dissent asserts. Indeed that decision, upon which our Brother heavily relies, has no direct application to the questions we consider today at all. For there the Court sustained an application of the Emergency Price Control Act to a sale of timber by the State of Washington, expressly noting that the 'only question is whether the State's power to make the sales must be in subordination to the power of Congress to fix maximum prices in order to carry on war.'
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Case v. Bowles by explaining that it involved different circumstances (war powers) and has no direct application to the current case, thereby limiting its relevance.

quote: In Fry, supra, the Court recognized that an express declaration of this limitation is found in the Tenth Amendment: 'While the Tenth Amendment has been characterized as a truism,' stating merely that all is retained which has not been surrendered, United States v. Darby, 312 U. S. 100, 124 (1941), it is not without significance.'
rationale: The Acting Decision references the characterization of the Tenth Amendment from Darby (which cites Helvering v. Gerhardt) without any negative treatment, using it as part of the constitutional analysis.

quote: In Coyle v. Oklahoma, 221 U. S. 559 (1911), the Court gave this example of such an attribute: 'The power to locate its own seat of government and to determine when and how it shall be changed from one place to another, and to appropriate its own public funds for that purpose, are essentially and peculiarly state powers.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Coyle as supportive precedent for the principle of state sovereignty and attributes of state power without any criticism or negative treatment.

quote: In Lane County v. Oregon, 7 Wall. 71 (1869), his opinion for the Court said: 'Both the States and the United States existed before the Constitution. The people, through that instrument, established a more perfect union by substituting a national government, acting, with ample power, directly upon the citizens, instead of the Confederate government, which acted with powers, greatly restricted, only upon the States.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Lane County v. Oregon as supportive precedent for the principle of state sovereignty and the federal system without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Parden v. Terminal Railway of Alabama State Docks Department (1964)
quote: For the same reasons, despite Mr. Justice Brennan's claims to the contrary, the holdings in Parden v. Terminal R. Co., 377 U. S. 184 (1964), and California v. Taylor, 353 U. S. 553 (1957), are likewise unimpaired by our decision today.
rationale: The Acting Decision states that Parden's holding is unimpaired by the current decision, indicating that it remains valid precedent without negative treatment.

cited_decision: Employees of Department of Public Health v. Department of Public Health (1973)
quote: We sustained the validity of the combined effect of these two amendments in Maryland v. Wirtz, 392 U. S. 183 (1968).
rationale: The Acting Decision references the case as part of the historical development of Fair Labor Standards Act coverage without any negative treatment, though it is mentioned in the context of discussing Wirtz which is later overruled.

quote: In Michelin the Court upheld the application of a general ad valorem property tax to imported tires and tubes. The Court surveyed the history and purposes of the Import-Export-Clause to determine, for the first time, which taxes fell within the absolute ban on 'Imposts or Duties.'
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on and applies the analytical framework established in Michelin without criticizing or questioning its validity, using it as the foundation for its Import-Export Clause analysis.

cited_decision: Complete Auto Transit, Inc. v. Brady
quote: We conclude that Complete Auto Transit, Inc. v. Brady, where the Court held that a State under appropriate conditions may tax directly the privilege of conducting interstate business, requires such rejection.
rationale: The Acting Decision uses Complete Auto as the basis for overruling the Stevedoring Cases, treating it as controlling precedent that permits direct taxation of interstate commerce privileges under appropriate conditions.

cited_decision: Joseph v. Carter & Weekes Stevedoring Co.
quote: To the extent that Puget Sound Stevedoring Co. v. State Tax Comm'n and Joseph v. Carter & Weekes Stevedoring Co. stand to the contrary, each is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Carter & Weekes is overruled to the extent it conflicts with the Court's holding that Washington's business and occupation tax does not violate the Commerce Clause.

quote: In Canton R. Co. v. Rogan, 340 U. S. 511 (1951), the Court upheld a gross-receipts tax on a steam railroad operating exclusively within the Port of Baltimore... The Court rejected that argument primarily on the ground that immunity of services incidental to importing and exporting was not so broad as the immunity of the goods themselves
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on Canton R. Co. as supportive precedent for distinguishing between taxes on goods themselves versus taxes on services related to handling those goods, using it to support the validity of the stevedoring tax.

cited_decision: Western Live Stock v. Bureau of Revenue
quote: As was recognized in Western Live Stock v. Bureau of Revenue, 303 U. S. 250 (1938), interstate commerce must bear its fair share of the state tax burden.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Western Live Stock as established precedent supporting the principle that interstate commerce should bear its fair share of state tax burdens, using it to support the constitutionality of the Washington tax.

cited_decision: Puget Sound Stevedoring Co. v. State Tax Commission
quote: To the extent that Puget Sound Stevedoring Co. v. State Tax Comm'n and Joseph v. Carter & Weekes Stevedoring Co. stand to the contrary, each is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly overrules Puget Sound to the extent it conflicts with the Court's holding that Washington's business and occupation tax on stevedoring does not violate the Commerce Clause.

quote: Pollard's Lessee held that under the equal-footing doctrine new States, upon their admission to the Union, acquire title to the lands underlying navigable waters within their boundaries.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Pollard's Lessee as establishing the foundational equal-footing doctrine without criticizing or questioning its validity, using it as support for the Court's analysis.

quote: Our analysis today leads us to conclude that our decision to apply federal common law in Bonelli was incorrect... Upon full reconsideration of our decision in Bonelli, we conclude that it was wrong in treating the equal-footing doctrine as a source of federal common law after that doctrine had vested title to the riverbed in the State of Arizona as of the time of its admission to the Union... For all of these reasons, we have now decided that Bonelli's application of federal common law to cases such as this must be overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Bonelli was incorrect and must be overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value regarding the application of federal common law to state riverbed ownership disputes.

quote: And in Shively v. Bowlby, 152 U. S. 1 (1894), the Court recounted in extenso the many cases which had followed the doctrine of Pollard's Lessee.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Shively v. Bowlby as supporting precedent that followed the doctrine of Pollard's Lessee, without any negative treatment or criticism of the decision.

cited_decision: Borax Consolidated, Ltd. v. Los Angeles
quote: In Borax, Ltd. v. Los Angeles, 296 U. S. 10 (1935), this Court also found a basis to apply federal law, but its rationale does not dictate a different result in this case... But that determination is solely for the purpose of fixing the boundaries of the riverbed acquired by the State at the time of its admission to the Union; thereafter the role of the equal-footing doctrine is ended, and the land is subject to the laws of the State.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Borax by limiting its application to initial boundary determinations only, rather than allowing it to support ongoing federal common law application as was done in Bonelli.

quote: In Barney v. Keokuk, 94 U. S. 324, 338 (1877), the Court extended the doctrine to waters which were nontidal but nonetheless navigable, consistent with its earlier extension of admiralty jurisdiction to such waters
rationale: The Acting Decision references Barney v. Keokuk as extending established doctrine to nontidal navigable waters, citing it as supportive precedent without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: County of St. Clair v. Lovingston
quote: This statement of the law was quoted by the Court in County of St. Clair v. Lovingston, 23 Wall. 46, 68 (1874).
rationale: The Acting Decision references County of St. Clair v. Lovingston as having quoted established common law principles, treating it as supportive precedent without criticism.

quote: In addition, as the Court is certain to announce when the occasion arises, today's holding also overrules Hughes v. Washington, 389 U. S. 290 (1967), a nine-year-old decision also joined by all but one of the participating Justices.
rationale: While the majority opinion does not formally overrule Hughes, the dissenting opinion explicitly states that the majority's holding overrules Hughes v. Washington, and the majority's reasoning necessarily undermines Hughes' federal common law approach.

cited_decision: Joy v. City of St. Louis
quote: This doctrine was squarely applied to the case of a riparian proprietor in Joy v. St. Louis, 201 U. S. 332 (1906)... Central to this result was the holding: 'As this land in controversy is not the land described in the letters patent or the [A]cts of Congress, but, as is stated in the petition, is formed by accretions or gradual deposits from the river, whether such land belongs to the plaintiff is, under the cases just cited, a matter of local or state law, and not one arising under the laws of the United States.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Joy v. St. Louis as supporting the principle that state law governs property disputes involving accretions to federally patented land, using it as supportive precedent.

quote: Indeed, the rule that lands once having passed from the Federal Government are subject to the laws of the State in which they lie antedates Pollard's Lessee. As long ago as 1839, the Court said: 'We hold the true principle to be this, that whenever the question in any Court, state or federal, is, whether a title to land which had once been the property of the United States has passed, that question must be resolved by the laws of the United States; but that whenever, according to those laws, the title shall have passed, then that property, like all other property in the state, is subject to state legislation; so far as that legislation is consistent with the admission that the title passed and vested according to the laws of the United States.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Wilcox v. Jackson as establishing the principle that once federal land passes to private ownership, it becomes subject to state law, using it as supportive precedent for the Court's reasoning.

quote: we now overrule Monroe v. Pape, supra, insofar as it holds that local governments are wholly immune from suit under § 1983
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it overrules Monroe v. Pape to the extent it held local governments immune from § 1983 suits, directly nullifying this aspect of the precedent.

quote: Building on Prigg, Shellabarger argued that a remedy against municipalities and counties was an appropriate — and hence constitutional — method for ensuring the protection which the Fourteenth Amendment made every citizen's federal right
rationale: The Acting Decision references Prigg as part of the historical analysis of constitutional arguments made during the 1871 debates, without criticizing or questioning its precedential value.

quote: we have reaffirmed Monroe without further examination on three occasions
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions Moor as one of the cases that reaffirmed Monroe, but does not provide any negative treatment of the decision itself.

cited_decision: 12 Fair empl.prac.cas. 836, 11 Empl. Prac. Dec. P 10,755 Jane Monell v. Department of Social Services of the City of New York, Defendants
quote: For the reasons stated above, therefore, we hold that stare decisis does not bar our overruling of Monroe insofar as it is inconsistent with Parts I and II of this opinion... For the reasons stated above, the judgment of the Court of Appeals is Reversed
rationale: The Acting Decision directly overturns the Court of Appeals judgment in this same case, which is the typical treatment when an appellate court reverses a lower court's decision.

quote: Compare this statement with Representative Poland's remark upon which our holding in Monroe was based
rationale: The Acting Decision references Supervisors v. Durant as part of the historical analysis of Contract Clause cases that were cited during the 1871 congressional debates, without any negative treatment.

quote: Collector v. Day, cited by Blair, was the clearest and, at the time of the debates, the most recent pronouncement of a doctrine of coordinate sovereignty
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Collector v. Day as part of the historical constitutional doctrine that influenced the 1871 congressional debates, noting it as precedent that 'has not survived' but not directly criticizing it.

quote: we have reaffirmed Monroe without further examination on three occasions
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions City of Kenosha v. Bruno as one of the cases that reaffirmed Monroe, but does not provide any negative treatment of the decision itself.

cited_decision: Bivens v. Six Unknown Named Agents of Federal Bureau of Narcotics
quote: municipal bodies sued under § 1983 cannot be entitled to an absolute immunity, lest our decision that such bodies are subject to suit under § 1983 'be drained of meaning'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Bivens in a string citation to support the principle that absolute immunity would drain the right to sue of meaning, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Cleveland Board of Education v. LaFleur
quote: The gravamen of the complaint was that the Board and the Department had as a matter of official policy compelled pregnant employees to take unpaid leaves of absence before such leaves were required for medical reasons. Cf. Cleveland Board of Education v. LaFleur
rationale: The Acting Decision references LaFleur as a comparison case regarding the constitutional issues with mandatory maternity leave policies, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Mt. Healthy City School District Board of Education v. Doyle
quote: we indicated in Mt. Healthy City Board of Education v. Doyle, 429 U. S. 274, 279 (1977), last Term that the question presented here was open and would be decided 'another day.'
rationale: The Acting Decision references Mt. Healthy as having left open the question of municipal liability under § 1983, without any negative treatment of that decision.

quote: Cf., e. g., Ex parte Virginia, 100 U. S. 339, 346-347 (1880)
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Ex parte Virginia in support of the principle that municipalities could be included within the scope of § 1983, without any negative treatment.

quote: we have reaffirmed Monroe without further examination on three occasions
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions Aldinger as one of the cases that reaffirmed Monroe, but does not provide any negative treatment of the decision itself.

cited_decision: United States v. Martin Linen Supply Co.
quote: Only last Term, this Court relied upon these precedents in United States v. Martin Linen Supply Co., 430 U. S. 564 (1977), and held that the Government could not appeal the granting of a motion to acquit pursuant to Fed. Rule Crim. Proc. 29 where a second trial would be required upon remand.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Martin Linen Supply Co. as supporting precedent for the principle that judgments of acquittal may not be appealed when a second trial would be required, without criticizing or questioning its validity.

quote: However, only last Term, in Lee, supra, the Government was permitted to institute a second prosecution after a midtrial dismissal of an indictment. The Court found the circumstances presented by that case 'functionally indistinguishable from a declaration of mistrial.'
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Lee by noting that it involved circumstances that were functionally equivalent to a mistrial, unlike the present case involving a dismissal based on preindictment delay.

quote: In our first encounter with the new statute, we concluded that 'Congress intended to remove all statutory, barriers to Government appeals and to allow appeals whenever the Constitution would permit.' United States v. Wilson, 420 U. S. 332, 337 (1975).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Wilson as establishing the principle that Congress intended to allow Government appeals whenever constitutionally permitted, using it as foundational precedent without criticism.

quote: Yet, though our assessment of the history and meaning of the Double Jeopardy Clause in Wilson, Jenkins, and Serfass v. United States, 420 U. S. 377 (1975), occurred only three Terms ago, our vastly increased exposure to the various facets of the Double Jeopardy Clause has now convinced us that Jenkins was wrongly decided... We have therefore decided to overrule Jenkins, and thus to reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals in this case.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Jenkins was wrongly decided and formally overrules it, finding that it placed unwarranted emphasis on the defendant's right to have guilt decided by the first jury.

quote: As this Court has described the purpose underlying the prohibition against double jeopardy: 'The underlying idea, one that is deeply ingrained in at least the Anglo-American system of jurisprudence, is that the State with all its resources and power should not be allowed to make repeated attempts to convict an individual for an alleged offense...' Green, supra, at 187-188.
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes Green to explain the underlying purposes of the Double Jeopardy Clause, using it as authoritative precedent to establish foundational principles.

quote: And, in the very first case presenting the issues, United States v. Ball, 163 U. S. 662 (1896), the Court established principles that have been adhered to ever since... Although Ball firmly established that a successful appeal of a conviction precludes a subsequent plea of double jeopardy, the opinion shed no light on whether a judgment of acquittal could be reversed on appeal consistently with the Double Jeopardy Clause.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Ball as establishing enduring principles regarding double jeopardy and successful appeals of convictions, treating it as foundational precedent without criticism.

quote: In our recent decision in Arizona v. Washington, 434 U. S. 497 (1978), we reviewed this Court's attempts to give content to the term 'manifest necessity.'
rationale: The Acting Decision references Arizona v. Washington as providing guidance on the concept of 'manifest necessity' in mistrial contexts, using it as supportive precedent.

quote: Because of the statutory restrictions upon Government appeals in criminal cases, this Court in the years after Ball was faced with that question only in unusual circumstances, such as were present in Kepner v. United States, 195 U. S. 100 (1904).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Kepner as an example of unusual circumstances where the Court addressed whether acquittals could be reversed on appeal, using it as historical precedent.

quote: Yet, though our assessment of the history and meaning of the Double Jeopardy Clause in Wilson, Jenkins, and Serfass v. United States, 420 U. S. 377 (1975), occurred only three Terms ago, our vastly increased exposure to the various facets of the Double Jeopardy Clause has now convinced us that Jenkins was wrongly decided.
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions Serfass as part of the Court's previous assessment of Double Jeopardy Clause principles, grouping it with other cases in the Court's evolving understanding.

quote: '[A] motion by the defendant for mistrial is ordinarily assumed to remove any barrier to reprosecution, even if the defendant's motion is necessitated by a prosecutorial or judicial error.' United States v. Jorn, 400 U. S. 470, 485 (1971) (opinion of Harlan, J.).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Jorn to support the principle that defendant-initiated mistrials generally do not bar reprosecution, using it as supportive precedent for established doctrine.

quote: More than 50 years later, in Fong Foo v. United States, 369 U. S. 141 (1962), this Court reviewed the issuance of a writ of mandamus by the Court of Appeals for the First Circuit instructing a District Court to vacate certain judgments of acquittal. Although indicating its agreement with the Court of Appeals that the judgments had been entered erroneously, this Court nonetheless held that a second trial was barred by the Double Jeopardy Clause.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Fong Foo as precedent establishing that even erroneous acquittals cannot be appealed when a second trial would be required, using it as supportive authority for double jeopardy principles.

quote: The automatic standing, rule of Jones v. United States, supra, is therefore overruled.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that the automatic standing rule established in Jones v. United States is overruled, directly nullifying this precedent.

quote: This Court's ruling in Simmons thus not only extends protection against this risk of self-incrimination in all of the cases covered by Jones, but also grants a form of 'use immunity' to those defendants charged with nonpossessory crimes.
rationale: The Court discusses Simmons favorably as providing broader protection than Jones and uses it to support the elimination of one of Jones's original rationales, without criticizing or questioning Simmons itself.

quote: Thus, as we stated in Brown v. United States, 411 U. S., at 228, '[t]he self-incrimination dilemma, so central to the Jones decision, can no longer occur under the prevailing interpretation of the Constitution [in Simmons].'
rationale: The Court cites Brown v. United States to support its analysis that the self-incrimination rationale underlying Jones has been eliminated, using it as supportive authority without any negative treatment.

quote: The same argument has been rejected by this Court as a sufficient basis for allowing persons whose Fourth Amendment rights were not violated to nevertheless claim the benefits of the exclusionary rule. In Alderman v. United States, 394 U. S., at 174-175, we explicitly stated...
rationale: The Court cites Alderman approvingly to support its rejection of the deterrence argument for retaining automatic standing, using it as established precedent to bolster its reasoning.

quote: Our consideration of the foundations for the privilege and its history satisfy us that reason and experience no longer justify so sweeping a rule as that found acceptable by the Court in Hawkins. Accordingly, we conclude that the existing rule should be modified so that the witness-spouse alone has a privilege to refuse to testify adversely; the witness may be neither compelled to testify nor foreclosed from testifying.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that the Hawkins rule is no longer justified and concludes that the existing rule should be modified, effectively overruling the precedent established in Hawkins.

quote: Indeed, it was not until 1933, in Funk v. United States, 290 U.S. 371, that this Court abolished the testimonial disqualification in the federal courts, so as to permit the spouse of a defendant to testify in the defendant's behalf. Funk, however, left undisturbed the rule that either spouse could prevent the other from giving adverse testimony.
rationale: The Court references Funk to provide historical context about the evolution of spousal testimony rules, describing what Funk accomplished without criticizing or questioning its validity.

quote: Hawkins, then, left the federal privilege for adverse spousal testimony where it found it, continuing 'a rule which bars the testimony of one spouse against the other unless both consent.' Id., at 78. Accord, Wyatt v. United States, 362 U.S. 525, 528 (1960).
rationale: The Court cites Wyatt merely to show that it was in accord with the Hawkins rule, using it as supporting authority for the historical description of the law without any negative treatment.
