quote: The Federal Rules of Evidence acknowledge the authority of the federal courts to continue the evolutionary development of testimonial privileges in federal criminal trials 'governed by the principles of the common law as they may be interpreted ... in the light of reason and experience.' Fed. Rule Evid. 501. Cf. Wolfle v. United States, 291 U.S. 7, 12 (1934).
rationale: The Court references Wolfle in a comparative citation to support the principle that courts have authority to develop privilege law, without any criticism or negative treatment of the decision.

quote: It was applied by this Court in Stein v. Bowman, 13 Pet. 209, 220-223 (1839), in Graves v. United States, 150 U.S. 118 (1893), and again in Jin Fuey Moy v. United States, 254 U.S. 189, 195 (1920), where it was deemed so well established a proposition as to 'hardly requir[e] mention.'
rationale: The Court cites Stein as a historical example of when the spousal disqualification rule was applied, providing factual background without criticizing the decision itself.

quote: This Court recognized just such a confidential marital communications privilege in Wolfle v. United States, 291 U.S. 7 (1934), and in Blau v. United States, 340 U.S. 332 (1951). In neither case, however, did the Court adopt the Wigmore view that the communications privilege be substituted in place of the privilege against adverse spousal testimony.
rationale: The Court references Blau to acknowledge its recognition of the confidential marital communications privilege and clarifies that today's holding does not disturb Blau, indicating neutral treatment.

quote: Geer v. Connecticut, 161 U. S. 519 (1896), on which the Court of Criminal Appeals relied, is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Geer v. Connecticut is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value.

cited_decision: Lacoste v. Department of Conservation of Louisiana
quote: Thus, despite its citation of Geer, Lacoste is actually more compatible with the cases following the views of the Justices dissenting in Geer.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Lacoste from Geer, noting that despite citing Geer, Lacoste's approach was actually more aligned with the dissenting views in Geer and compatible with later cases.

quote: Foster-Fountain Packing Co. v. Haydel, 278 U. S. 1 (1928), undermined Geer even more directly. A Louisiana statute forbade the transportation beyond the State of shrimp taken in Louisiana waters until the heads and shells had been removed.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Foster-Fountain Packing as part of the historical evolution that undermined Geer, providing additional analysis without questioning its precedential value.

cited_decision: H. P. Hood & Sons, Inc. v. Du Mond
quote: See H. P. Hood & Sons, Inc. v. Du Mond, 336 U. S. 525, 533-534 (1949). The Commerce Clause has accordingly been interpreted by this Court not only as an authorization for congressional action, but also, even in the absence of a conflicting federal statute, as a restriction on permissible state regulation.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites H. P. Hood & Sons as supportive authority for Commerce Clause interpretation without any negative treatment or criticism.

cited_decision: West v. Kansas Natural Gas Co.
quote: The erosion of Geer began only 15 years after it was decided. A Commerce Clause challenge was addressed to an Oklahoma statute designed to prohibit the transportation beyond the State of natural gas produced by wells within the State. West v. Kansas Natural Gas Co., 221 U. S. 229 (1911).
rationale: The Acting Decision references West v. Kansas Natural Gas Co. as part of the historical progression that eroded Geer, providing factual background without challenging its validity.

quote: Today's principle is that stated in Pike v. Bruce Church, Inc., 397 U. S. 137, 142 (1970): 'Where the statute regulates evenhandedly to effectuate a legitimate local public interest, and its effects on interstate commerce are only incidental, it will be upheld unless the burden imposed on such commerce is clearly excessive in relation to the putative local benefits.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Pike v. Bruce Church as establishing the current principle for Commerce Clause analysis, treating it as authoritative precedent.

quote: Douglas v. Seacoast Products, Inc., 431 U. S. 265 (1977), dispelled any doubts on that score. In rejecting the argument that Virginia's 'ownership' of fish swimming in its territorial waters empowered the State to forbid fishing by federally licensed ships owned by nonresidents while permitting residents to fish, Seacoast Products explicitly embraced the analysis of the Geer dissenters
rationale: The Acting Decision references Douglas v. Seacoast Products as supportive authority that further undermined Geer's rationale, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Baldwin v. Fish and Game Comm'n of Mont.
quote: For less than one year ago we unreservedly reaffirmed the principles announced in Geer. Baldwin v. Montana Fish & Game Comm'n, 436 U. S. 371, 386 (1978). Today, the Court overrules that decision.
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions Baldwin in the dissenting opinion as having recently reaffirmed Geer principles, providing context for the disagreement with the majority's overruling of Geer.

cited_decision: City of Philadelphia v. New Jersey
quote: This formulation was employed only last Term to strike down New Jersey's attempt to 'conserve' the natural resource of landfill areas within the State for the disposal of waste generated within the State. Philadelphia v. New Jersey, 437 U. S. 617, 624 (1978).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Philadelphia v. New Jersey as an example of applying the Pike test to strike down discriminatory state regulations, treating it as supportive precedent.

quote: Foster-Fountain Packing's implicit shift away from Geer's formalistic 'ownership' analysis became explicit in Toomer v. Witsell, 334 U. S. 385, 402 (1948), which struck down as violations of the Commerce Clause and the Privileges and Immunities Clause certain South Carolina laws discriminating against out-of-state commercial fishermen
rationale: The Acting Decision references Toomer v. Witsell as part of the historical progression that explicitly rejected Geer's ownership theory, providing supportive analysis without negative treatment.

cited_decision: State Ex Rel. Douglas v. Sporhase (1981)
quote: The judgment of the Nebraska Supreme Court is reversed, and the case is remanded for proceedings not inconsistent with this opinion.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly overturns the outcome of the Cited Decision, which is the Nebraska Supreme Court ruling in the same case that upheld the statute's constitutionality.

cited_decision: City of Altus, Oklahoma v. Carr (1966)
quote: In summarily affirming the District Court in City of Altus, we did not necessarily adopt the court's reasoning. Our affirmance indicates only our agreement with the result reached by the District Court.
rationale: The Acting Decision references the Cited Decision to clarify the scope of its prior summary affirmance without criticizing or questioning its precedential value.

cited_decision: Hudson County Water Co. v. McCarter (1908)
quote: City of Altus, however, is inconsistent with Hudson County. For in the latter case the Court found Geer v. Connecticut, supra, to be controlling on the Commerce Clause issue.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes the Cited Decision by noting its reliance on the now-overruled Geer doctrine and explaining how different state property law regimes lead to different Commerce Clause outcomes.

cited_decision: West v. Kansas Natural Gas Co. (1911)
quote: The city relied upon West v. Kansas Natural Gas Co., 221 U. S. 229 (1911), which invalidated an Oklahoma statute that prevented the interstate transfer of natural gas produced within the State
rationale: The Acting Decision references the Cited Decision as precedent relied upon by a party in another case, without any criticism or analysis of its continuing validity.

quote: In expressly overruling Geer three years ago, this Court traced the demise of the public ownership theory and definitively recast it as 'but a fiction expressive in legal shorthand of the importance to its people that a State have power to preserve and regulate the exploitation of an important resource.'
rationale: The Acting Decision merely notes that Geer was previously overruled by Hughes v. Oklahoma, without itself overruling or criticizing the decision.

quote: Our decision today is inconsistent with the disposition in Robbins v. California and with the portion of the opinion in Arkansas v. Sanders on which the plurality in Robbins relied. Nevertheless, the doctrine of stare decisis does not preclude this action. Although we have rejected some of the reasoning in Sanders, we adhere to our holding in that case
rationale: The Court explicitly states it rejects some of the reasoning in Sanders while adhering to its holding, indicating a limitation of Sanders' scope and applicability rather than complete overruling.

quote: In Carroll v. United States, 267 U. S. 132, the Court held that a warrantless search of an automobile stopped by police officers who had probable cause to believe the vehicle contained contraband was not unreasonable within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment.
rationale: The Court relies on and builds upon Carroll as foundational precedent for the automobile exception, using it as the basis for extending the warrantless search doctrine to containers within vehicles.

quote: Unlike Chadwick and Sanders, in this case police officers had probable cause to search respondent's entire vehicle.
rationale: The Court distinguishes Chadwick by noting that unlike in Chadwick, where police had probable cause only to search a specific container, here police had probable cause to search the entire vehicle, making the automobile exception applicable.

quote: Our decision today is inconsistent with the disposition in Robbins v. California... And the Court unambiguously overrules 'the disposition' of Robbins
rationale: The Court explicitly states that its decision is inconsistent with Robbins and unambiguously overrules the disposition in that case, directly nullifying its precedential value.

quote: In Chambers v. Maroney the police found weapons and stolen property 'concealed in a compartment under the dashboard.' 399 U. S., at 44. No suggestion was made that the scope of the search was impermissible.
rationale: The Court cites Chambers as supportive precedent for warrantless automobile searches, using it to support the proposition that searching compartments within vehicles is permissible under the automobile exception.

cited_decision: United States v. Albert Ross, Jr.
quote: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed. The case is remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
rationale: This is the lower court decision in the same case, and the Supreme Court explicitly reverses the Court of Appeals judgment, directly overturning the outcome of the cited decision.

quote: We have soundly rejected attempts to create such an exception in the past, see Coolidge v. New Hampshire, 403 U. S. 443 (1971), and we should do so again today.
rationale: The Court references Coolidge in the dissenting opinion as precedent that rejected a broad probable cause exception to the warrant requirement, using it to argue against the majority's approach.

quote: In Helvering v. Mitchell, 303 U. S. 391 (1938), the Court considered the preclusive effect of a prior criminal acquittal on a subsequent action for a monetary penalty... The disposition of the instant case follows readily from the principles articulated in Mitchell and One Lot Emerald Cut Stones.
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on and follows the principles established in Mitchell without criticizing or questioning its precedential value, using it as supportive authority for the court's analysis.

quote: As the Court noted in United States v. Ward, 448 U. S. 242, 248 (1980): 'Our inquiry in this regard has traditionally proceeded on two levels. First, we have set out to determine whether Congress, in establishing the penalizing mechanism, indicated either expressly or impliedly a preference for one label or the other.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Ward as established precedent and applies its two-prong test for determining whether a statutory scheme is civil or criminal in nature, treating it as authoritative guidance.

quote: In Kennedy v. Mendoza-Martinez, 372 U. S. 144, 168-169 (1963), we set forth a list of considerations that has proved helpful in the past in making such determinations.
rationale: The Acting Decision references the Mendoza-Martinez factors as established precedent and applies them to analyze whether the forfeiture statute is punitive, treating the decision as authoritative without criticism.

cited_decision: United States v. One Assortment of 89 Firearms, National Rifle Association of America, Amicus Curiae
quote: A divided United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, sitting en banc, reversed... We granted certiorari, 459 U. S. 1199 (1983), and we reverse.
rationale: This is the lower court decision in the same case that the Acting Decision directly overturns, as indicated by the Supreme Court's statement that it reverses the Fourth Circuit's judgment.

cited_decision: One Lot Emerald Cut Stones and One Ring v. United States
quote: Most recently, in One Lot Emerald Cut Stones v. United States, 409 U. S. 232 (1972) (per curiam), the Court held that a civil action for forfeiture of a ring and stones was not barred by the owner's prior acquittal... The disposition of the instant case follows readily from the principles articulated in Mitchell and One Lot Emerald Cut Stones.
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on and follows the principles established in One Lot Emerald Cut Stones as supportive precedent for its holding, treating it as authoritative without criticism.

quote: 'Only the clearest proof' that the purpose and effect of the forfeiture are punitive will suffice to override Congress' manifest preference for a civil sanction. Id., at 249 (quoting Flemming v. Nestor, 363 U. S. 603, 617 (1960)).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Flemming v. Nestor as established precedent for the standard requiring 'clearest proof' to override Congress' intent, using it as authoritative support without criticism.

quote: To the extent that Coffey v. United States suggests otherwise, it is hereby disapproved... we reject today the contrary rationale of Coffey v. United States, 116 U. S. 436 (1886).
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly disapproves and rejects the rationale of Coffey, stating that its analytical underpinnings have been recognized as inadequate and formally overruling its holding to the extent it conflicts with the current decision.

cited_decision: United States v. Yellow Cab Co.
quote: The Yellow Cab passage is most fairly read in light of this settled rule. In Yellow Cab, the affiliation of the defendants was irrelevant because the original acquisitions were themselves illegal. An affiliation 'flowing from an illegal conspiracy' would not avert sanctions. Common ownership and control were irrelevant because restraint of trade was 'the primary object of the combination,' which was created in a 'deliberate, calculated' manner.
rationale: The Acting Decision narrows the scope of Yellow Cab by interpreting it as applying only to cases where the original acquisitions were themselves illegal, rather than establishing a broad intra-enterprise conspiracy doctrine.

cited_decision: Timken Roller Bearing Co. v. United States
quote: The American defendant in Timken did not own a majority interest in either of the foreign corporate conspirators and, as the District Court found, it did not control them. Moreover, as in Yellow Cab, there was evidence that the stock acquisitions were themselves designed to effectuate restrictive practices. The Court's reliance on the intra-enterprise conspiracy doctrine was in no way necessary to the result.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Timken by noting that it involved corporations where the defendant did not have majority ownership or control, making it factually different from the parent-wholly owned subsidiary relationship at issue.

cited_decision: Kiefer-Stewart Co. v. Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, Inc.
quote: To the extent that prior decisions of this Court are to the contrary, they are disapproved and overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly overrules Kiefer-Stewart along with other prior decisions that supported the intra-enterprise conspiracy doctrine, as it directly contradicts the Court's new holding that parent corporations and wholly owned subsidiaries cannot conspire.

cited_decision: Perma Life Mufflers, Inc. v. International Parts Corp.
quote: But the Court noted immediately thereafter that '[i]n any event' each plaintiff could 'clearly' charge a combination between itself and the defendants or between the defendants and other franchise dealers. Thus, for the same reason that a finding of liability in Kiefer-Stewart could today be justified without reference to the intra-enterprise conspiracy doctrine, the doctrine was at most only an alternative holding in Perma Life Mufflers.
rationale: The Acting Decision limits Perma Life Mufflers by characterizing the intra-enterprise conspiracy doctrine as merely an alternative holding that was unnecessary to the result, thereby reducing its precedential value.

cited_decision: Appalachian Coals, Inc. v. United States
quote: However, examination of that case reveals that it gives very little support for the broad doctrine Yellow Cab has been thought to announce. On the contrary, the language of Chief Justice Hughes speaking for the Court in Appalachian Coals supports a contrary conclusion.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Appalachian Coals by arguing that it actually supports the opposite conclusion from what Yellow Cab suggested, thereby undermining the foundation for the intra-enterprise conspiracy doctrine.

cited_decision: United States v. Crescent Amusement Co.
quote: The Crescent Amusement Court, however, in affirming an order of divestiture, noted that such a remedy was appropriate when 'creation of the combination is itself the violation.' This suggests that both Crescent Amusement and Yellow Cab, which cited the very page on which this passage appears, stand for a narrow rule based on the original illegality of the affiliation.
rationale: The Acting Decision limits Crescent Amusement by interpreting it as standing only for a narrow rule applicable when the original creation of the corporate combination was itself illegal, rather than supporting a broad intra-enterprise conspiracy doctrine.

cited_decision: United States v. American Tobacco Co.
quote: A § 1 agreement may be found when 'the conspirators had a unity of purpose or a common design and understanding, or a meeting of minds in an unlawful arrangement.' American Tobacco Co. v. United States, 328 U.S. 781, 810 (1946).
rationale: The Acting Decision merely cites American Tobacco Co. for the definition of what constitutes a § 1 agreement, without any negative treatment or criticism of the decision itself.

cited_decision: United States v. Parke, Davis & Co.
quote: A theory of combination between the subsidiaries and the wholesalers could now support § 1 relief, whether or not it could have when Kiefer-Stewart was decided. See Albrecht v. Herald Co., 390 U.S. 145, 149-150, and n. 6 (1968); United States v. Parke, Davis & Co., 362 U.S. 29 (1960).
rationale: The Acting Decision simply cites Parke Davis as support for the proposition that certain theories of combination could support § 1 relief, without any criticism or negative treatment of the decision.

cited_decision: Independence Tube Corporation v. Copperweld Corporation
quote: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly reverses the Court of Appeals decision, which had affirmed liability based on the intra-enterprise conspiracy doctrine that the Supreme Court now rejects.

cited_decision: National League of Cities v. Usery
quote: National League of Cities v. Usery, 426 U. S. 833 (1976), is overruled.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that National League of Cities is overruled, finding its 'traditional governmental function' standard unworkable and inconsistent with federalism principles.

cited_decision: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission v. Wyoming
quote: See EEOC v. Wyoming, 460 U. S. 226, 248 (1983) (concurring opinion).
rationale: The decision is cited for reference without significant discussion or analysis that would affect its precedential value.

cited_decision: Hodel v. Virginia Surface Mining & Reclamation Assn., Inc.
quote: The prerequisites for governmental immunity under National League of Cities were summarized by this Court in Hodel, supra.
rationale: The decision is referenced to explain the four-part test for governmental immunity under National League of Cities, without criticism or negative treatment.

cited_decision: United Transportation Union v. Long Island Rail Road
quote: The only other case in which the Court has had occasion to address the problem is Long Island.
rationale: The decision is discussed as an example of the Court's difficulty in applying the 'traditional governmental function' standard, but without negative treatment of the decision itself.

quote: It was this uncertainty and instability that led the Court shortly thereafter, in New York v. United States, 326 U. S. 572 (1946), unanimously to conclude that the distinction between 'governmental' and 'proprietary' functions was 'untenable' and must be abandoned.
rationale: The decision is cited approvingly as support for abandoning the governmental/proprietary distinction in tax immunity cases, which parallels the Court's reasoning for overruling National League of Cities.

cited_decision: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission v. Mississippi
quote: See EEOC v. Wyoming, 460 U. S. 226 (1983); FERC v. Mississippi, 456 U. S. 742 (1982).
rationale: The decision is cited as an example of federal encroachment on state activities, but without any negative treatment of the decision itself.

quote: Many constitutional standards involve 'undoubte[d] . . . gray areas,' Fry v. United States, 421 U. S. 542, 558 (1975) (dissenting opinion).
rationale: The decision is cited for the general proposition that constitutional standards often involve gray areas, without any treatment affecting its precedential value.

quote: The application of the FLSA to public schools and hospitals was ruled to be within Congress' power under the Commerce Clause. Maryland v. Wirtz, 392 U. S. 183 (1968).
rationale: The decision is mentioned factually as having been overruled by National League of Cities, but the Acting Decision does not itself treat Maryland v. Wirtz negatively.

cited_decision: San Antonio Metropolitan Transit Authority v. Donovan
quote: The judgment of the District Court therefore must be reversed.
rationale: This is the lower court decision in the same case, and the Supreme Court explicitly reverses the District Court's judgment that granted summary judgment to SAMTA.

quote: In Powers, the Court upheld the application of the federal income tax to the income of trustees of a state-operated commuter railroad.
rationale: The decision is cited as an example in the discussion of the governmental/proprietary distinction in tax immunity cases, without any negative treatment.

quote: In South Carolina v. United States, 199 U. S. 437 (1905), the Court held for the first time that the state tax immunity recognized in Collector v. Day, 11 Wall. 113 (1871), extended only to the 'ordinary' and 'strictly governmental' instrumentalities of state governments.
rationale: The decision is discussed as part of the historical development of the governmental/proprietary distinction in tax immunity cases, without negative treatment.

quote: To the extent Bain stands for the proposition that it constitutes an unconstitutional amendment to drop from an indictment those allegations that are unnecessary to an offense that is clearly contained within it, that case has simply not survived. To avoid further confusion, we now explicitly reject that proposition.
rationale: The Court explicitly rejects one aspect of Bain while preserving its general proposition about impermissible additions to indictments, thus limiting the scope and applicability of the Bain decision.

quote: Stirone, however, stands for a very different proposition. In Stirone the offense proved at trial was not fully contained in the indictment, for trial evidence had 'amended' the indictment by broadening the possible bases for conviction from that which appeared in the indictment. Stirone was thus wholly unlike the cases discussed in Part II, supra, and unlike respondent's case, all of which involve trial evidence that narrowed the indictment's charges without adding any new offenses.
rationale: The Court distinguishes Stirone by explaining that it involved broadening an indictment with new offenses, whereas the current case involves narrowing without adding new offenses, making the factual situations materially different.

cited_decision: United States v. James Rual Miller
quote: The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit agreed and vacated the judgment of conviction. 715 F. 2d 1360 (1983), modified, 728 F. 2d 1269 (1984). We granted certiorari, 469 U. S. 814 (1984), and reverse.
rationale: The Supreme Court directly overturns the Court of Appeals decision that had vacated Miller's conviction, reversing the lower court's ruling in the same case.

quote: Cf. Kotteakos v. United States, 328 U. S. 750 (1946). See also Berger v. United States, 295 U. S. 78, 83 (1935).
rationale: The Court merely cites Berger as supporting authority without significant discussion or analysis, using it as a reference point for established legal principles.

quote: See Russell v. United States, 369 U. S. 749, 763-764 (1962).
rationale: The Court cites Russell as supporting authority for notice-related concerns underlying indictment requirements without extensive discussion or analysis of the case.

quote: That our holding today is fully consistent with prior legal understanding is apparent from an examination of the state of the law, as seen by Chief Justice Stone, more than 40 years ago: 'An indictment is amended when it is so altered as to charge a different offense from that found by the grand jury. Ex parte Bain, 121 U. S. 1 . But here there was no alteration of the indictment, Salinger v. United States, 272 U. S. 542, 549...' United States v. Ballard, 322 U. S., at 90-91 (dissenting).
rationale: The Court quotes Chief Justice Stone's dissenting opinion in Ballard to support its holding, using it as historical authority for the legal principle being applied.

quote: In Salinger v. United States, supra, for example, the Court was presented with facts quite similar to the instant case... This Court unanimously rejected Salinger's argument on the ground that the offense proved was fully contained within the indictment.
rationale: The Court discusses Salinger as precedential support for its holding, explaining how the facts are similar and how Salinger supports the current decision without questioning its validity.

cited_decision: Complete Auto Transit, Inc. v. Brady
quote: We agree with appellants that the Montana tax must be evaluated under Complete Auto Transit's four-part test. Under that test, a state tax does not offend the Commerce Clause if it 'is applied to an activity with a substantial nexus with the taxing State, is fairly apportioned, does not discriminate against interstate commerce, and is fairly related to services provided by the State.'
rationale: The Acting Decision applies the Complete Auto Transit test as the established framework for evaluating Commerce Clause challenges to state taxes, without criticizing or questioning its validity.

cited_decision: Department of Revenue v. Ass'n of Washington Stevedoring Companies
quote: As the Court has stated, ''[e]ven interstate business must pay its way.'' Western Live Stock v. Bureau of Revenue, 303 U. S. 250, 254 (1938), quoting Postal Telegraph-Cable Co. v. Richmond, 249 U. S. 252, 259 (1919). Consequently, the Heisler Court's concern that a loss of state taxing authority would be an inevitable result of subjecting taxes on 'local' activities to Commerce Clause scrutiny is no longer tenable.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case as support for the principle that interstate commerce must pay its fair share of state tax burden, using it to reinforce established precedent.

quote: On appeal, the Montana Supreme Court affirmed the judgment of the trial court. -Mont.-, 615 P. 2d 847 (1980). The Supreme Court held that the tax is not subject to scrutiny under the Commerce Clause because it is imposed on the severance of coal, which the court characterized as an intrastate activity preceding entry of the coal into interstate commerce.
rationale: The Acting Decision references the lower court decision being reviewed, describing its holding without expressing agreement or disagreement with its reasoning.

quote: When a tax is assessed in proportion to a taxpayer's activities or presence in a State, the taxpayer is shouldering its fair share of supporting the State's provision of 'police and fire protection, the benefit of a trained work force, and the advantages of a civilized society.' Exxon Corp. v. Wisconsin Dept. of Revenue, 447 U. S., at 228, quoting Japan Line, Ltd. v. County of Los Angeles, 441 U. S., at 445. Cf. Nippert v. Richmond, 327 U. S., at 427.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Nippert as supporting authority for the principle that proportional taxes allow taxpayers to shoulder their fair share of governmental costs.

quote: But the Montana tax is computed at the same rate regardless of the final destination of the coal, and there is no suggestion here that the tax is administered in a manner that departs from this evenhanded formula. We are not, therefore, confronted here with the type of differential tax treatment of interstate and intrastate commerce that the Court has found in other 'discrimination' cases. See, e. g., Maryland v. Louisiana, 451 U. S. 725 (1981).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Maryland v. Louisiana as an example of a discrimination case, distinguishing the present case from situations involving differential tax treatment.

cited_decision: Western Live Stock v. Bureau of Revenue
quote: As the Court has stated, ''[e]ven interstate business must pay its way.'' Western Live Stock v. Bureau of Revenue, 303 U. S. 250, 254 (1938), quoting Postal Telegraph-Cable Co. v. Richmond, 249 U. S. 252, 259 (1919).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Western Live Stock as established precedent supporting the principle that interstate commerce must bear its fair share of state tax burden.

quote: As we explained in General Motors Corp. v. Washington, supra, at 440-441: '[T]he validity of the tax rests upon whether the State is exacting a constitutionally fair demand for that aspect of interstate commerce to which it bears a special relation.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites General Motors as supporting precedent for the principle that tax validity depends on whether the state's demand is constitutionally fair in relation to the interstate commerce activity.

quote: Consequently, in reviewing appellants' contentions, we put to one side those cases in which the Court reviewed challenges to 'user' fees or 'taxes' that were designed and defended as a specific charge imposed by the State for the use of state-owned or state-provided transportation or other facilities and services. See, e. g., Evansville-Vanderburgh Airport Authority Dist. v. Delta Airlines, Inc., 405 U. S. 707 (1972); Clark v. Paul Cray, Inc., 306 U. S. 583 (1939).
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Clark v. Paul Gray as involving user fees rather than general revenue taxes, setting it aside as not applicable to the present case.

quote: We agree that Heisler's reasoning has been undermined by more recent cases. The Heisler analysis evolved at a time when the Commerce Clause was thought to prohibit the States from imposing any direct taxes on interstate commerce... We therefore hold that a state severance tax is not immunized from Commerce Clause scrutiny by a claim that the tax is imposed on goods prior to their entry into the stream of interstate commerce. Any contrary statements in Heisler and its progeny are disapproved.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Heisler's reasoning has been undermined and disapproves contrary statements in Heisler, indicating criticism of its approach while acknowledging it was not necessarily wrongly decided at the time.

cited_decision: Michigan-Wisconsin Pipe Line Co. v. Calvert
quote: Correspondingly, when the measure of a tax bears no relationship to the taxpayers' presence or activities in a State, a court may properly conclude under the fourth prong of the Complete Auto Transit test that the State is imposing an undue burden on interstate commerce. See Nippert v. Richmond, 327 U. S., at 427; cf. Michigan-Wisconsin Pipe Line Co. v. Calvert, 347 U. S. 157 (1954).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Michigan-Wisconsin Pipe Line Co. v. Calvert as an example of when a court may find an undue burden on interstate commerce when tax measures bear no relationship to taxpayer activities in the state.

quote: Consequently, in reviewing appellants' contentions, we put to one side those cases in which the Court reviewed challenges to 'user' fees or 'taxes' that were designed and defended as a specific charge imposed by the State for the use of state-owned or state-provided transportation or other facilities and services. See, e. g., Evansville-Vanderburgh Airport Authority Dist. v. Delta Airlines, Inc., 405 U. S. 707 (1972); Clark v. Paul Cray, Inc., 306 U. S. 583 (1939); Ingels v. Morf, 300 U. S. 290 (1937).
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Ingels v. Morf as involving user fees rather than general revenue taxes, setting it aside as not applicable to the present case involving a general revenue tax.

quote: Upon reflection, we agree and overrule Parratt to the extent that it states that mere lack of due care by a state official may 'deprive' an individual of life, liberty, or property under the Fourteenth Amendment.
rationale: The Court explicitly overrules part of Parratt while maintaining other aspects, thereby limiting its scope and applicability regarding negligent conduct constituting a constitutional deprivation.

quote: Hudson v. Palmer, 468 U. S. 517 (1984) (intentional destruction of inmate's property)
rationale: The decision is cited as an example of deliberate government action that constitutes a deprivation under the Due Process Clause, without any negative treatment or criticism.

quote: Ingraham v. Wright, 430 U. S. 651 (1977) (paddling student)
rationale: The decision is cited as an example of deliberate government action that constitutes a deprivation under the Due Process Clause, and also referenced regarding historical protections, without any negative treatment.

quote: Medical malpractice does not become a constitutional violation merely because the victim is a prisoner
rationale: The decision is cited approvingly to support the principle that not all injuries to prisoners constitute constitutional violations, reinforcing the Court's reasoning.

quote: The touchstone of due process is protection of the individual against arbitrary action of government
rationale: The decision is cited to support the Court's understanding of the fundamental purpose of due process protection, without any criticism or limitation.

quote: false imprisonment does not become a violation of the Fourteenth Amendment merely because the defendant is a state official
rationale: The decision is cited approvingly to support the principle that state official status alone does not transform ordinary torts into constitutional violations.

cited_decision: South v. Maryland Ex Rel. Pottle
quote: We read South v. Maryland, supra, an action brought under federal diversity jurisdiction on a Maryland sheriff's bond, as stating no more than what this Court thought to be the principles of common law and Maryland law applicable to that case; it is not cast at all in terms of constitutional law
rationale: The Court distinguishes this case by explaining it was decided on common law grounds rather than constitutional principles, rejecting petitioner's attempt to use it as constitutional authority.

quote: As explained in Monroe v. Pape, 365 U. S. 167 (1961), this conclusion derives from the fact that the statute — the Ku Klux Act of 1871 — was intended to provide a federal remedy for the violation of a federal constitutional right.
rationale: The decision is cited in Justice Stevens' concurrence to explain the purpose and scope of § 1983, without any negative treatment or criticism.

quote: See, e. g., Groppi v. Leslie, 404 U. S. 496 (1972); In re Oliver, 333 U. S. 257 (1948).
rationale: The decision is cited as an example of procedural due process requirements in Justice Stevens' concurrence, without any negative treatment.

quote: In Martinez v. California, 444 U. S. 277 (1980), we held that California's immunity statute did not violate the Due Process Clause simply because it operated to defeat a tort claim arising under state law.
rationale: The decision is cited in Justice Stevens' concurrence to support the principle that sovereign immunity defenses do not necessarily render state procedures constitutionally inadequate.

quote: The judgment of the Supreme Court of Alabama is reversed, and the cause remanded for further proceedings not inconsistent with this opinion.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly overturns the outcome of the Alabama Supreme Court's decision in Ex Parte Smith, which had held that a presumption of vindictiveness applied when a sentence was increased after trial following a guilty plea.

quote: While the Pearce opinion appeared on its face to announce a rule of sweeping dimension, our subsequent cases have made clear that its presumption of vindictiveness 'do[es] not apply in every case where a convicted defendant receives a higher sentence on retrial.'
rationale: The Acting Decision narrows the scope and applicability of Pearce by holding that its presumption of vindictiveness does not apply when the first sentence was based on a guilty plea and the second follows a trial.

quote: In Colten v. Kentucky, 407 U. S. 104 (1972), for example, we refused to apply the presumption when the increased sentence was imposed by the second court in a two-tiered system which gave a defendant convicted of a misdemeanor in an inferior court the right to trial de novo in a superior court.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Colten as supportive precedent for limiting the Pearce presumption, using it to illustrate circumstances where the presumption does not apply without criticizing or questioning its validity.

quote: As we explained in Texas v. McCullough, 'the evil the [Pearce] Court sought to prevent' was not the imposition of 'enlarged sentences after a new trial' but 'vindictiveness of a sentencing judge.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites McCullough as authority for the principle that the Pearce presumption is designed to prevent vindictiveness rather than all increased sentences, using it to support the court's reasoning without any negative treatment.

quote: Because the Pearce presumption 'may operate in the absence of any proof of an improper motive and thus . . . block a legitimate response to criminal conduct,' United States v. Goodwin, supra, at 373, we have limited its application
rationale: The Acting Decision references Goodwin to support its reasoning about limiting the application of the Pearce presumption, citing it as authority without any criticism or negative treatment.

quote: On reexamination of O'Callahan, we have decided that the service connection test announced in that decision should be abandoned... Our conclusion is that the case of Adkins v. Children's Hospital, supra, should be, and it is, overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it has decided to abandon the service connection test from O'Callahan and directly overrules the precedent, nullifying its precedential value.

cited_decision: United States Ex Rel. Toth v. Quarles
quote: One pre-1969 decision of this Court suggests that the constitutional power of Congress to authorize trial by court-martial must be limited to 'the least possible power adequate to the end proposed.' United States ex rel. Toth v. Quarles, 350 U. S. 11, 23 (1955)... Yet the Court in Toth v. Quarles was addressing only the question whether an ex-serviceman may be tried by court-martial for crimes committed while serving in the Air Force. Thus, the dictum may be also interpreted as limited to that context.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Toth v. Quarles by noting that it addressed a different factual situation (ex-servicemen) and interprets the cited language as limited to that specific context rather than applying broadly.

cited_decision: Relford v. Commandant, U. S. Disciplinary Barracks
quote: Since O'Callahan and Relford, military courts have identified numerous categories of offenses requiring specialized analysis of the service connection requirement... The confusion created by the complexity of the service connection requirement, however, is perhaps best illustrated in the area of off-base drug offenses... When considered together with the doubtful foundations of O'Callahan, the confusion wrought by the decision leads us to conclude that we should read Clause 14 in accord with the plain meaning of its language as we did in the many years before O'Callahan was decided.
rationale: The Acting Decision overrules Relford along with O'Callahan, criticizing the confusion and complexity created by the service connection requirement established in both cases and abandoning their approach entirely.

quote: This view was premised on what the Court described as the 'natural meaning' of Art. I, § 8, cl. 14, as well as the Fifth Amendment's exception for 'cases arising in the land or naval forces.' Reid v. Covert, supra, at 19; United States ex rel. Toth v. Quarles, supra, at 15.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Reid v. Covert to support its historical analysis of court-martial jurisdiction based on military status, using it as authority for the constitutional interpretation without criticizing or questioning its precedential value.

cited_decision: Kinsella v. United States Ex Rel. Singleton
quote: As explained in Kinsella v. Singleton, supra: 'The test for jurisdiction ... is one of status, namely, whether the accused in the court-martial proceeding is a person who can be regarded as falling within the term 'land and naval Forces.'... 'Without contradiction, the materials ... show that military jurisdiction has always been based on the 'status' of the accused, rather than on the nature of the offense.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Kinsella favorably to support its argument that military jurisdiction should be based on status rather than service connection, using it as precedential authority without any negative treatment.

quote: Implicit in the military status test was the principle that determinations concerning the scope of court-martial jurisdiction over offenses committed by servicemen was a matter reserved for Congress... See also Coleman v. Tennessee, supra, at 514; Warren, The Bill of Rights and the Military, 37 N. Y. U. L. Rev. 181, 187 (1962).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Coleman v. Tennessee as supporting authority for the principle that Congress has primary responsibility for determining court-martial jurisdiction, citing it without any criticism or limitation of its precedential value.

cited_decision: Garcia v. San Antonio Metropolitan Transit Authority
quote: The Tenth Amendment limits on Congress' authority to regulate state activities are set out in Garcia v. San Antonio Metropolitan Transit Authority, 469 U. S. 528 (1985). Garcia holds that the limits are structural, not substantive— i. e., that States must find their protection from congressional regulation through the national political process, not through judicially defined spheres of unregulable state activity.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Garcia as establishing the controlling framework for Tenth Amendment analysis without criticizing or questioning its validity, using it as the foundation for its constitutional analysis.

quote: All federal activities are immune from direct state taxation, see Graves, 306 U. S., at 477 , but at least some state activities have always been subject to direct federal taxation. For a time, only the States' governmental, as opposed to proprietary, activities enjoyed tax immunity, see e. g., Helvering v. Powers, 293 U. S. 214, 227 (1934); South Carolina v. United States, 199 U. S. 437, 454-463 (1905), but this distinction was subsequently abandoned as untenable by all eight Justices participating in New York v. United States, 326 U. S. 572 (1946).
rationale: The Acting Decision references New York v. United States as part of the historical development of tax immunity doctrine, noting how it abandoned the governmental/proprietary distinction without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Graves v. New York Ex Rel. O'Keefe
quote: In Graves v. New York ex rel. O'Keefe, 306 U. S. 466 (1939), the Court announced: 'The theory . . . that a tax on income is legally or economically a tax on its source, is no longer tenable.' Id., at 480.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Graves as establishing important precedent that rejected the burden theory underlying earlier tax immunity cases, using it to support the Court's reasoning without any negative treatment.

quote: Prior to that the Court had already confined Collector v. Day to its facts in Helvering v. Gerhardt, 304 U. S. 405 (1938), which upheld the constitutionality of a federal tax on the salaries of state employees involved in state construction projects.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Helvering v. Gerhardt as part of the historical progression of intergovernmental tax immunity doctrine, noting how it limited earlier precedent without any criticism of the decision itself.

cited_decision: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission v. Mississippi
quote: Because, by hypothesis, § 310 effectively prohibits issuing unregistered bonds, it presents the very situation FERC distinguished from a commandeering of state regulatory machinery: the extent to which the Tenth Amendment 'shields the States from generally applicable federal regulations.' 456 U. S., at 759 . Section 310 regulates state activities; it does not, as did the statute in FERC , seek to control or influence the manner in which States regulate private parties.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes FERC by explaining that the current case involves different facts and legal principles - direct regulation of state activities rather than commandeering of state regulatory machinery.

cited_decision: Indian Motocycle Co. v. United States
quote: The commonality of the rationale underlying all these immunities for government contracts was highlighted by Indian Motocycle, 283 U. S. 570 (1931). In that case, the Court reviewed the then current status of intergovernmental tax immunity doctrine, observing that a tax on interest earned on a state or federal bond was unconstitutional because it would burden the exercise of the government's power to borrow money
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Indian Motocycle as part of the historical development of tax immunity doctrine, explaining how it applied the burden theory that was later rejected, without any negative treatment of the decision itself.

cited_decision: Pollock v. Farmers' Loan & Trust Co.
quote: We thus confirm that subsequent case law has overruled the holding in Pollock that state bond interest is immune from a nondiscriminatory federal tax.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it is overruling Pollock's holding that state bond interest is immune from federal taxation, directly nullifying the precedential value of that aspect of the Cited Decision.

cited_decision: Brown-Forman Distillers Corp. v. New York State Liquor Authority
quote: This Court agreed, reaffirming and elaborating on our established view that a state law that has the 'practical effect' of regulating commerce occurring wholly outside that State's borders is invalid under the Commerce Clause.
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on Brown-Forman as established precedent to support its analysis and applies its principles without criticism or limitation.

cited_decision: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, Inc. v. Hostetter
quote: In the interest of removing any lingering uncertainty about the constitutional validity of affirmation statutes and of avoiding further litigation on the subject of liquor-price affirmation, we recognize today what was all but determined in Brown-Forman: to the extent that Seagram holds that retrospective affirmation statutes do not facially violate the Commerce Clause, it is no longer good law.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Seagram is 'no longer good law' to the extent it held that retrospective affirmation statutes do not violate the Commerce Clause, thereby overruling that portion of the decision.

cited_decision: Baldwin v. G. A. F. Seelig, Inc.
quote: We began by reviewing past decisions, starting with Baldwin v. G. A. F. Seelig, Inc., 294 U. S. 511 (1935). The Court in Seelig struck down a New York statute that set minimum prices for milk purchased from producers in New York and other States and banned the resale within New York of milk that had been purchased for a lower price.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Baldwin as established precedent and applies its principles favorably without any negative treatment, using it to support the constitutional analysis.

quote: First, the 'Commerce Clause . . . precludes the application of a state statute to commerce that takes place wholly outside of the State's borders, whether or not the commerce has effects within the State,' Edgar v. MITE Corp., 457 U. S. 624, 642-643 (1982) (plurality opinion)
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Edgar v. MITE Corp. as supporting authority for the principle that the Commerce Clause precludes application of state statutes to wholly out-of-state commerce, without any negative treatment.

quote: As in Healy I, the Court of Appeals reversed. It held that the 1984 law (even as interpreted by the declaratory ruling), like its predecessor, violated the Commerce Clause by controlling the prices at which out-of-state shippers could sell beer in other States.
rationale: The Acting Decision references the Court of Appeals decision (Healy II) as part of the procedural history and factual background, affirming its judgment without criticism.

cited_decision: United States Brewers Ass'n v. Healy
quote: On cross-motions for summary judgment, the District Court upheld the statute as modified by the legislature and construed in the Department of Liquor Control's declaratory ruling, resting its decision on Seagram, supra, and distinguishing this Court's subsequent decision in Brown-Forman
rationale: The Acting Decision references this District Court decision as part of the procedural history, noting its ruling without expressing agreement or disagreement with its analysis.

quote: To the extent that Thompson v. Utah rested on the Ex Post Facto Clause and not the Sixth Amendment, we overrule it.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that it overrules Thompson v. Utah to the extent it relied on the Ex Post Facto Clause, finding that the right to jury trial is not related to the definition of crimes, defenses, or punishments which is the concern of the Ex Post Facto Clause.

quote: So well accepted were these principles that the Court in Beazell v. Ohio, 269 U. S. 167 (1925), was able to confidently summarize the meaning of the Clause as follows: 'It is settled, by decisions of this Court so well known that their citation may be dispensed with, that any statute which punishes as a crime an act previously committed, which was innocent when done; which makes more burdensome the punishment for a crime, after its commission, or which deprives one charged with crime of any defense available according to law at the time when the act was committed, is prohibited as ex post facto.'
rationale: The Court cites Beazell favorably as providing an authoritative summary of the Ex Post Facto Clause's meaning and uses it as support for the traditional understanding of the clause without criticizing or questioning its precedential value.

quote: We accordingly overrule Kring.
rationale: The Court explicitly overrules Kring v. Missouri, finding that its departure from Calder's explanation of the original understanding of the Ex Post Facto Clause was unjustified and that its broad reading of the clause departs from the meaning as understood at the time of the Constitution's adoption.

quote: In April 1985, the District Court, feeling bound by Bogany, recommended that the writ be granted.
rationale: The Court references Bogany v. State as factual background to explain the procedural history of the case and the legal context that led to the Texas legislature's enactment of the new statute, without expressing any criticism or disagreement with the decision itself.

quote: The references in Duncan and Malloy to 'substantial protections' and 'personal rights' should not be read to adopt without explanation an undefined enlargement of the Ex Post Facto Clause.
rationale: The Court limits the scope and applicability of Malloy v. South Carolina by clarifying that its references to 'substantial protections' and 'personal rights' should not be interpreted as expanding the Ex Post Facto Clause beyond the traditional Calder categories.

quote: In light of these same concerns, we now hold that regulations affecting the sending of a 'publication' (see the regulations' specific definition of this word, n. 4, supra) to a prisoner must be analyzed under the Turner reasonableness standard... Furthermore, we acknowledge today that the logic of our analyses in Martinez and Turner requires that Martinez be limited to regulations concerning outgoing correspondence... To the extent that Martinez itself suggests such a distinction, we today overrule that case; the Court accomplished much of this step when it decided Turner.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly limits Martinez to outgoing correspondence only and overrules it to the extent it would apply to incoming publications, thus narrowing the scope and applicability of the Cited Decision.

quote: We now hold that the District Court correctly anticipated that the proper inquiry in this case is whether the regulations are 'reasonably related to legitimate penological interests,' Turner v. Safley, 482 U. S. 78, 89 (1987), and we conclude that under this standard the regulations are facially valid.
rationale: The Acting Decision adopts and applies the Turner standard as the appropriate test for reviewing prison regulations, providing additional analysis and elaboration without questioning its precedential value.

cited_decision: Jones v. North Carolina Prisoners' Labor Union, Inc.
quote: The Court's subsequent decisions regarding First Amendment rights in the prison context, however, laid down a different standard of review from that articulated in Martinez. As recently explained in Turner, these later decisions, which we characterized as involving 'prisoners' rights,' adopted a standard of review that focuses on the reasonableness of prison regulations
rationale: The Acting Decision references Jones as one of the cases that established the reasonableness standard for prisoners' rights cases, using it to support the development of constitutional doctrine without criticism.

quote: The Court set forth in Turner the development of this reasonableness standard in the respective decisions in Pell and Jones and in Block v. Rutherford, 468 U. S. 576 (1984), and we need not repeat that discussion here.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Pell as part of the historical development of the reasonableness standard without significant discussion or criticism of its holding.

cited_decision: Jack Abbott v. Edwin Meese, Iii, Attorney General of the United States
quote: We therefore disagree with the Court of Appeals on the issue of facial validity, but we agree with that court's remand of the case to the District Court for a determination of the validity of the regulations as applied to each of the 46 publications... The judgment of the Court of Appeals is vacated, and the case is remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly overturns the Court of Appeals' finding that the regulations were facially invalid, vacating the judgment and remanding with different instructions.

quote: nor do they bar free citizens from exercising their own constitutional rights by reaching out to those on the 'inside,' id., at 94-99; Bell v. Wolfish, 441 U. S. 520 (1979); Jones v. North Carolina Prisoners' Labor Union, Inc., 433 U. S. 119 (1977); Pell v. Procunier, 417 U. S. 817 (1974).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Bell v. Wolfish as supporting precedent for the principle that citizens retain constitutional rights when communicating with prisoners, without significant analysis or criticism.

cited_decision: Exxon Corp. v. Central Gulf Lines, Inc. (1989)
quote: The District Court noted that '[a] prerequisite to the existence of a maritime lien based on a breach of contract is that the subject matter of the contract must fall within the admiralty jurisdiction.' 707 F. Supp. 155, 158 (SDNY 1989).
rationale: The Acting Decision references the District Court's opinion as part of the procedural history and factual background, without any criticism or negative treatment of its reasoning.

quote: In determining the boundaries of admiralty jurisdiction, we look to the purpose of the grant. See Insurance Co. v. Dunham, 11 Wall. 1, 24 (1871).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Dunham positively as authority for the principle that courts should look to the purpose of admiralty jurisdiction grants, and uses it to support the current approach to determining admiralty jurisdiction.

quote: In Archawski, supra, the Court held that an action cognizable as assumpsit would no longer be automatically excluded from admiralty. Rather, 'admiralty has jurisdiction, even where the libel reads like indebitatus assumpsit at common law, provided that the unjust enrichment arose as a result of the breach of a maritime contract.' 350 U. S., at 536.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Archawski positively to show how one of Minturn's rationales has been discredited, using it as support for overruling Minturn.

quote: We conclude that Minturn is incompatible with current principles of admiralty jurisdiction over contracts and therefore should be overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Minturn should be overruled because its theoretical underpinnings are no longer valid law and its approach is inconsistent with modern admiralty principles.

quote: In United States v. Ross, 456 U. S. 798, decided in 1982, we held that a warrantless search of an automobile under the Carroll doctrine could include a search of a container or package found inside the car when such a search was supported by probable cause.
rationale: The Court extensively discusses Ross as establishing precedent for automobile searches including containers, using it as foundational authority without criticizing or limiting its holding.

quote: We conclude that it is better to adopt one clear-cut rule to govern automobile searches and eliminate the warrant requirement for closed containers set forth in Sanders.
rationale: The Court narrows the scope and applicability of Chadwick by eliminating the warrant requirement it established for closed containers, choosing not to comply with Chadwick's rule in the automobile context.

quote: Sanders was explicitly undermined in Ross, 456 U. S., at 824, and the existence of the dual regimes for automobile searches that uncover containers has proved as confusing as the Chadwick and Sanders dissenters predicted. We conclude that it is better to adopt one clear-cut rule to govern automobile searches and eliminate the warrant requirement for closed containers set forth in Sanders.
rationale: The Court expressly nullifies Sanders by eliminating the warrant requirement it established for closed containers, explicitly stating that Sanders has been undermined and adopting a rule that directly contradicts Sanders' holding.

quote: In United States v. Johns, 469 U. S. 478 (1985), Customs agents saw two trucks drive to a private airstrip and approach two small planes. The agents drew near the trucks, smelled marijuana, and then saw in the backs of the trucks packages wrapped in a manner that marijuana smugglers customarily employed.
rationale: The Court references Johns as an example supporting its position without criticizing or questioning its precedential value, using it to illustrate the application of existing doctrine.

quote: In Carroll, this Court established an exception to the warrant requirement for moving vehicles, for it recognized 'a necessary difference between a search of a store, dwelling house or other structure in respect of which a proper official warrant readily may be obtained, and a search of a ship, motor boat, wagon or automobile, for contraband goods, where it is not practicable to secure a warrant because the vehicle can be quickly moved out of the locality or jurisdiction in which the warrant must be sought.'
rationale: The Court cites Carroll as foundational precedent for the automobile exception without any negative treatment, relying on it as established authority for warrantless vehicle searches.

quote: In his opinion for the Court in Johnson v. United States, id., at 13-14, Justice Jackson explained: 'The point of the Fourth Amendment, which often is not grasped by zealous officers, is not that it denies law enforcement the support of the usual inferences which reasonable men draw from evidence. Its protection consists in requiring that those inferences be drawn by a neutral and detached magistrate instead of being judged by the officer engaged in the often competitive enterprise of ferreting out crime.'
rationale: The Court references Johnson in the dissenting opinion to explain the warrant requirement without any negative treatment, using it as authority for the principle of neutral magistrate review.

quote: The Court refined the exigency requirement in Chambers v. Maroney, 399 U. S. 42 (1970), when it held that the existence of exigent circumstances was to be determined at the time the automobile is seized.
rationale: The Court cites Chambers as precedent that refined the automobile exception doctrine without any criticism, treating it as established authority for determining exigent circumstances.

quote: The first case cited by the dissent, United States v. Place, 462 U. S. 696 (1983), however, did not involve an automobile at all. We considered in Place the temporary detention of luggage in an airport. Not only was no automobile involved, but the defendant, Place, was waiting at the airport to board his plane rather than preparing to leave the airport in a car.
rationale: The Court distinguishes Place by noting it involved different facts (airport luggage detention rather than automobile searches) and therefore requires different legal analysis, making it inapposite to the current case.

quote: See also Robbins v. California, 453 U. S. 420, 425-426 (1981) (listing cases decided by Federal Courts of Appeals since Chadwick had been announced).
rationale: The Court briefly references Robbins as an example of cases showing confusion in the lower courts following Chadwick, without any significant analysis or criticism of Robbins itself.

quote: Again addressing the issue of state procedural default in Coleman v. Thompson, 501 U. S. 722 (1991), we described Fay as based on a conception of federal/state relations that undervalued the importance of state procedural rules, 501 U. S., at 750, and went on to hold that the cause-and-prejudice standard applicable to failure to raise a particular claim should apply as well to failure to appeal at all.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Coleman v. Thompson as support for applying the cause-and-prejudice standard uniformly to state procedural defaults, using it to build the foundation for the Court's reasoning without criticizing or questioning its precedential value.

quote: However, in light of more recent decisions of this Court, Townsend's holding in this respect must be overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Townsend's holding regarding the deliberate bypass standard must be overruled, directly nullifying that part of the precedent.

quote: In McCleskey v. Zant, 499 U. S. 467 (1991), we held that the same standard used to excuse state procedural defaults should be applied in habeas corpus cases where abuse of the writ is claimed by the government.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites McCleskey v. Zant as precedential support for applying the cause-and-prejudice standard consistently across different habeas corpus contexts, without any negative treatment.

quote: This was necessary because Brown was inconsistent with the holding of Townsend regarding habeas petitioners who failed to adequately develop federal claims in state-court proceedings.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Brown v. Allen to explain the historical development of habeas corpus law and its relationship to Townsend, without directly treating Brown itself negatively.

quote: In Wainwright v. Sykes, 433 U. S. 72 (1977), we rejected the application of Fay's standard of 'knowing waiver' or 'deliberate bypass' to excuse a petitioner's failure to comply with a state contemporaneous-objection rule, stating that the state rule deserved more respect than the Fay standard accorded it.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Wainwright v. Sykes as precedential support for rejecting the deliberate bypass standard and adopting the cause-and-prejudice standard, using it as foundational authority for the Court's reasoning.

quote: We agree with Justice O'Connor that under our holding a claim invoking the fifth circumstance of Townsend will be unavailing where the cause asserted is attorney error. Murray v. Carrier, 477 U. S. 478 (1986), and Coleman v. Thompson, 501 U. S. 722 (1991), dictate as much.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Murray v. Carrier as controlling precedent that dictates the result regarding attorney error as cause, treating it as binding authority without any negative commentary.

quote: Accordingly, the decision of the Court of Appeals is reversed, and the cause is remanded to the District Court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly overturns the Court of Appeals decision in this case, which is the same case involving Tamayo-Reyes, making this a reversal of the lower court's ruling.

quote: We have consistently reaffirmed that the 'cause-and-prejudice' standard embodies the correct accommodation between the competing concerns implicated in a federal court's habeas power. Reed v. Ross, 468 U. S. 1, 11 (1984); Engle v. Isaac, 456 U. S. 107, 129 (1982).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Reed v. Ross as support for the cause-and-prejudice standard, treating it as precedential authority that confirms the Court's approach without any negative treatment.

quote: In Francis v. Henderson, 425 U. S. 536 (1976), we acknowledged a federal court's power to entertain an application for habeas even where the claim has been procedurally waived in state proceedings, but nonetheless examined the appropriateness of the exercise of that power and recognized, as we had in Fay, that considerations of comity and concerns for the orderly administration of criminal justice may in some circumstances require a federal court to forgo the exercise of its habeas corpus power.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Francis v. Henderson as part of the historical development of habeas corpus law and as precedential support for the cause-and-prejudice standard, without any negative treatment.

quote: We decline to so expand the Harris presumption. The Harris presumption does not apply here. Coleman does not argue, nor could he, that it 'fairly appears' that the Virginia Supreme Court's decision rested primarily on federal law or was interwoven with such law.
rationale: The Acting Decision limits the scope of the Long presumption by refusing to expand it beyond cases where state court decisions fairly appear to rest primarily on federal law, thus narrowing its applicability.

quote: Coleman reads Harris too broadly. A predicate to the application of the Harris presumption is that the decision of the last state court to which the petitioner presented his federal claims must fairly appear to rest primarily on federal law or to be interwoven with federal law.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly limits Harris by clarifying that its presumption only applies when state court decisions fairly appear to rest primarily on federal law, rejecting Coleman's broader interpretation.

quote: Wainwright v. Sykes, 433 U. S. 72 (1977), applied the cause and prejudice, standard more broadly. Sykes did not object at trial to the introduction of certain inculpatory statements he had earlier made to the police.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Sykes as establishing the cause and prejudice standard for procedural defaults, providing background context without challenging its precedential value.

quote: We now make it explicit: In all cases in which a state prisoner has defaulted his federal claims in state court pursuant to an independent and adequate state procedural rule, federal habeas review of the claims is barred unless the prisoner can demonstrate cause for the default and actual prejudice as a result of the alleged violation of federal law, or demonstrate that failure to consider the claims will result in a fundamental miscarriage of justice.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly overrules Fay's deliberate bypass standard, replacing it with the cause and prejudice standard for all procedural defaults in federal habeas cases.

quote: In Daniels v. Allen , the companion case to Brown v. Allen, 344 U. S. 443 (1953), we confronted a situation nearly identical to that here.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Brown v. Allen as background context for discussing the companion case Daniels v. Allen, without any negative treatment of Brown itself.

quote: Engle v. Isaac, 456 U. S. 107 (1982), held that the standard applies even in cases in which the alleged constitutional error impaired the truthfinding function of the trial.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Engle as supporting precedent for applying the cause and prejudice standard broadly, affirming its continued validity without criticism.

quote: There is no constitutional right to an attorney in state post-conviction proceedings. Pennsylvania v. Finley, 481 U. S. 551 (1987); Murray v. Giarratano, 492 U. S. 1 (1989) (applying the rule to capital cases).
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on Finley as established precedent for the principle that there is no constitutional right to counsel in state post-conviction proceedings.

quote: Murray v. Carrier considered the circumstances under which attorney error constitutes cause. Carrier argued that his attorney's inadvertence in failing to raise certain claims in his state appeal constituted cause for the default sufficient to allow federal habeas review.
rationale: The Acting Decision applies Carrier's holding about attorney error and cause without criticism, using it as controlling precedent for the current case.

cited_decision: O'Brien v. Socony Mobil Oil Co.
quote: Coleman cites also O'Brien v. Socony Mobil Oil Co., 207 Va. 707 , 152 S. E. 2d 278 (1967). In that case, O'Brien, a civil litigant making a constitutional property rights claim, filed her notice of appeal several years late... The court then addressed O'Brien's constitutional claim on the merits and ruled against her.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes O'Brien by noting it involved different circumstances and that the Virginia Supreme Court explicitly declined to announce a rule about constitutional exceptions to time requirements.

quote: As Justice Harlan once observed, '[b]oth the individual criminal defendant and society have an interest in insuring that there will at some point be the certainty that comes with an end to litigation, and that attention will ultimately be focused not on whether a conviction was free from error but rather on whether the prisoner can be restored to a useful place in the community.' Sanders v. United States, 373 U. S. 1, 24-25 (1963) (dissenting opinion).
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes Sanders approvingly to support the principle of finality in criminal litigation, using it as supportive authority without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Roger K. Coleman v. Charles Thompson, Warden
quote: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit affirmed. 895 F. 2d 139 (1990). The court held that Coleman had defaulted all of the claims that he had presented for the first time in state habeas.
rationale: The Acting Decision references the Fourth Circuit's decision as the lower court ruling being reviewed, providing procedural background without expressing any view on its correctness.

quote: Francis v. Henderson, 425 U. S. 536 (1976), involved a Louisiana prisoner challenging in federal habeas the composition of the grand jury that had indicted him... We held that Francis' claim was barred in federal habeas unless he could establish cause and prejudice.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Francis as establishing precedent for the cause and prejudice standard in federal habeas cases, treating it as authoritative without criticism.

cited_decision: Complete Auto Transit, Inc. v. Brady
quote: Complete Auto rejected Freeman and Spector's formal distinction between 'direct' and 'indirect' taxes on interstate commerce because that formalism allowed the validity of statutes to hinge on 'legal terminology,' 'draftsmanship and phraseology.' Bellas Hess did not rely on any such labeling of taxes and therefore did not automatically fall with Freeman and its progeny.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Complete Auto to explain its four-part test and to distinguish it from the Bellas Hess rule, but does not criticize or overrule Complete Auto itself.

cited_decision: State Ex Rel. Heitkamp v. Quill Corp.
quote: The judgment of the Supreme Court of North Dakota is reversed, and the case is remanded for further proceedings not inconsistent with this opinion.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly overturns the outcome of the North Dakota Supreme Court's decision in this same case, which is the classic definition of a reversal.

cited_decision: National Bellas Hess, Inc. v. Department of Revenue
quote: Thus, to the extent that our decisions have indicated that the Due Process Clause requires physical presence in a State for the imposition of duty to collect a use tax, we overrule those holdings as superseded by developments in the law of due process... For these reasons, we disagree with the North Dakota Supreme Court's conclusion that the time has come to renounce the bright-line test of Bellas Hess.
rationale: The Acting Decision overrules the due process aspect of Bellas Hess but maintains its Commerce Clause holding, thereby limiting the scope and applicability of the Cited Decision.

cited_decision: National Geographic Society v. California Board of Equalization
quote: Thus, three weeks after Complete Auto was handed down, we cited Bellas Hess for this proposition and discussed the case at some length. In National Geographic Society v. California Bd. of Equalization, 430 U. S. 551, 559 (1977), we affirmed the continuing vitality of Bellas Hess' 'sharp distinction . . . between mail-order sellers with [a physical presence in the taxing] State and those ... who do no more than communicate with customers in the State by mail or common carrier as part of a general interstate business.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites National Geographic Society as support for the continuing validity of the Bellas Hess rule without any negative treatment.

quote: We have continued to cite Bellas Hess with approval ever since. For example, in Goldberg v. Sweet, 488 U. S. 252, 263 (1989), we expressed 'doubt that termination of an interstate telephone call, by itself, provides a substantial enough nexus for a State to tax a call. See National Bellas Hess . . . (receipt of mail provides insufficient nexus).' See also D. H. Holmes Co. v. McNamara, 486 U. S. 24, 33 (1988); Commonwealth Edison Co. v. Montana, 453 U. S. 609, 626 (1981).
rationale: The Acting Decision merely cites Commonwealth Edison Co. v. Montana as one of several cases that have cited Bellas Hess with approval, without any substantive discussion or treatment.

cited_decision: D. H. Holmes Co., Ltd. v. McNamara
quote: We have continued to cite Bellas Hess with approval ever since. For example, in Goldberg v. Sweet, 488 U. S. 252, 263 (1989), we expressed 'doubt that termination of an interstate telephone call, by itself, provides a substantial enough nexus for a State to tax a call. See National Bellas Hess . . . (receipt of mail provides insufficient nexus).' See also D. H. Holmes Co. v. McNamara, 486 U. S. 24, 33 (1988).
rationale: The Acting Decision merely cites D. H. Holmes Co. v. McNamara as one of several cases that have cited Bellas Hess with approval, without any substantive discussion or treatment.

cited_decision: Northwestern States Portland Cement Co. v. Minnesota
quote: Moreover, a bright-line rule in the area of sales and use taxes also encourages settled expectations and, in doing so, fosters investment by businesses and individuals... our law in this area is something of a 'quagmire' and the 'application of constitutional principles to specific state statutes leaves much room for controversy and confusion and little in the way of precise guides to the States in the exercise of their indispensable power of taxation.' Northwestern States Portland Cement Co. v. Minnesota, 358 U. S. 450, 457-458 (1959).
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes Northwestern States Portland Cement Co. v. Minnesota to support the argument for maintaining bright-line rules in tax law, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Arkansas Electric Cooperative Corp. v. Arkansas Public Service Commission
quote: None of those factors obtains in this case.
