First, the Attleboro rule was 'anachronistic' because it relied on formal distinctions between 'direct' and 'indirect' regulation (and on the regulatory counterparts of our Freeman line of cases); as discussed above, Bellas Hess turned on a different logic and thus remained sound after the Court repudiated an analogous distinction in Complete Auto.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Arkansas Electric Cooperative Corp. by explaining that the factors that led to overruling the bright-line test in that case do not apply to the Bellas Hess situation, thereby showing the cases involve different circumstances.

quote: Bramblett is hereby overruled. We hold that a federal court is neither a 'department' nor an 'agency' within the meaning of § 1001.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Bramblett is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value and casting doubt on its authority.

quote: Although such a reconsideration is appropriate only in the rarest circumstances, we believe this case permits it because of a highly unusual 'intervening development of the law,' see Patterson, 491 U. S., at 173
rationale: The Acting Decision references Patterson to support its analysis of when reconsideration of precedent is appropriate, without criticizing or questioning its authority.

cited_decision: Daniel Jackson Oliver Wendel Holmes Morgan v. United States
quote: The seeds of the exception were planted by the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit only seven years after Bramblett was decided. In Morgan v. United States, 309 F. 2d 234 (1962), cert. denied, 373 U. S. 917 (1963), the defendant, who had falsely held himself out to be a bona fide member of the bar, was prosecuted on three counts of violating § 1001
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Morgan as the origin of the judicial function exception without criticizing its reasoning, merely providing historical context for the development of the exception.

cited_decision: United States v. James Ralph Erhardt
quote: Relying on Morgan, the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit reversed a conviction several years later 'because § 1001 does not apply to the introduction of false documents as evidence in a criminal proceeding.' United States v. Erhardt, 381 F. 2d 173, 175 (1967) (per curiam).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Erhardt as part of the historical development of the judicial function exception without expressing disagreement with its reasoning or outcome.

quote: Respect for precedent is strongest 'in the area of statutory construction, where Congress is free to change this Court's interpretation of its legislation.' Illinois Brick Co. v. Illinois, 431 U. S. 720, 736 (1977).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Illinois Brick Co. to support the principle that stare decisis has special force in statutory interpretation, without questioning or criticizing the decision.

cited_decision: Burnet v. Coronado Oil & Gas Co.
quote: 'Stare decisis is usually the wise policy, because in most matters it is more important that the applicable rule of law be settled than that it be settled right. This is commonly true even where the error is a matter of serious concern, provided correction can be had by legislation.' Id., at 406 (citations omitted).
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes Burnet approvingly to explain the general principle of stare decisis, using it to support the discussion of when precedent should be followed despite potential errors.

quote: But the reasoning of Sinclair has already been repudiated in a number of respects... Other reasoning in Sinclair, not yet repudiated, we repudiate now... we think stare decisis cannot possibly be controlling when, in addition to those factors, the decision in question has been proved manifestly erroneous, and its underpinnings eroded, by subsequent decisions of this Court.
rationale: The Court explicitly repudiates the reasoning in Sinclair that had not already been repudiated by other decisions, finding it manifestly erroneous and its underpinnings eroded by subsequent Court decisions.

quote: in United States v. Olano, 507 U.S. 725, 732 (1993), the Court noted the limitations on 'plain error' review by the courts of appeals under Rule 52(b).
rationale: The Court references Olano to explain the standards for plain error review without criticizing or questioning its precedential value, merely using it to clarify the applicable legal framework.

cited_decision: United States v. Michael E. Gaudin
quote: A panel of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed these convictions because Circuit precedent dictated that materiality in a §1001 prosecution be decided by the jury. 997 F. 2d 1267 (1993). On rehearing en banc, the Court of Appeals stood by this precedent. It held that taking the question of materiality from the jury denied respondent a right guaranteed by the Fifth and Sixth Amendments to the United States Constitution. 28 F. 3d 943 (1994).
rationale: The Court simply describes the procedural history and the lower court's holding without any criticism or analysis of the decision's reasoning, ultimately affirming the Court of Appeals' judgment.

quote: We have held that these provisions require criminal convictions to rest upon a jury determination that the defendant is guilty of every element of the crime with which he is charged, beyond a reasonable doubt. Sullivan v. Louisiana, 508 U.S. 275, 277-278 (1993).
rationale: The Court cites Sullivan favorably as support for the principle that criminal convictions must rest upon jury determination of every element, using it as precedential authority without any negative treatment.

quote: Within broad constitutional bounds, legislatures have flexibility in defining the elements of a criminal offense. See Patterson v. New York, 432 U.S. 197, 210 (1977).
rationale: The Court cites Patterson as authority for the principle that legislatures have flexibility in defining criminal offense elements, using it supportively without any criticism or limitation of its precedential value.

quote: Sparf, supra, the case on which the Government relies, had nothing to do with the issue before us here. The question there was whether the jury could be deprived of the power to determine, not only historical facts, not only mixed questions of fact and law, but pure questions of law in a criminal case... But our decision in no way undermined the historical and constitutionally guaranteed right of criminal defendants to demand that the jury decide guilt or innocence on every issue, which includes application of the law to the facts.
rationale: The Court distinguishes Sparf by explaining that it dealt with a different issue (pure questions of law rather than mixed questions of law and fact) and clarifies that Sparf does not undermine the defendant's right to jury determination on mixed questions.

quote: It is hard to imagine questions more diverse than, on the one hand, whether an appellate court must remand to a district court for a determination of materiality in a denaturalization proceeding (Kungys) and, on the other hand, whether the Constitution requires the finding of the element of materiality in a criminal prosecution to be made by the jury (the present case)... Kungys assuredly did not involve an adjudication to which the Sixth Amendment right to jury trial attaches... Whatever support it gave to the validity of those decisions was obiter dicta, and may properly be disregarded.
rationale: The Court distinguishes Kungys by explaining that it involved a fundamentally different question (appellate remand in denaturalization proceedings) that did not implicate Sixth Amendment jury trial rights, and dismisses any contrary support as obiter dicta.

quote: The fountainhead of the same-conduct rule, he asserts, is In re Nielsen, 131 U. S. 176 (1889). That is demonstrably wrong. Nielsen simply applies the common proposition, entirely in accord with Blockburger, that prosecution for a greater offense (cohabitation, defined to require proof of adultery) bars prosecution for a lesser included offense (adultery).
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Nielsen extensively but does not criticize or overrule it. Instead, it clarifies Nielsen's holding as being consistent with established precedent rather than creating new law.

quote: We have concluded, however, that Grady must be overruled. Unlike Blockburger analysis, whose definition of what prevents two crimes from being the same offence, U. S. Const., Amdt. 5, has deep historical roots and has been accepted in numerous precedents of this Court, Grady lacks constitutional roots.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly overrules Grady v. Corbin, finding it inconsistent with earlier precedent and lacking constitutional foundation.

quote: In both the multiple punishment and multiple prosecution contexts, this Court has concluded that where the two offenses for which the defendant is punished or tried cannot survive the same-elements test, the double jeopardy bar applies. See, e. g., Brown v. Ohio, 432 U. S. 161, 168-169 (1977).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Brown v. Ohio as supporting authority for the same-elements test without any negative treatment or criticism.

quote: Both the Government, Brief for United States 15-17, and Justice Blackmun, post, at 743, contend that the legal obligation in Dixons case may serve interests . . . fundamentally different from the substantive criminal law, because it derives in part from the determination of a court rather than a determination of the legislature. That distinction seems questionable, since the courts power to establish conditions of release, and to punish their violation, was conferred by statute; the legislature was the ultimate source of both the criminal and the contempt prohibition.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Grafton in various contexts but does not subject it to negative treatment, using it primarily for analytical comparison.

quote: In this situation, in which the contempt sanction is imposed for violating the order through commission of the incorporated drug offense, the later attempt to prosecute Dixon for the drug offense resembles the situation that produced our judgment of double jeopardy in Harris v. Oklahoma, 433 U. S. 682 (1977) (per curiam).
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on Harris v. Oklahoma as supporting precedent for its analysis, applying its reasoning to the case at hand without criticism.

quote: We have described our terse per curiam in Harris as standing for the proposition that, for double jeopardy purposes, the crime generally described as felony murder is not a separate offense distinct from its various elements. Illinois v. Vitale, 447 U. S. 410, 420-421 (1980).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Vitale as explanatory authority for understanding Harris, without any negative treatment or disagreement with its holding.

cited_decision: Young v. United States Ex Rel. Vuitton Et Fils S. A. (1987)
quote: Indeed, we recognized in Young, supra, that contempt proceedings are not intended to punish conduct proscribed as harmful by the general criminal laws. Rather, they are designed to serve the limited purpose of vindicating the authority of the court.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Young as supporting authority for understanding the purpose of contempt proceedings, without any criticism or negative treatment.

quote: In contrast to the above-discussed dicta relied upon by Justice Souter, there are two pre-Grady (and post Nielsen) cases that are directly on point. In both Gavieres v. United States, 220 U. S., at 343, and Burton v. United States, 202 U. S. 344, 379-381 (1906), the Court upheld subsequent prosecutions after concluding that the Blockburger test (and only the Blockburger test) was satisfied.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Gavieres as supporting precedent for the Blockburger test being the exclusive standard, using it to support its position without negative treatment.

quote: In contrast to the above-discussed dicta relied upon by Justice Souter, there are two pre-Grady (and post Nielsen) cases that are directly on point. In both Gavieres v. United States, 220 U. S., at 343, and Burton v. United States, 202 U. S. 344, 379-381 (1906), the Court upheld subsequent prosecutions after concluding that the Blockburger test (and only the Blockburger test) was satisfied.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Burton alongside Gavieres as supporting precedent for the Blockburger test, without any criticism or negative treatment.

quote: It is well established that criminal contempt, at least the sort enforced through nonsummary proceedings, is a crime in the ordinary sense. Bloom, supra, at 201.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Bloom as established authority for the proposition that criminal contempt is a crime in the ordinary sense, without any disagreement or criticism.

quote: The Double Jeopardy Clause prevents the government from mak[ing] repeated attempts to convict an individual for an alleged offense, thereby subjecting him to embarrassment, expense and ordeal and compelling him to live in a continuing state of anxiety and insecurity. Green v. United States, 355 U. S. 184, 187 (1957).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Green as authority for explaining the purposes behind the Double Jeopardy Clause protection, without any negative treatment.

quote: Of course, it follows that to the extent (if any) that Fullilove held federal racial classifications to be subject to a less rigorous standard, it is no longer controlling. But we need not decide today whether the program upheld in Fullilove would survive strict scrutiny as our more recent cases have defined it.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that Fullilove is no longer controlling to the extent it applied a less rigorous standard than strict scrutiny, thereby limiting its precedential scope and applicability.

cited_decision: City of Richmond v. J. A. Croson Co.
quote: With Croson, the Court finally agreed that the Fourteenth Amendment requires strict scrutiny of all race-based action by state and local governments.
rationale: The Court references Croson positively as establishing the principle of strict scrutiny for state and local racial classifications, using it as support for extending the same standard to federal classifications.

cited_decision: Metro Broadcasting, Inc. v. Federal Communications Commission
quote: Accordingly, we hold today that all racial classifications, imposed by whatever federal, state, or local governmental actor, must be analyzed by a reviewing court under strict scrutiny. In other words, such classifications are constitutional only if they are narrowly tailored measures that further compelling governmental interests. To the extent that Metro Broadcasting is inconsistent with that holding, it is overruled.
rationale: The Court explicitly overrules Metro Broadcasting to the extent it is inconsistent with the holding that all racial classifications must be subject to strict scrutiny, rejecting its intermediate scrutiny standard for federal racial classifications.

cited_decision: Wygant v. Jackson Board of Education
quote: Justice Powell's plurality opinion observed that 'the level of scrutiny does not change merely because the challenged classification operates against a group that historically has not been subject to governmental discrimination,' id., at 273, and stated the two-part inquiry as 'whether the layoff provision is supported by a compelling state purpose and whether the means chosen to accomplish that purpose are narrowly tailored.'
rationale: The Court cites Wygant approvingly as support for the principle that strict scrutiny applies to racial classifications regardless of which group is burdened or benefited.

cited_decision: Regents of the University of California v. Bakke
quote: Justice Powell's defense of this conclusion bears repeating here: 'If it is the individual who is entitled to judicial protection against classifications based upon his racial or ethnic background because such distinctions impinge upon personal rights, rather than the individual only because of his membership in a particular group, then constitutional standards may be applied consistently.'
rationale: The Court favorably cites Justice Powell's opinion in Bakke as supporting the principle that constitutional standards should be applied consistently to all racial classifications, regardless of the race of those affected.

quote: When the Court first faced a Fifth Amendment equal protection challenge to a federal racial classification, it adopted a similar approach, with most unfortunate results. In Hirabayashi v. United States, 320 U. S. 81 (1943), the Court considered a curfew applicable only to persons of Japanese ancestry.
rationale: The Court characterizes Hirabayashi as having 'most unfortunate results' and uses it as an example of the problematic approach of applying different standards to federal versus state racial classifications.

quote: In Bolling v. Sharpe, 347 U. S. 497 (1954), the Court for the first time explicitly questioned the existence of any difference between the obligations of the Federal Government and the States to avoid racial classifications.
rationale: The Court cites Bolling approvingly as establishing the principle that the Federal Government and States have equivalent obligations under equal protection, supporting the Court's holding that the same strict scrutiny standard should apply to both.

quote: The District Court granted the Government's motion for summary judgment. Adarand Constructors, Inc. v. Skinner, 790 F. Supp. 240 (1992).
rationale: The Court merely references the lower court decision as part of the procedural history without any substantive analysis or treatment of its reasoning.

quote: (We note, incidentally, that this case concerns only classifications based explicitly on race, and presents none of the additional difficulties posed by laws that, although facially race neutral, result in racially disproportionate impact and are motivated by a racially discriminatory purpose. See generally Arlington Heights v. Metropolitan Housing Development Corp., 429 U. S. 252 (1977); Washington v. Davis, 426 U. S. 229 (1976).)
rationale: The Court references Washington v. Davis only to distinguish the current case, noting that it deals with explicit racial classifications rather than facially neutral laws with discriminatory impact.

quote: Korematsu demonstrates vividly that even 'the most rigid scrutiny' can sometimes fail to detect an illegitimate racial classification, compare Korematsu, 323 U. S., at 223 ('To cast this case into outlines of racial prejudice, without reference to the real military dangers which were presented, merely confuses the issue. Korematsu was not excluded from the Military Area because of hostility to him or his race'), with Pub. L. 100-383, § 2 (a), 102 Stat. 903 -904 ('[Tjhese actions [of relocating and interning civilians of Japanese ancestry] were carried out without adequate security reasons .. . and were motivated largely by racial prejudice, wartime hysteria, and a failure of political leadership').
rationale: The Court criticizes Korematsu as an example of how even purportedly strict scrutiny failed to prevent an illegitimate racial classification, noting that Congress later acknowledged the decision was motivated by racial prejudice rather than legitimate security concerns.

quote: As recently as 1987, for example, every Justice of this Court agreed that the Alabama Department of Public Safety's 'pervasive, systematic, and obstinate discriminatory conduct' justified a narrowly tailored race-based remedy. See United States v. Paradise, 480 U. S., at 167 (plurality opinion of Brennan, J.); id., at 190 (Stevens, J., concurring in judgment); id., at 196 (O'Connor, J., dissenting).
rationale: The Court cites Paradise as an example of when race-based remedial action can be constitutional under strict scrutiny, demonstrating that strict scrutiny is not necessarily fatal to all racial classifications.

cited_decision: Central Hudson Gas & Electric Corp. v. Public Service Commission
quote: In Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of N. Y., 447 U. S. 557 (1980), we took stock of our developing commercial speech jurisprudence.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Central Hudson as establishing the framework for commercial speech analysis and applies its test, without criticizing or limiting its precedential value.

cited_decision: Virginia State Board of Pharmacy v. Virginia Citizens Consumer Council, Inc.
quote: In Virginia Bd. of Pharmacy v. Virginia Citizens Consumer Council, Inc., 425 U. S. 748 (1976), we expanded on our holding in Bigelow and held that the State's blanket ban on advertising the price of prescription drugs violated the First Amendment.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Virginia Board of Pharmacy favorably as foundational precedent for commercial speech protection, providing additional analysis without questioning its validity.

cited_decision: Posadas De Puerto Rico Associates v. Tourism Co. of Puerto Rico
quote: The reasoning in Posadas does support the State's argument, but, on reflection, we are now persuaded that Posadas erroneously performed the First Amendment analysis.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Posadas 'erroneously performed the First Amendment analysis' and rejects its reasoning, though it does not have authority to formally overrule it.

quote: Last Term we held that a federal law abridging a brewer's right to provide the public with accurate information about the alcoholic content of malt beverages is unconstitutional. Rubin v. Coors Brewing Co., 514 U. S. 476, 491 (1995).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Rubin favorably as recent precedent supporting its analysis, using it to reinforce the constitutional protection of commercial speech.

quote: The parties stipulated that the price advertising ban is vigorously enforced, that Rhode Island permits 'all advertising of alcoholic beverages excepting references to price outside the licensed premises,' and that petitioners' proposed ads do not concern an illegal activity and presumably would not be false or misleading. 44 Liquor Mart, Inc. v. Racine, 829 F. Supp. 543, 545 (RI 1993).
rationale: The Acting Decision references the lower court decision factually to establish the procedural history and factual findings, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: City of Cincinnati v. Discovery Network, Inc.
quote: It is the State's interest in protecting consumers from 'commercial harms' that provides 'the typical reason why commercial speech can be subject to greater governmental regulation than noncommercial speech.' Cincinnati v. Discovery Network, Inc., 507 U. S. 410, 426 (1993).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Discovery Network to support its analysis of when commercial speech regulations are appropriate, using it as authoritative precedent.

cited_decision: United States v. Edge Broadcasting Co.
quote: In Edge, we upheld a federal statute that permitted only those broadcasters located in States that had legalized lotteries to air lottery advertising. The statute was designed to regulate advertising about an activity that had been deemed illegal in the jurisdiction in which the broadcaster was located. 509 U. S., at 433-434 . Here, by contrast, the commercial speech ban targets information about entirely lawful behavior.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Edge Broadcasting by noting that it involved advertising about illegal activity, whereas the current case involves advertising about lawful behavior, making Edge inapplicable.

cited_decision: Linmark Associates, Inc. v. Township of Willingboro
quote: For example, in Linmark, 431 U. S., at 92-94 , we concluded that a ban on 'For Sale' signs was 'content based' and failed to leave open 'satisfactory' alternative channels of communication.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Linmark favorably as precedent supporting the principle that complete speech bans are particularly dangerous and must leave open alternative channels of communication.

cited_decision: Florida Bar v. Went for It, Inc.
quote: Moreover, last Term we upheld a 30-day prohibition against a certain form of legal solicitation largely because it left so many channels of communication open to Florida lawyers. Florida Bar v. Went For It, Inc., 515 U. S. 618, 633-634 (1995).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Went for It to illustrate the principle that speech restrictions are more likely to be upheld when they leave alternative channels of communication open.

cited_decision: Michigan Beer & Wine Wholesalers Ass'n v. Attorney General
quote: Moreover, it agreed with the reasoning of the Rhode Island Supreme Court that the Twenty-first Amendment gave the statutes an added presumption of validity. Id., at 8 . Alternatively, it concluded that reversal was compelled by this Court's summary action in Queensgate Investment Co. v. Liquor Control Comm'n of Ohio, 459 U. S. 807 (1982). See 39 F. 3d, at 8 . In that case the Court dismissed the appeal from a decision of the Ohio Supreme Court upholding a prohibition against off-premises advertising of the prices of alcoholic beverages sold by the drink. See Queensgate Investment Co. v. Liquor Control Comm'n of Ohio, 69 Ohio St. 2d 361 , 433 N. E. 2d 138 (1982). Queensgate has been both followed and distinguished in subsequent cases reviewing the validity of similar advertising bans.
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions the Michigan case in a footnote as one of the cases that distinguished Queensgate, providing factual background without any treatment of the Michigan decision itself.

quote: We are now persuaded that the Court's analysis in LaRue would have led to precisely the same result if it had placed no reliance on the Twenty-first Amendment... Without questioning the holding in LaRue , we now disavow its reasoning insofar as it relied on the Twenty-first Amendment.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly limits LaRue by disavowing its reasoning regarding the Twenty-first Amendment, while preserving its holding, thus narrowing the scope and applicability of the decision.

quote: We believe that Halper's deviation from longstanding double jeopardy principles was ill considered. As subsequent cases have demonstrated, Halper's test for determining whether a particular sanction is 'punitive,' and thus subject to the strictures of the Double Jeopardy Clause, has proved unworkable.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly criticizes Halper's approach as 'ill considered' and 'unworkable,' disagreeing with its reasoning and methodology for determining punitive sanctions.

quote: In making this latter determination, the factors listed in Kennedy v. Mendoza-Martinez, 372 U. S. 144, 168-169 (1963), provide useful guideposts
rationale: The Acting Decision references Kennedy favorably as providing useful factors for analysis without criticizing or questioning its precedential value.

cited_decision: Department of Revenue of Mont. v. Kurth Ranch
quote: We have since recognized that all civil penalties have some deterrent effect. See Department of Revenue of Mont. v. Kurth Ranch, 511 U. S. 767, 777, n. 14 (1994)
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Kurth Ranch as support for the proposition that all civil penalties have deterrent effect, using it as authority without negative treatment.

quote: Our reasons for so holding in large part disavow the method of analysis used in United States v. Halper, 490 U. S. 435, 448 (1989), and reaffirm the previously established rule exemplified in United States v. Ward, 448 U. S. 242, 248-249 (1980).
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly reaffirms Ward as the proper approach and uses it as the foundation for its analysis, treating it favorably as established precedent.

quote: We have since recognized that all civil penalties have some deterrent effect. See Department of Revenue of Mont. v. Kurth Ranch, 511 U. S. 767, 777, n. 14 (1994); United States v. Ursery, 518 U. S. 267, 284-285, n. 2 (1996).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Ursery as supporting authority for the principle that civil penalties have deterrent effects, using it without negative treatment.

quote: The Clause protects only against the imposition of multiple criminal punishments for the same offense, Helvering v. Mitchell, 303 U. S. 391, 399 (1938)
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Helvering as authority for the principle that the Double Jeopardy Clause protects only against multiple criminal punishments, using it as supportive precedent.

quote: While petitioners have been prohibited from further participating in the banking industry, this is 'certainly nothing approaching the infamous punishment' of imprisonment.' Flemming v. Nestor, 363 U. S. 603, 617 (1960).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Flemming as authority for distinguishing between different types of sanctions, using it supportively in its analysis.

quote: This fact is insufficient to render the money penalties and debarment sanctions criminally punitive, Ursery, 518 U. S., at 292, particularly in the double jeopardy context, see United States v. Dixon, 509 U. S. 688, 704 (1993) (rejecting 'same-conduct' test for double jeopardy purposes).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Dixon as supporting authority for rejecting the 'same-conduct' test in double jeopardy analysis, using it favorably without negative treatment.

quote: In this ease, we are asked to reconsider that decision in light of subsequent decisions of this Court. We conclude that Albrecht should be overruled.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that Albrecht should be overruled, directly nullifying the precedential value of the decision that established vertical maximum price fixing as a per se violation.

cited_decision: Continental T. V., Inc. v. GTE Sylvania Inc.
quote: Nine years later, in Continental T. V., Inc. v. GTE Sylvania Inc., 438 U. S. 36 (1977), the Court overruled Schwinn, thereby rejecting application of a per se rule in the context of vertical nonprice restrictions.
rationale: The Court references GTE Sylvania as supportive precedent that weakened Albrecht's analytical underpinnings, but does not criticize or question the decision itself.

cited_decision: Barkat U. Khan and Khan & Associates, Inc. v. State Oil Company
quote: We therefore vacate the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remand the ease for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
rationale: The Supreme Court vacated and remanded the Court of Appeals decision, directly overturning the lower court's ruling that was based on the now-overruled Albrecht precedent.

cited_decision: Atlantic Richfield Co. v. USA Petroleum Co.
quote: Most recently, in ARCO, 495 U. S. 328 (1990), although Al-brecht's continuing validity was not squarely before the Court, some disfavor with that decision was signaled by our statement that we would 'assume, arguendo, that Albrecht correctly held that vertical, maximum price fixing is subject to the per se rule.'
rationale: The Court cites ARCO as evidence that previous decisions had already signaled disfavor with Albrecht, using it to support the overruling without criticizing ARCO itself.

cited_decision: Arizona v. Maricopa County Medical Society
quote: As a consequence, most antitrust claims are analyzed under a 'rule of reason,' according to which the finder of fact must decide whether the questioned practice imposes an unreasonable restraint on competition, taking into account a variety of factors, including specific information about the relevant business, its condition before and after the restraint was imposed, and the restraint's history, nature, and effect. 457 U. S., at 343
rationale: The Court references Maricopa County as established precedent explaining the rule of reason analysis without any negative treatment or criticism of the decision.

cited_decision: United States v. Arnold, Schwinn & Co.
quote: Four years later, in United States v. Arnold, Schwinn & Co., 388 U. S. 365 (1967), the Court reconsidered the status of exclusive dealer territories and held that, upon the transfer of title to goods to a distributor, a supplier's imposition of territorial restrictions on the distributor was 'so obviously destructive of competition' as to constitute a per se violation of the Sherman Act.
rationale: The Court mentions Schwinn as historical context for understanding the development of antitrust law leading to Albrecht, noting that Schwinn was later overruled by GTE Sylvania, but does not itself treat Schwinn negatively.

cited_decision: Zobrest v. Catalina Foothills School District
quote: In Zobrest v. Catalina Foothills School Dist., 509 U. S. 1 (1993), we examined whether the IDEA, 20 U. S. C. § 1400 et seq., was constitutional as applied to a deaf student who sought to bring his state-employed sign-language interpreter with him to his Roman Catholic high school. We held that this was permissible, expressly disavowing the notion that 'the Establishment Clause [laid] down [an] absolute bar to the placing of a public employee in a sectarian school.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Zobrest favorably as precedent that supports its reasoning, using it to justify overruling Aguilar without criticizing or questioning its validity.

quote: We therefore hold that a federally funded program providing supplemental, remedial instruction to disadvantaged children on a neutral basis is not invalid under the Establishment Clause when such instruction is given on the premises of sectarian schools by government employees pursuant to a program containing safeguards such as those present here... Accordingly, we must acknowledge that Aguilar, as well as the portion of Ball addressing Grand Rapids' Shared Time program, are no longer good law.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Aguilar is 'no longer good law' and overrules it, directly nullifying its precedential value.

cited_decision: Witters v. Washington Department of Services for the Blind
quote: In Witters v. Washington Dept. of Servs. for Blind, 474 U. S. 481 (1986), we held that the Establishment Clause did not bar a State from issuing a vocational tuition grant to a blind person who wished to use the grant to attend a Christian college and become a pastor, missionary, or youth director.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Witters favorably as supporting precedent for its analysis, using it to demonstrate changes in Establishment Clause jurisprudence without questioning its validity.

cited_decision: School District of Grand Rapids v. Ball
quote: Accordingly, we must acknowledge that Aguilar, as well as the portion of Ball addressing Grand Rapids' Shared Time program, are no longer good law... We therefore overrule Ball and Aguilar to the extent those decisions are inconsistent with our current understanding of the Establishment Clause.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly overrules Ball, stating that portions of it are 'no longer good law' and expressly overruling it to the extent it is inconsistent with current Establishment Clause understanding.

quote: The Court conducted its analysis by applying the three-part test set forth in Lemon v. Kurtzman, 403 U. S. 602 (1971): 'First, the statute must have a secular legislative purpose; second, its principal or primary effect must be one that neither advances nor inhibits religion; finally, the statute must not foster an excessive government entanglement with religion.'
rationale: The Acting Decision references Lemon as the established test framework without criticizing or questioning its validity, treating it as established precedent.

cited_decision: Felton v. Secretary, United States Dept. of Ed.
quote: Recognizing that more than 90% of the private schools within the Board's jurisdiction are sectarian, Felton v. Secretary, United States Dept. of Ed., 739 F. 2d 48, 51 (CA2 1984), the Board initially arranged to transport children to public schools for after-school Title I instruction.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case merely for factual background information about the percentage of sectarian schools, without any substantive legal analysis or treatment.

cited_decision: Board of Ed. of Kiryas Joel Village School Dist. v. Grumet
quote: Five Justices joined opinions calling for reconsideration of Aguilar. See 512 U. S., at 718 (O'Connor, J., concurring in part and concurring in judgment); id., at 731 (Kennedy, J., concurring in judgment); id., at 750 (Scalia, J., joined by Rehnquist, C. J., and Thomas, J., dissenting). But the question of Aguilar's propriety was not before us.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Kiryas Joel to note that five Justices called for reconsidering Aguilar, but clarifies this did not constitute a change in law, treating it as factual background.

quote: First, drawing upon the analysis in Meek v. Pittenger, 421 U. S. 349 (1975), the Court observed that 'the teachers participating in the programs may become involved in intentionally or inadvertently inculcating particular religious tenets or beliefs.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Meek as part of its analysis of prior precedent that supported the reasoning in Ball and Aguilar, without directly criticizing Meek itself.

cited_decision: Rufo v. Inmates of Suffolk County Jail
quote: In Rufo v. Inmates of Suffolk County Jail, supra, at 384, we held that it is appropriate to grant a Rule 60(b)(5) motion when the party seeking relief from an injunction or consent decree can show 'a significant change either in factual conditions or in law.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Rufo favorably as establishing the standard for Rule 60(b)(5) motions, using it as supportive precedent without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Rosenberger v. Rector & Visitors of University of Virginia
quote: Petitioners also argue that there have been two significant legal developments since Aguilar was decided: a majority of Justices have expressed their views that Aguilar should be reconsidered or overruled, see supra, at 214; and Aguilar has in any event been undermined by subsequent Establishment Clause decisions, including Witters v. Washington Dept. of Servs. for Blind, 474 U. S. 481 (1986), Zobrest v. Catalina Foothills School Dist., 509 U. S. 1 (1993), and Rosenberger v. Rector and Visitors of Univ. of Va., 515 U. S. 819 (1995).
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions Rosenberger as one of the subsequent decisions that undermined Aguilar, treating it as supportive precedent for the changed legal landscape.

quote: See Bowen v. Kendrick, 487 U. S. 589, 602-604 (1988) (concluding that Adolescent Family Life Act had a secular purpose); Board of Ed. of Westside Community Schools (Dist. 66) v. Mergens, 496 U. S. 226, 248-249 (1990) (concluding that Equal Access Act has a secular purpose)
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Bowen as an example of cases that continue to apply established Establishment Clause principles, treating it as supportive precedent without any negative treatment.

quote: Our decision, we must acknowledge, is in direct conflict with the portion of our decision in House v. Mayo, 324 U. S. 42, 44 (1945) (per curiam), holding that we lack statutory certiorari jurisdiction to review refusals to issue certificates of probable cause. Given the number and frequency of the cases, and the difficulty of reconciling our practice with a requirement that only an extraordinary writ can be used to address them, we do not think stare decisis concerns require us to adhere to that decision. Its conclusion was erroneous, and it should not be followed.
rationale: The Court explicitly states that its decision is in direct conflict with House v. Mayo and declares that the conclusion was erroneous and should not be followed, which constitutes an express overruling of the precedent.

quote: In Ex parte Quirin, 317 U. S. 1 (1942), we confronted the analogous question whether a request for leave to file a petition for a writ of habeas corpus was a case in a district court for the purposes of the then-extant statute governing court of appeals review of district court decisions. We held the request for leave constituted a case in the district court over which the court of appeals could assert jurisdiction, even though the district court had denied the request.
rationale: The Court cites Ex Parte Quirin as supportive precedent for its position that threshold jurisdictional inquiries can constitute cases for review purposes, without criticizing or questioning the decision's validity.

quote: Stare decisis is 'the preferred course because it promotes the evenhanded, predictable, and consistent development of legal principles, fosters reliance on judicial decisions, and contributes to the actual and perceived integrity of the judicial process.' Payne v. Tennessee, 501 U. S. 808, 827 (1991).
rationale: The Court quotes Payne v. Tennessee to explain the general principle of stare decisis without any criticism or negative treatment, using it as authority for the importance of precedent.

quote: For example, we have felt less constrained to follow precedent where, as here, the opinion was rendered without full briefing or argument. Gray v. Mississippi, 481 U. S. 648, 651, n. 1 (1987) (questioning the precedential value of Davis v. Georgia, 429 U. S. 122 (1976) (per curiam)).
rationale: The Court cites Gray v. Mississippi as support for the proposition that opinions rendered without full briefing have reduced precedential value, using it as authority without any negative treatment.

quote: We now overrule Evans insofar as it holds that the Compensation Clause forbids Congress to apply a generally applicable, nondiscriminatory tax to the salaries of federal judges, whether or not they were appointed before enactment of the tax.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it overrules Evans v. Gore regarding its holding that the Compensation Clause forbids nondiscriminatory taxes on federal judges' salaries.

quote: In 1939, 14 years after Miles extended Evans' tax immunity to judges appointed after enactment of the tax, this Court retreated from that extension. See O'Malley, 307 U.S., at 283 (overruling Miles). And in so doing the Court, in an opinion announced by Justice Frankfurter, adopted the reasoning of the Evans dissent.
rationale: The Acting Decision references O'Malley favorably as precedent that supports its reasoning, without criticizing or questioning its validity, and uses it to support overruling Evans.

quote: The Will Year One example, however, shows only that, in the circumstances, and unlike the case before us, the later salary increase was related to the earlier salary diminishment.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Will by noting that the circumstances in Will were different from the present case, specifically regarding whether later salary increases cured constitutional violations.

quote: The Federal Circuit reversed, ordering summary judgment for the judges as to liability. 64 F. 3d 647 (1995).
rationale: The Acting Decision merely references this lower court decision as part of the procedural history without any substantive analysis or treatment of its reasoning.

cited_decision: Seminole Tribe of Florida v. Florida
quote: Our decision three Terms ago in Seminole Tribe, supra, held that the power 'to regulate Commerce' conferred by Article I of the Constitution gives Congress no authority to abrogate state sovereign immunity.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Seminole Tribe as established precedent that supports its holding, without criticizing or questioning its validity.

cited_decision: Employees of Department of Public Health v. Department of Public Health
quote: Only nine years later, in Employees of Dept. of Public Health and Welfare of Mo. v. Department of Public Health and Welfare of Mo., 411 U. S. 279 (1973), we began to retreat from Parden.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Employees as part of the historical development of sovereign immunity jurisprudence, noting how it began the retreat from Parden without criticizing the decision itself.

cited_decision: Parden v. Terminal Railway of Alabama State Docks Department
quote: Today, we drop the other shoe: Whatever may remain of our decision in Parden is expressly overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly and completely overrules Parden, stating that it was 'ill conceived' and describing it as an 'anomaly' that should not be salvaged.

cited_decision: Welch v. Texas Department of Highways & Public Transportation
quote: Several Terms later, in Welch v. Texas Dept. of Highways and Public Transp., 483 U. S. 468 (1987), although we expressly avoided addressing the constitutionality of Congress's conditioning a State's engaging in Commerce Clause activity upon the State's waiver of sovereign immunity, we said there was 'no doubt that Parden's discussion of congressional intent to negate Eleventh Amendment immunity is no longer good law,' and overruled Parden 'to the extent [it] is inconsistent with the requirement that an abrogation of Eleventh Amendment immunity by Congress must be expressed in unmistakably clear language.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Welch as part of the historical progression that limited Parden, without criticizing Welch itself but rather using it to support the current overruling of Parden.

quote: Accordingly, our 'test for determining whether a State has waived its immunity from federal-court jurisdiction is a stringent one.' Atascadero State Hospital v. Scanlon, 478 U. S. 234, 241 (1985).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Atascadero as established precedent supporting the stringent test for waiver of sovereign immunity, without any negative treatment.

quote: 'All congressional creations of private rights of action attach recovery to the defendant's commission of some act, or possession of some status, in a field where Congress has authority to regulate conduct. Thus, all federal prescriptions are, insofar as their prospective application is concerned, in a sense conditional, and — to the extent that the objects of the prescriptions consciously engage in the activity or hold the status that produces liability — can be redescribed as invitations to 'waiver.'' Pennsylvania v. Union Gas Co., 491 U. S. 1, 43 (1989) (Scalia, J., dissenting).
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes from Justice Scalia's dissent in Union Gas to support its argument about the similarity between forced waiver and abrogation, using it as supportive authority.

cited_decision: White v. Massachusetts Council of Construction Employers, Inc.
quote: The 'market participant' cases from our dormant Commerce Clause jurisprudence, relied upon by the United States, are inapposite. See, e.g., White v. Massachusetts Council of Constr. Employers, Inc., 460 U. S. 204 (1983).
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the market participant cases, including White, are 'inapposite' to the sovereign immunity context, distinguishing them as involving different legal principles.

quote: These considerations make Congress' need to possess the power to condition entry into the market upon a waiver of sovereign immunity (as 'necessary and proper' to the exercise of its commerce power) unusually strong, for to deny Congress that power would deny Congress the power effectively to regulate private conduct. Cf. California v. Taylor, 353 U. S. 553, 566 (1957).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Taylor in the dissenting opinion as supportive authority for the argument that Congress needs flexibility to regulate commerce effectively, without any negative treatment.

quote: As authority for the abrogation in the present case, petitioner relies upon §5 of the Fourteenth Amendment, which we held in Fitzpatrick v. Bitzer, supra, and reaffirmed in Seminole Tribe, see 517 U. S., at 72-73, could be used for that purpose.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Fitzpatrick as established precedent regarding Congress's power under Section 5 of the Fourteenth Amendment to abrogate state sovereign immunity, without any criticism.

quote: In Agostini, however, we brought some clarity to our case law, by overruling two anomalous precedents (one in whole, the other in part) and by consolidating some of our previously disparate considerations under a revised test.
rationale: The Acting Decision relies heavily on Agostini as controlling precedent and uses its framework for analysis, treating it as authoritative guidance without criticism or limitation.

cited_decision: Zobrest v. Catalina Foothills School District
quote: The heart of our reasoning in Zobrest, upholding governmental provision of a sign-language interpreter to a deaf student at his Catholic high school, was as follows: 'The service at issue in this case is part of a general government program that distributes benefits neutrally to any child qualifying as 'disabled' under the [statute], without regard to the 'sectarian-nonsectarian, or public-nonpublic nature' of the school the child attends.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Zobrest approvingly as support for the principle of neutrality and private choice in government aid programs, using it to bolster the constitutional analysis.

cited_decision: Witters v. Washington Department of Services for the Blind
quote: In Witters, we held that the Establishment Clause did not bar a State from including within a neutral program providing tuition payments for vocational rehabilitation a blind person studying at a Christian college to become a pastor, missionary, or youth director.
rationale: The Acting Decision uses Witters as supportive precedent for the principle that neutral aid programs involving private choice do not violate the Establishment Clause, even when aid flows to religious institutions.

cited_decision: Board of Ed. of Central School Dist. No. 1 v. Allen
quote: The Ninth Circuit also relied, id., at 1467, on our observation in Board of Ed. of Kiryas Joel Village School Dist. v. Grumet, 512 U. S. 687 (1994), that 'we have frequently relied explicitly on the general availability of any benefit provided religious groups or individuals in turning aside Establishment Clause challenges,' id., at 704. The Ninth Circuit purported to distinguish Meek and Wolman based on the percentage of schools receiving aid that were parochial (a large percentage in those cases and a moderate percentage in Walker), 46 F. 3d, at 1468, but that court undermined this distinction when it observed that Meek also upheld 'the massive provision of textbooks to parochial schools.'
rationale: The Acting Decision references Allen as part of the historical development of Establishment Clause jurisprudence and as precedent that supports textbook lending programs, treating it as established authority.

cited_decision: Everson v. Board of Ed. of Ewing
quote: In the over 50 years since Everson v. Board of Ed. of Ewing, 330 U. S. 1 (1947), we have consistently struggled to apply these simple words in the context of governmental aid to religious schools.
rationale: The Acting Decision treats Everson as the foundational case in Establishment Clause jurisprudence regarding aid to religious schools, referencing it as the starting point for constitutional analysis in this area.

quote: To the extent that Meek and Wolman conflict with this holding, we overrule them.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly overrules Wolman, finding that its distinction between textbooks and other instructional materials is no longer good law and conflicts with the Court's current constitutional analysis.

quote: To the extent that Meek and Wolman conflict with this holding, we overrule them.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly overrules Meek, determining that its reasoning regarding instructional materials and equipment lending programs is inconsistent with current Establishment Clause doctrine.

quote: The tax deduction for educational expenses that we upheld in Mueller was, in these respects, the same as the tuition grant in Witters. We upheld it chiefly because it 'neutrally provides state assistance to a broad spectrum of citizens,' 463 U. S., at 398-399, and because 'numerous, private choices of individual parents of school-age children,' id., at 399, determined which schools would benefit from the deductions.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Mueller approvingly as precedent supporting the principles of neutrality and private choice in government aid programs, using it to strengthen the constitutional framework.

quote: Whereas in Lemon we had considered whether a statute (1) has a secular purpose, (2) has a primary effect of advancing or inhibiting religion, or (3) creates an excessive entanglement between government and religion, see 403 U. S., at 612-613, in Agostini we modified Lemon for purposes of evaluating aid to schools and examined only the first and second factors, see 521 U. S., at 222-223.
rationale: The Acting Decision limits the application of Lemon by adopting Agostini's modification of the Lemon test, reducing its three-part analysis to a more streamlined approach for school aid cases.

cited_decision: Rosenberger v. Rector & Visitors of University of Virginia
quote: Finally, in addition to relying on our decision in Zobrest and the Ninth Circuit's decision in Walker, Judge Livaudais invoked Rosenberger v. Rector and Visitors of Univ. of Va., 615 U. S. 819 (1995), in which, a few months after Walker, we held that the Establishment Clause does not require a public university to exclude a student-run religious publication from assistance available to numerous other student-run publications.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Rosenberger as supportive precedent for the principle that neutral aid programs do not violate the Establishment Clause, using it as part of the broader constitutional framework.

cited_decision: Oregon Department of Fish & Wildlife v. Klamath Indian Tribe
quote: This case does not bear the weight the State places on it, however, because it has been qualified by later decisions of this Court... More importantly, however, the State's argument that similar language in two Treaties involving different parties has precisely the same meaning reveals a fundamental misunderstanding of basic principles of treaty construction.
rationale: The Court distinguishes Klamath by explaining that the facts and treaty language are materially different, and criticizes the State's attempt to apply Klamath's holding to different treaty language and circumstances.

quote: we interpret Indian treaties to give effect to the terms as the Indians themselves would have understood them. See Washington v. Washington State Commercial Passenger Fishing Vessel Assn., 443 U. S. 658, 675-676 (1979); United States v. Winans, 198 U. S. 371, 380-381 (1905).
rationale: The Court cites Winans as supporting authority for the principle that Indian treaties should be interpreted as the Indians would have understood them, without any negative treatment.

cited_decision: Mille Lacs Band of Chippewa Indians v. Minnesota (Court of Appeals)
quote: The Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit affirmed. 124 F. 3d 904 (1997). Three parts of the Eighth Circuit's decision are relevant here.
rationale: The Court simply references the Court of Appeals decision that it is reviewing, describing its holdings without criticism or negative treatment.

quote: This case does not bear the weight the State places on it, however, because it has been qualified by later decisions of this Court... But Race Horse rested on a false premise. As subsequent cases have made clear, an Indian tribe's treaty rights to hunt, fish, and gather on state land are not irreconcilable with a State's sovereignty over the natural resources in the State.
rationale: The Court explicitly limits Race Horse by explaining that its foundational premise has been rejected by subsequent decisions, thereby narrowing its scope and applicability.

cited_decision: Washington v. Washington State Commercial Passenger Fishing Vessel Assn.
quote: we interpret Indian treaties to give effect to the terms as the Indians themselves would have understood them. See Washington v. Washington State Commercial Passenger Fishing Vessel Assn., 443 U. S. 658, 675-676 (1979)
rationale: The Court cites this decision as supporting authority for treaty interpretation principles without any negative treatment or criticism.

cited_decision: Mille Lacs Band of Chippewa Indians v. Minnesota (District Court)
quote: After a bench trial on the Phase I issues, the District Court concluded that the Mille Lacs Band retained its usufructuary rights as guaranteed by the 1837 Treaty. 861 F. Supp. 784 (1994).
rationale: The Court simply references the District Court's decision as part of the procedural history without any criticism or negative treatment.

cited_decision: Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Sawyer
quote: The Court of Appeals began its analysis of this question with a statement of black letter law: ' 'The President's power, if any, to issue the order must stem either from an act of Congress or from the Constitution itself.' ' 124 F. 3d, at 915 (quoting Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Sawyer, 343 U. S. 579, 585 (1952)).
rationale: The Court references Youngstown as establishing the basic principle regarding presidential power, citing it approvingly through the Court of Appeals' quotation.

cited_decision: New York Ex Rel. Kennedy v. Becker
quote: In New York ex rel. Kennedy v. (1916), the Court considered significantly different language. The Big Tree Treaty of 1797, as the agreement was known, provided that the Seneca were to retain 'the privilege of fishing and hunting on the said tract of land' conveyed by the agreement.
rationale: The Court references Kennedy in Justice Thomas's dissent as an example of different treaty language, without any negative treatment of the decision itself.

quote: The conservation necessity standard appears to have its origin in Tulee v. Washington, 315 U. S. 681 (1942). In the 1859 Treaty with the Yakima Indians, the Yakima reserved 'The right of taking fish at all usual and accustomed places, in common with citizens of the Territory.'
rationale: The Court references Tulee in Justice Thomas's dissent as the origin of the conservation necessity standard, without any criticism or negative treatment.

quote: We have held that Indian treaties are to be interpreted liberally in favor of the Indians... and that any ambiguities are to be resolved in their favor, Winters v. United States, 207 U.S. 564, 576-577 (1908).
rationale: The Court cites Winters as supporting authority for the principle that ambiguities in Indian treaties should be resolved in favor of the Indians, without any negative treatment.
